If it be said: тАЬthe etymological sense assisted by the context is as powerful as the customary sense, and thus рдкреБрд░реБрд╖реЛрддреНрддрдо expresses, not implies a тАШgood man.тАЩ Thus, inasmuch as there is no implication, this is but рд╢реНрд▓реЗрд╖, not рдЕрдкреНрд░рд╕реНрддреБрддрдкреНрд░рд╢рдВрд╕тАЭ We reply:тАФ No, for although here both the senses may be looked upon as it expressed, still, the customary sense even though it is рдЕрдкреНрд░рд╕реНрддреБрдд is first apprehended; the etymological sense being dependent upon the context, is apprehended afterwards. Thus there is рдЕрдкреНрд░рд╕реНрддреБрддрдкреНрд░рд╢рдВрд╕рд╛, not рд╢реНрд▓реЗрд╖ here.

Really speaking,┬╣ the poet here principally intends to impart knowledge of the matter in hand by describing what is not the matter in hand. рд╢реНрд▓реЗрд╖ is subordinate inasmuch as

__________________________________________________________________

  1. рд╡рд╕реНрддреБрддрд╕реНрддреНрд╡рддреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрд░рдХреГрддрджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдиреНрддреЗрди рдкреНрд░рдХреГрддрд╛рд╡рдмреЛрдзрдирдВ рдореБрдЦреНрдпрдВ рдХрд╡реЗрд╕реНрддрд╛рддреНрдкрд░реНрдпрд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрдГред рд╢реНрд▓реЗрд╖рд╕реНрддреБрддрджреБрдкрдпреЛрдЧрд┐рддрдпрд╛ рдЧреБрдг рдЗрддрд┐ рдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдиреЗрдиреИрд╡ рд╡реНрдпрдкрджреЗрд╢реЛ рдпреБрдХреНрдд рдЗрддрд┐ рдЬреНрдЮреЗрдпрдореН 1 Pr.

it simply helps the fulfilment of this intention. This being the case, the figure should be termed after what is principal i.e. рдЕрдкреНрд░рд╕реНрддреБрддрдкреНрд░рд╢рдВрд╕рд╛, and not after what is suborbinate, i.e. рд╢реНрд▓реЗрд╖.

The second sub-variety (5b) is instanced in рдпреЗрдирд╛ etc. verse 53. Here, the subject тАШmoonтАЩ is not paranomastic only the attributes are so. In virtue of these, paranomastic attributes, the account of a rich and a poor man is implied.

The third sub-variety (5c) is instanced in рдЖрджрд╛рдп рд╡рд╛рд░рд┐ etc.┬▓ verse 54. Here a тАШbad lord squandering his ill-gotten wealthтАЩ is in question; тАШthe ocean salting the water gathered from the rivers and thus resembling that lordтАЩ is, however, described.

рд╡рд┐рд╖реНрдгреБ and рд╕рддреНрдкреБрд░реБрд╖ are here said to resemble each other, because they possess a common property consisting in the fact that both the things are expressed by one and the same word рдкреБрд░реБрд╖реЛрддреНрддрдо,

Thus, here a тАШbad lordтАЩ is implied in virtue of simple resemblance between him and the тАШocean,тАЩ althouth there is no paronomasia.

This sub-variety is again instanced by Prad

─лpa in рдХреМрдЯрд┐рд▓реНрдп etc. page 38. Here, a warning to a poet in the company of a bad king is conveyed through the description of a woman associated with a bad husband.

This third sub-variety, *sometimes, occurs, only when the suggested senseтАФ*which is the manner in handтАФis not superimposed upon the expressed sense:тАФas instanced in рдЕрдмреНрдзреЗрд░рдореНрднрдГ etc. verse 55. Here, the factтАФthat the prosperity of a bad and fierce master is better than his adversity, for,

__________________________________________________________________

2. This verse is ascribed to рдЗрдиреНрджреБрд░рд╛рдЬ by рдХреНрд╖реЗрдореЗрдиреНрджреНрд░ in his рдФрдЪрд┐рддреНрдпрд╡рд┐рдЪреНрдЪрд╛рд░рдЪрд░реНрдЪрд╛ (рдХрд╛рд╡реНрдпрдорд╛рд▓рд╛, рдЧреБрдЪреНрдЫрдХ 1, P.139). According to рд╢рд╛рд░реНрдЩреНрдЧрдзрд░рдкрджреНрдзрддрд┐ it belongs to рд╢реНрд░реАрд╢реБрдХ or рд░реАрд╢реБрдХ See Subhasitvali, Notes 891.

in the latter state he becomes more fierce,тАФis the matter in hand. This fact is here suggested by the description of the тАШoceanтАЩ through mere resemblance. Here, all the adjectives mentioned in the verse are applicable to the ocean as well as to a bad master. Thus, the superimposition of a тАШbad lordтАЩтАФ the suggested senseтАФ upon the тАШoceanтАЩ the expressed senseтАФ is not necessary; for, the verse is intelligible even without it.

Here, the suggested sense is subordinate, and therefore this is no Suggestive Poetry. The ‘ocean’ is: с╣Зot the matter in hand and therefore its description is quiet irrelevant here. This description, in order to make itself relevant, forcibly brings in the suggested sense. Thus, the suggested sense, inasmuch as it helps the expressed sense, is subordinate to it. Thus the verse is not an example of Suggestive Poetry.

Sometimes (this sub-variety occurs), only when the suggested sense is superimposed (upon the expressed sense): as instanced in рдХрд╕реНрддреНрд╡рдВ рднреЛрдГ etc. verse 56. Here, the dialogue of a traveller and the inanimate рд╢рд╛рдЦреЛрдЯрдХ tree is impossible unless we superimpose upon the рд╢рд╛рдЦреЛрдЯрдХтАФthe expressed senseтАФthe character intended, i.e. that of a low casteman disappointed at the rejection of his hospitality by a good manтАФwhich is the suggested sense.

This is not Metaphor, for therethe superimposition is upon the matter in hand; here it is upon what is not the matter in hand. Nor is this рдЕрддрд┐рд╢рдпреЛрдХреНрддрд┐ consisting in the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди (i.e. a good and a bad man) being expressed by the same words as the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп (i.e. рд╢рд╛рдЦреЛрдЯрдХ and рд╡рдЯ); for, in рдЕрддрд┐рд╢рдпреЛрдХреНрддрд┐, the objects superimposed (i.e. рд╢рд╛рдЦреЛрдЯрдХ and рд╡рдЯ) being prominent, an address to them would be impossible.

  • Sometimes (this sub-variety occurs), when the subjected sense is partially superimposed on the expressed sense;* as instanced in рд╕реЛрд╜рдкреВрд░реНрд╡реЛ etc. verse 57. Here, рд░рд╕рдирд╛рд╡рд┐рдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рд╕ (reversion of the tongue), рд╢реВрдиреНрдпрдХрд░рддреНрд╡ (hollowness of the trunk) and рдордж (rut) are (really) no causes why the beeтАФthe expressed senseтАФ should not serve (the elephant), although they ought to be stated by the poet as such.

But when we superimpose the characters of a тАШrepulsive masterтАЩand a тАШdevoted servantтАЩ, upon the тАШelephantтАЩ and the тАШbeeтАЩ, then рд░рд╕рдирд╛рд╡рд┐рдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рд╕ (inconsistency of speech), рд╢реВрдиреНрдпрдХрд░рддреНрд╡ (poverty) andрдордж (arrogance) become fit causes why the bee (by which a тАШdevoted servantтАЩ is to be understood) should not serve the elephant (by which a тАШrepulsive masterтАЩ is to be understood). Thus, superimposition is necessary in order to render these adjectives intelligible.

тАШThe incessant movements of the elephantтАЩs earsтАЩ are, however, a (fit) cause why the bee should not serve the elephant. Hence, superimposition is not necessary in this case; for, the attribute рдХрд░реНрдгрдЪрд╛рдкрд▓ is intelligible without it. рдордж (rut) on the contrary, is a cause why the bee should (and not why it should not) serve (the elephant). But when we have recourse to the superimposition mentioned above,рдордж (arrogance) becomes a fit cause why the bee (i.e. the devoted servant) should not serve the elephant (i.e. the repulsive master). Hence, superimposition is necessary in this case. Thus, there is here superimposition in some parts and absence of superimposition in the other parts of the verse.

Thus, the account of the тАШmasterтАЩ and the тАШservantтАЩ is suggested by the description of the тАШelephantтАЩ and the тАШbeeтАЩ in virtue of the presence of paronomastic words (in the verse) which alone constitute the common property between the expressed sense and the suggested sense.

12. HYPERBOLE (рдЕрддрд┐рд╢рдпреЛрдХреНрддрд┐).

K─АRIK─А XIV and XV

K─Б. xiv and xv, abc:тАФ (1) When a subject under discourse is ascertained as (identical with another, being) swallowed up (or altogether taken in) by it; (2) when a subject under discourse is (ascertained as something) other (than ordinary); (3) when there is a supposition under a condition introduced by тАШifтАЩ; and (4) when the sequence of cause and effect is inverted, that should be understood as (the figure) Hyperbole.

That is one (kind of Hyperbole), when the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп is ascertained as (identical with) the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди, (being) swallowed up (or completely taken in by it), i.e. not being┬╣ expressed by a word different from that which expresses the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди. Thus, this kind is based upon рдЧреМрдгреА рд╕рд╛рдзреНрдпрд╡рд╕рд╛рдирд╛ рд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрд╛.

Instanced in рдХрдорд▓рдордирдореНрдн ╨╡tc. verse 58. Here, the face etc. (of the heroine), obtained from the context, are ascertained as identical with a lotus etc. By this ascertainment, the preeminent excellence of the face is brought out.

This kind is again instanced by Prad

─лpa in рдХрд▓рд╢реЗ etc in page 42. Here, the breasts etc. of a woman are apprehended as identical with a jar etc.

When a thing (belonging┬▓ to one kind) is ascertained as (belonging to a) different (kind that is superior), that is the second (kind of Hyperbole). Instanced in рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреН рд╕реМрдХреБрдорд╛рд░реНрдпрдВ etc. verse 59. Here, the beauty of a woman is ascertained as belonging to a superior kind of beauty. Thus, a distinction is here apprehended when there is really an identity;

__________________________________________________________________

  1. рдЙрдкрдореЗрдпрд╕реНрдпреЗрддрд┐ред рдЙрдкрдорд╛рдиреЗрди рдирд┐рдЧреАрд░реНрдп рдкреГрдердЧрдирд┐рд░реНрджрд┐рд╢реНрдп рдЕрдзреНрдпрд╡рд╕рд╛рдирдВ рд╕реНрд╡рд░реВрдкреЗрдг рдирд┐рд╢реНрдЪрдпрдГред Pr.
  2. рднреЗрджрдХрд╛рддрд┐рд╢рдпреЛрдХреНрддрд┐рдГ рд╕рд╛ рддрд╕реНрдпреИрд╡рд╛рдиреНрдпрддреНрд╡рд╡рд░реНрдгрдирдореНред Ku. рддрд╕реНрдпреИрд╡ рддрдЬреНрдЬрд╛рддреАрдпрд╕реНрдпреИрд╡ред рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреНрд╡рд╡рд░реНрдгрдирдВ рддрдЬреНрдЬрд╛рддрд┐рднрд┐рдиреНрдирддреНрд╡реЗрди рд╡рд░реНрдгрдирдореНред Chan.

and is thus distinguished from the first kind where an identity is apprehended when there is really a distinction.

A supposition, of course, of an impossible thing, under a condition introduced by the word рдпрджрд┐ or рдЪреЗрддреН is the third (kind of Hyperbole). The thing here is impossible, of course, because it is said here to be supposed. Instanced in рд░рд╛рдХрд╛рдпрд╛рдВ etc. verse 60. Here, According to рдЪрдХреНрд░рд╡рд░реНрддрд┐11, the likeness of the тАШfaceтАЩ to the тАШmoonтАЩ is not real but supposed. This supposition brings out prominently the excessive beauty of the тАШface.тАЩ According to рдЙрджреНрдпреЛрдд, however, in the first half, the connection between the тАШfull moonтАЩ and тАШspotlessness,тАЩ which does not really exist, is supposed to exist. In the latter half, the word рдкрд░рд╛рднрд╡ shows that the relation of resemblance which really exists between рдореБрдЦ and **рдЪрдВрдиреНрджреНрд░12**is supposed not to exist. Thus this kind has two varieties:тАФ (Supposition of) a connection when there is no connection, and supposition of no connection when there is a connection.

The fourth (kind) is when the effect is mentioned before (the cause), in order to bring out the speedy action of the cause. Inversion of the sequence of cause and effect is two-fold:тАФ The effect may be supposed (1) to precede the cause or (2) to co-exist with it. The first sub-variety (1) is instanced in рд╣реГрджрдп etc. verse 61. Here, the effect, i.e. the taking hold of M

─Бlat

─лтАЩs heart by Cupid, is mentioned before the cause, i.e. the entrance of the king into her heart.

The second sub-variety (2) may be instanced in such a verse as рд╕рдордореЗрд╡ рд╕рдорд╛рдХреНрд░рд╛рдиреНрддрдВ ╨╡tc. Raghu IV 4. Here, both the causes, i.e. тАШseating himself on his fatherтАЩs throne,тАЩ and the effect i.e. тАШconquest of the kingdoms of other kingsтАЩ, are described as occurring simultaneously.

13. THE PARALLEL (рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╡рд╕реНрддреВрдкрдорд╛)

K

─АRIK

─АS XV & XVI

K─Б. xv, d & xxvi, ab:тАФ When one common property stands twice in two sentences that is (termed) the Parallel.

When a common property is expressed by (two) different words, [for, Repetition of a word has been (already i.e. in the seventh Ull─Бsa) declared to be a fault], in the sentence expresssive of the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп and in the sentence expressive of the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди, that is рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╡рд╕реНрддреВрдкрдорд╛; (so called) because, it (literally) is тАШthat where the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди is a thing in the form of the sense of a sentence or, more correctly, тАШthat where the common property is (differently expressed) in every different sentence.тАЩ

тАШTwoтАЩ means not тАШtwoтАЩ only but тАШmany.тАЩ and тАШtwiceтАЩ means тАШmany times.тАЩ The word рдПрдХрд╕реНрдп in the K─Бrik─Б excludes рдирд┐рджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╛ and рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдиреНрдд where the common properties standing as the type (рд╡рд┐рдореНрдм) and the prototype (рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдмрд┐рдореНрдм) are necessarily two.

The resemblance intended here is implied; thus the figure differs from рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрд╛рд░реНрдереЛрдкрдорд╛ instanced in рджрд┐рд╡рд┐ рднрд╛рддрд┐ рдпрдерд╛13 etc. where the resemblance is expressed (by the word рдЗрд╡).

This figure is of two kinds:тАФ Single and Serial. Of these, Single рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╡рд╕реНрддреВрдкрдорд╛ is instanced in рджреЗрд╡реАрднрд╛рд╡рдВ рдЧрдорд┐рддрд╛ etc. verse 62.

According to some, this is an example, because the properties тАШbeing treated like an ordinary womanтАЩ and тАШfitness of being enjoyedтАЩ are identical. According to others,┬▓this is an example, because one and the same property, i.e. тАШunfitnessтАЩ is expressed by different expressions рдХрдердВ рднрдЬрддрд┐ and рди рдЦрд▓реБ. The former view is not right, because the

__________________________________________________________________

2рдЕрдерд╡рд╛ рдЕрдиреМрдЪрд┐рддреНрдпрд╕реНрдп рдПрдХрд╕реНрдп рдзрд░реНрдорд╕реНрдпреЛрдкрд╛рджрд╛рдирд╛рджреБрджрд╛рд╣рд░рдгрддреНрд╡рдорд┐рддрд┐ рдорддрд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдорд╛рд╣тАФ рдХрдердорд┐рддрд┐ред Pr.

common property expressed by рдкрд░рд┐рд╡рд╛рд░рдкрджрддреНрд╡ and рдкрд░рд┐рднреЛрдЧрдпреЛрдЧреНрдпрддреНрд╡ is not the common property that is stated in the two sentences. Here, the figure is based upon similarity. It may also be based upon dissimilarity between the two sentences; as instanced in рд╡рдВрд╢рднрд╡реЛ etc. and рдЪрдХреЛрд░реНрдп┬╣ etc.

Serial рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╡рд╕реНрддреВрдкрдорд╛ should (also) be understood (as possible); as instanced in рдпрджрд┐ рджрд╣рддрд┐ etc. verse 63. Here, the common property тАШabsence of wonderfulnessтАЩ is expressed by four different expressions рдХрд┐рдорджреНрднреБрддрдВ рдХрд┐рдВ рддрддрдГ etc. in four different sentences. The last sentence here expresses the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп, ’the fortitude of good menтАЩ being the subject under discourse. The same (i. e. рдорд╛рд▓рд╛*) should be understood (as possible) elsewhere, i.e.* in other figures also, as in рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХ14 instanced in рд╣рд░рд╡рдиреНрди etc.

14. EXEMPLIFICATION (рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдиреНрдд)

K─Б. xvi. c d:тАФ Exemplification again is the reflective representation of all these.

тАШOf theseтАЩ (means) тАШof a common property,тАЩ (тАШthe thing compared,тАЩ and тАШthe thing compared toтАЩ). This is not рдЙрдкрдорд╛; for, such words as рдпрдерд╛, рдЗрд╡ etc. are here absent. Nor is this рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдиреНрдпрд╛рд╕; for, here the relation of the general and the particular does not exist.

The term рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдиреНрдд etymologically (means) тАШthat in which the ascertainment of the matter in hand is observed,тАЩ i.e. made with authority. In other words, it is that in which the authoritativeness of the matter in hand is ascertained by means of induction from the example given in the verse.

__________________________________________________________________

1. рдЪрдХреЛрд░реНрдп рдПрд╡ рдЪрддреБрд░рд╛рд╢реНрдЪрдиреНрджреНрд░рд┐рдХрд╛рдкрд╛рдирдХрд░реНрдордгрд┐ред
рд╡рд┐рдирд╛рд╜рд╡рдиреНрддреАрд░реНрди рдирд┐рдкреБрдгрд╛рдГ рд╕реБрджреГрд╢реЛ рд░рддрдХрд░реНрдордгрд┐ S. D.

** рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдиреНрдд** is two foldтАФbeing founded upon Similarity or Contrast.

The first kind is instanced in рддреНрд╡рдпрд┐ рджреГрд╖реНрдЯ etc. verse 64. Here, the commen properties рдирд┐рд░реНрд╡рд╛рдг and рд╡рд┐рдХрд╕рди, although different, correspond to each other in virtue of resemblance between the с╣нwo sentences.

Thus, this figure is not рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╡рд╕реНрддреВрдкрдорд╛ where the common properties are identical.

Nor is this рдирд┐рджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╛ also: (1) for, there the common properties are not stated. (2) Again, there the sentences are dependent upon each other for their meanings; here they are independent. (3) Again, there resemblance is supposed in virtue of impossibility of connection between the two sentences, whilst, here it is supposed in virtue of the correspondence of properties mentioned in the two sentences.

  • This is* рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдиреНрдд under Similarity.

рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдиреНрдд under Contrast, however, is instanced in рддрд╡рд╛рд╣рд╡реЗ etc. verse 65. Here, by reversing this contrast between the two sentences, we get resemblance between them thus:тАФ тАШwarriors fled from the battle-field, when you simply wished to take hold of your sword, as particles of dust fly about when there is a whirlwind.тАЩ

15 ILLUMINATOR (рджреАрдкрдХ).

K─АRIK─А XVII

K─Б. xvii:тАФ (I) When the matter in hand and that which is not the matter in hand have got an attribute mentioned only once, or, (II) when a case-noun (occurs only once) in connection with more than one verb, it is (termed) the Illuminator.

When the property such as an тАШactionтАЩ ctc., of the matter in hand and of what is not the matter in hand, i.e. (of course) of (the things becoming) the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп and the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди*, is employed only*

once, that is one kind of рджреАрдкрдХ; (so called) because it (literally) is ‘that which residing in one (sentence) connects itself with all the other sentences (of the verse),’ just as a lamp standing in the house illumines the street also. The force of the word **рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рддреН15**in the Vс╣Ыtti is that the property which resides in both the matter in hand and what is not the matter in hand, itself, becomes the common property between them. Thus, in virtue of that common property, they necessarily become the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп and the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди.

Here, the comparison is suggested, such words as рдЗрд╡ etc. expressing comparison being absent. Thus this is not рдЙрдкрдорд╛. The suggested comparison is again here subordinate to the expressed sense of the verse. Thus this is not Suggestive Poetry. This is again neither рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╡рд╕реНрддреВрдкрдорд╛ nor рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдиреНрдд; for, the common property, although one, is mentioned here only
once, and besides, the sentences are not here two.

The first variety is instanced in рдХреГрдкрдгрд╛рдирд╛рдВ etc. verse 66. Here, the common property ‘cannot be touched’ is an ‘action’ and is mentioned only once. ‘The breasts of noble women’ are the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдпрд╜ and ’the wealth of misers etc. are the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рдирд╜.

In рд╢реНрдпрд╛рдорд▓рд╛ рдкреНрд░рд╛рд╡реГрд╖реЗрдгреНрдпрд╛рдВ etc., the common property ‘darkness’ is a quality.

When a case-noun occurs (only) once in connection with a plurality of verbs that is (the second kind of) рджреАрдкрдХ; as instanced in рд╕реНрд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрддрд┐etc. verse 67. Here, **рд╡рдзреВрдГтАФ**a noun in the nominative case and **рд╢рдпрдиреЗтАФ**a noun in the locative case are mentioned only once in connection with many verbs рд╕реНрд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрддрд┐, рдХреВрдгрддрд┐ etc.

No resemblance is apprehended in this kind which is thus distinct from the first where there is an apprehension of resemblance.

This very fact distinguishes this kind from рддреБрд▓реНрдпрдпреЛрдЧрд┐рддрд╛where also there is an apprehension of resemblance.

Again, the condition required for the first kind, namely that in it, certain things must beрдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд and certain othersрдЕрдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд is here absent. All the actions here may be (1) рдкреНрд░рдХреГрддor (2) рдЕрдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд or (3) some рдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд and others рдЕрдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд. Thus, this kind has three varieties. The first is instanced in рд╕реНрд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрддрд┐etc. Here, all the actions are рдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд. The second may be instanced in рджреВрд░реАрдХрд░реЛрддрд┐16etc. Here, all the actions are рдЕрдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд, And the third may be instanced in рд╡рд╕реБ рджрд╛рддреБрдВ17etc., рдЕрддреНрд░рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐рд╣реАрдирд╕реНрдп рдХрд╕реНрдпрдЪрд┐рджреНрджреАрдирд╕реНрдп рд╡рдЪрдиреЗ рд╡рд╕реБрджрд╛рдирд╕реНрд╡рддреНрд░рд╛рдгрд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрдпреЛрдГ рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрдпреЛрдГ рдкреНрд░рдХреГрддрдпреЛрдГ, рдЕрд░рд┐рдорд░реНрджрдирд╕реНрдп рдЪрд╛рдкреНрд░рдХреГрддрд╕реНрдп рд╕рд╛рдзрд╛рд░рдгрдВрдХрд░реНрддреГрдХрд╛рд░рдХрдореНред

K─АRIK─АXVIII

K─Б. xviii. a b:- When each preceding object successively helps the succeeding one, it is (termed) the Serial Illuminator.

** **The Vс╣Ыtti here is simple.

This variety is instanced in рд╕рдВрдЧреНрд░рд╛рдорд╛рдЩреНрдЧрдгetc. verse 68. Here, the ‘bow’ obliges the ‘arrows’ by enabling them to ‘reach the heads of the enemy’; the ‘arrows’ also oblige the enemy’s ‘heads’ by assisting them to reach the ‘ground’ etc.

One and the same action of рдЖрд╕рд╛рджрдиbeing everywhere connected, it is called the Illuminator.

This example is criticised by Jagann─Бtha who considers it to be a variety of рдПрдХрд╛рд╡рд▓реА, because in this verse the two important factors which go to make up theрджреАрдкрдХрд╛рд▓рдВрдХрд╛рд░, viz., рд╕рд╛рджреГрд╢реНрдп and рдкреНрд░рдХреГрддрд╛рдкреНрд░рдХреГрддрд╛рддреНрдордХрддреНрд╡ are absent.

рдорд╛рд▓реЛрдкрдорд╛ etc. are not separately defined, because they possess no other peculiarity than this, that one and the same рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп is connected with many рдЙрдкрдорд╛рдирд╜.

рдорд╛рд▓рджреАрдкрдХis, however, separalely defined, because of the additional peculiarity found in this figure, i. e. that there many things, helping each other, and the virtue of this mutual connection, forming a series, are described as connected with one attribute only.

16. EQUAL PAIRING

(рддреБрд▓реНрдпрдпреЛрдЧрд┐рддрд╛)

K─Б. xviii. c d:тАФWhen the (common) property of either only the matters in hand, or only what are not the matters in hand, is (mentioned) only once, it is (termed) Equal Pairing.

The Vс╣Ыtti here is simple.

The common property is either an ‘action’ or a ‘quality’. In рджреАрдкрдХ, the common property of both the matter in hand and what is not the matter in hand is expressed only once; here, of either the one or the other, not of both. Similarity is here implied as in рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХ. It is, however, distinguished from рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХby the fact that there strikingness lies in the superiority of the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп over the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди, and not in the apprehension of resemblance as here. The wordрд╕рдХреГрддреН shows that the figure does not occur in the verses рдореБрдЦрдВ18рд╡рд┐рдХрд╕рд┐рдд etc. and in **рджрдзрд┐ рдордзреБрд░рдВ19**etc.; for, in the first of these, different properties are expressed as connected with different objects, and in the second, one property is expressed many times.

The first variety is instanced in рдкрд╛рдгреНрдбреБ рдХреНрд╖рд╛рдордВ etc. verse 69. Here the property тАЩannouncement’, is mentioned as the property of the ‘face etc. (of a woman under separation)’ which are here the matters in hand, and not as that of the ‘disease’ which is the matter not in hand here.

The second variety is instanced inрдХреБрдореБрджрдХрдорд▓etc. verse 70. Here, in the first half, the property тАЩcontemptтАЩ suggested by the wordрдХрд╛ is mentioned as that of the ’lotus etc.’ only, which are not the matters in hand, they being the things to which the eyes of the women are compared. In the same way in the second half, only one property ‘conquest’ is mentioned as connected with ’nectar etc.’ only, which are not the matters in hand, the face being compared to them. рдХреБрдореБрдж,рдХрдорд▓ etc., and рдЕрдореГрдд, рдЪрдиреНрджреНрд░, etc. are apprehended as similar to each other, through the properties of ‘being contemned’ and ‘being conquered’ respectively.

This is not an Implied Comparison; for, strikingness here does not lie in the apprehension of resemblance only, but in the connection of many things with one property also.

Jagannath observes thatрджреАрдкрдХdoes not deserve to be afigure distinct fromрддреБрд▓реНрдпрдпреЛрдЧрд┐рддрд╛.For, the strikingness due to with many things is the same in both. It is true that a distinction exists between the two figures, i. e. that inрджреАрдкрдХ the things are bothрдкреНрд░рдХреГрддand рдЕрдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд whilst in рддреБрд▓реНрдпрдпреЛрдЧрд┐рддрд╛ they are either рдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд or рдЕрдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд. Still, this distinction, being a minor one, is not sufficient to makeрджреАрдкрдХ and рддреБрд▓реНрдпрдпреЛрдЧрд┐рддрд╛two distinct figures. For, if such a distinction be allowed to be sufficient for justifying the distinction of one figure from another, the two divisions ofрддреБрд▓реНрдпрдпреЛрдЧрд┐рддрд╛a would also have to be made two distinct figures; for, in these divisions also there is a distinction, *i. e.*that in one, the things are purely рдЕрдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд. We should, therefore, admit one figure only, *i. e.*рддреБрд▓реНрдпрдпреЛрдЧрд┐рддрд╛, defining it as

тАЩconnection of one attribute with many things’ and dividing it into the three kinds, viz. (1) when the things areрдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд, (2) when they areрдЕрдкреНрд░рдХреГand (3) when they are both рдкреНрд░рдХреГрддand рдЕрдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд.

Again, a separate definition of рдХрд╛рд░рдХрджреАрдкрдХis unnecessary. For, the definition given in the first line of the K─Бrik─Б applies to both the divisions ofрджреАрдкрдХ.AрдХрд╛рд░рдХ may also be looked upon as a рдзрд░реНрдо. Thus, рд╕рдХреГрджреНрд╡рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐рд░реНрдзрд░реНрдорд╕реНрдп, which is the definition of the first рджреАрдкрдХ, is applicable to рдХрд╛рд░рдХрджреАрдкрдХ also.

Again, the verse рд╕реНрд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрддрд┐, рдХреГрдгреЛрддрд┐etc. is not a good example of рдХрд╛рд░рдХрджреАрдкрдХ. For, the essence of рджреАрдкрдХ and рддреБрд▓реНрдпрдпреЛрдЧрд┐рддрд╛ is a suggested resemblance, Here, the various actionsрд╕реНрд╡реЗрджрди, рдХреГрдгрдиetc.. although connected with one рдХрд╛рд░рдХ, are not yet intended to possess resemblance. Even though it be persisted that there is a resemblance among the various actions mentioned in the verse, still, inasmuch as well these actions are purely рдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд, the verse deserves to be an example of рдХрд╛рд░рдХрддреБрд▓реНрдпрдпреЛрдЧрд┐рддрд╛, where all the things are allowed to be either рдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд or рдЕрдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд. It is true that Mammata does not admit рдХрд╛рд░рдХрддреБрд▓реНрдпрдпреЛрдЧрд┐рддрд╛ as a division of рддреБрд▓реНрдпрдпреЛрдЧрд┐рддрд╛ But, there is no reason why the principle on which рджреАрдкрдХ is distinguished from рддреБрд▓реНрдпрдпреЛрдЧрд┐рддрд╛should not be accepted in admittting рдХрд╛рд░рдХрддреБрд▓реНрдпрдпреЛрдЧрд┐рддрд╛, as distinct from рдХрд╛рд░рдХрджреАрдкрдХ. But, inasmuch as we have now made рджреАрдкрдХand рддреБрд▓реНрдпрдпреЛрдЧрд┐рддрд╛, one рдХрд╛рд░рдХрджреАрдкрдХ should be made a sub-division of рддреБрд▓реНрдпрдпреЛрдЧрд┐рддрд╛. Thus, рддреБрд▓реНрдпрдпреЛрдЧрд┐рддрд╛ should be divided into two kinds :тАФ(1) where theрдзрд░реНрдо is a рдХрд╛рд░рдХand (2) where theрдзрд░реНрдоis other than a рдХрд╛рд░рдХ. Each of these two kinds should again be. sub-divided into the above mentioned three kinds, i. e(a) where the things are рдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд(b) where they are рдЕрдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд(c) where they are both рдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд and рдЕрдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд.

If it be held that no resemblance is required for division (1), then Mamma╚Ыa’s example рд╕реНрд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрддрд┐ рдХреГрдгрддрд┐etc. would do. If it, however, be held that resemblance is necessary

for it, then the verse**рд╡рд╕реБ рджрд╛рддреБрдВ20**etc. looked upon as containing the eulogy of a king should be regarded as an example of it.

17. EXCELLENCE (рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХ)
K─АRIK─АXIX

K─Б. xix. ab:- The superiority over the thing compared to, of what is different from it, alone21 is Excellence.

‘Of what is different from it,’ (means) ‘of the thing compared. The termрд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХetymologically (means) ‘superiority due to the possession of superior attributes prominently brought out.’

The word рдЙрдкрдорд╛рдирд╛рддреН shows that рдХреБрдореБрджрд╛рджрддрд┐рд░рд┐рдЪреНрдпрддреЗ is no example of this figure; for,рдХреБрдореБрджis not known to be an object to which the face is compared, but is an object to which the eyes are compared. Thus,рдХреБрдореБрдж is not an рдЙрдкрдорд╛рдиhere. The wordрд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдг22shows that рдореБрдЦрдорд┐рд╡ рдЪрдВрджреНрд░рдГ also, is no example; for although there the excellence of the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдпconsisting in the fact that it is made the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди is suggested, still, there is no word there which brings out that excellence prominently. Such a word is however, present in рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХ. As for what is said by some one (i. e. Rudra╚Ыa, VII-89-90; Ruyyaka, p. 78 T. S. S. edn.):тАФ"рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХ should be defined as the ‘superiority of the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди over the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп or of the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп over the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди.’ How otherwise, can рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХbe instanced in рдХреНрд╖реАрдгetc.; where is described the superiority of the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рдитАФтАЩthe moon’ consisting in the fact that she waxes again even though she has

waned, over theрдЙрдкрдореЗрдптАФтАЩyouth’тАФwhich when once gone does not come back again?" it is not right for, the things that are contrasted here are not the ‘moon’ and ‘youth,’ but their ‘declines.’ The ‘decline’ of the moon is inferior inasmuch as it is again superseded by ‘increase.’ The ‘decline’ of youth is however, superior inasmuch as it is not again superseded by ‘growth.’ Thus, here the superiority of the instability of ‘youth’ (over that of the ‘moon’) is what is intended (by the poet). Hence, Rudrata’s statement that рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХoccurs (even) when the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рдиis superior to the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп is meaningless.

Ruyyak and, Kuvalay─Бnanda however, say that the verseрд░рдХреНрддрд╕реНрддреНрд╡рдВetc. is an example of that kind of Excellence where the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп falls short of the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди. But they are not right. For, the Excellence intended in the verse is that of the king whose grief indicates that he has ‘sentiency’ and ‘feeling’тАФ attributes not possessed by the A┼Ыoka tree. ‘Excellence’ here means possession of an attribute favourable to the sense of the sentence that is the matter in hand.’ The ‘state of separation from his beloved’ is the matter in hand.’ To this the ‘sentiency which renders ‘grief under separation’ possible is favourable. Thus, Excellence must be recognized as a distinct figure; the strikingness is positive, not merely negative as held by the author of the Dhvani who says that what is striking here is the absence of the figure Comparison. See рд░рд╕рдЧрдВрдЧрд╛рдзрд░it, pp. 353-355 where this point is examined in detail.

So also in the verseрд╣рдиреВрдорджрд╛рджреНрдпреИрд░реНрдпрд╢рд╕рд╛etc., dejection of Nala through self-disagreement is the matter in hand, which is contributed to, by ’the inferiority of the office of a messenger.’

He now states all the divisions of the figure:тАФ

K─Б. xix. ab & xx cd:тАФIn the mention of the (two) grounds in the three cases of the non-mention (of these);

when (the idea of) resemblance is conveyed by a word or by (its) sense or when it is suggested; so many when the word is paronomastic. Thus, three times eight.

The grounds of Excellence are (two):тАФThe ground of superiority residing in theрдЙрдкрдореЗрдпрдоand the ground of inferiority residing in the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди. When both of these are mentioned, there is one variety and when any one of these (i. e. either the first or the second) or even both are not mentioned, there are three varieties of Non-mention. These four varieties (occur) when the relation of the thing compared and the thing compared to is (directly) conveyed by such words asрдЗрд╡etc*.*, in virtue of the power possessed by these words. Only four varieties mentioned above (occur when that relation is conveyed) in an indirect mode, i. e. by such words as рддреБрд▓реНрдпetc. in virtue of the power possessed by the senses of these words, and so many (i. e, four) only, (occur) when resemblance is suggested. Thus, we get twelve (varieties). (All) these varieties (occur) in (the presence of) a paronomasia also, as in the,absence of a paronomasia. Thus, we get twenty-four varieties.

Examples in order :тАФ

The first variety is instanced in рдЕрд╕рд┐рдорд╛рддреНрд░etc. verse 72. Here, both the grounds, of рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХ, i. e. тАЩgreat fortitudeтАЩ belonging to the king-the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп-and ‘worthlessness’ belonging to an ordinary man the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди-are mentioned. The ‘absence of pride in the king’ constitutes the point of his superiority over an ordinary man.

  • In this very example again, by leaving out the wordsрддреБрдЪреНрдЫand рдорд╣рд╛рдзреГрддрд┐, either successively or simultaneously, and by reading the second line as рдиреВрдирдордиреНрдп рдЬрдирд╕реНрдпреЗрд╡ рди рд╕реНрдордпреЛрд╜рд╕реНрдп рдорд╣рд╛рд╢реНрд░реБрддреЗрдГ, рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреБрдЪреНрдЫрдЬрдирд╕реНрдпреЗрд╡ рди рд╕реНрдордпреЛрд╜рд╕реНрдп рдорд╣реАрдкрддреЗрдГ, and рдиреВрдирдордиреНрдпрдЬрдирд╕реНрдпреЗрд╡ рди рд╕реНрдордпреЛрд╜рд╕реНрдп рдорд╣реАрдкрддреЗрдГ, respectively, the next three varieties (are obtained). The same, i. e. three varieties should*

be understood in the other (varieties also of this figure.) Here the word

рдЗрд╡

being present, resemblance is expressed.

The fifth variety is instanced in рдЕрд╕рд┐рдорд╛рддреНрд░╨╡tc. verse 73. Here owing to (the employment of the affix) рд╡рддреНin the sense of resemblance is implied. The grounds of superiority and inferiority are both mentioned. The next three varieties can be obtained in this example also, as in the former, by reading the second line as рдиреВрдирдВ рдиреИрд╡рд╛рдиреНрдпрдЬрдирд╡рддреН рд╕рдЧрд░реНрд╡реЛрд╜рдпрдВ рдорд╣рд╛рдзреГрддрд┐рдГ, рдиреИрд╡рд╛рдиреНрдпрддреБрдЪреНрдЫрдЬрдирд╡рддреН рд╕рдЧрд░реНрд╡реЛрд╜рдпрдВ рдорд╣реАрдкрддрд┐рдГ, and рдиреВрдирдВ рдиреИрд╡рд╛рдиреНрдпрдЬрдирд╡рддреН рд╕рдЧрд░реНрд╡реЛрд╜рдпрдВ рдорд╣реАрдкрддрд┐рдГ, respectively.

The ninth variety is instanced in рдЗрдпрдВ рд╕реБрдирдпрдирд╛etc. verse 74. Here, in the absence of the wordsрдЗрд╡ etc. and рддреБрд▓реНрдпetc., resemblance is but suggested by the expression ’triumph over the stained moon.’ The grounds of superiority and inferiority, i. e. ‘Spottlessness’ and ‘Spottedness’ are both mentioned.

The next three varities can be obtained in this example also, by reading the second line as рдЖрдирдиреЗрди рдордиреЛрдЬреНрдЮреЗрди рдЬрдпрддреАрдиреНрджреБрдВ рдХрд▓рдВрдХрд┐рдирдореН, рдЖрдирдиреЗрдирд╛рдлрд▓рдВрдХреЗрди рдЬрдпрддреНрдпрдореГрддреАрдзрд┐рддрд┐рдореН, рдЖрдирдиреЗрди рдордиреЛрдЬреНрдЮреЗрди рдЬрдпрддреНрдпрдореГрддрджреАрдзрд┐рддрд┐рдореН, respectively.

If it be said that the eight divisions ofрдЖрдХреНрд╖рд┐реБрдкреНрдд рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХ(both paronomastic and un-paronomastic) are possible in a рд╡реНрдпрдВрдЧреЛрдкрдорд╛ also; for the words рдЬрдпрддрд┐, рд╣рд╕рддрд┐, рд╡рд┐рдбрдореНрдмрдпрддрд┐, рдирд┐рдиреНрджрддрд┐, etc. which suggest рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХalso suggest Comparison; we reply:тАФNo, for, although these words suggest Comparison, yet in as much as they are quite necessary to bring out superiority, the examples in which these words occur should be withdrawn from the province of рд╡реНрдпрдВрдЧреНрдпреЛрдкрдорд╛, and should be considered as those of рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХ only.

In all these 12 varieties Paronomasia is absent.

The 13th variety occurring in a Paronomasia is instanced in рдЬрд┐рддреЗрдиреНрджреНрд░рд┐рдпрддрдпрд╛etc. verse 75. Here, resemblance is expressed (owing to the employment of) the affix рд╡рддреНin the sense of **рдЗрд╡.**The grounds of superiority and inferiority, i. e. ’extreme

closeness of connection’ and ‘fragility’ are both mentioned, and the word рдЧреБрдгmeaning a ‘quality’ and a ‘fibre’ is paronomastic.

  • *The other three varieties can be obtained in this example also, by reading the second line asрд╕рддреНрдХрд░реНрдордирд┐рд░рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рд╕реНрдп рдирд╛рдмреНрдЬрд╡рджреНрднрдВрдЧреБрд░рд╛ рдЧреБрдгрд╛рдГ, рдЕрддрд┐рдЧрд╛рдврдЧреБрдгрд╕реНрдпрд╛рд╕реНрдп рди рддрд╛рдорд░рд╕рд╡рджреНрдЧреБрдгрд╛рдГ, рд╕рддреНрдХрд░реНрдордирд┐рд░рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛рд╕реНрдп рди рддрд╛рдорд░рд╕рд╡рджреНрдЧреБрдгрд╛рдГ, respectively.

The 17th variety is instanced in рдЕрдЦрдгреНрдбрдордгреНрдбрд▓etc. verse 76. Here, resemblance is implied owing to the employment of рд╡рддреН in the sense of рддреБрд▓реНрдп*. The word* рдХрд▓*, is paronomastic*meaning either an ‘art’ or ‘phase’. The grounds of superiority and inferiority, i. e. ‘disppearance ofрдХрд▓рд╛ (phases) and ’non-disappearance of рдХрд▓рд╛(arts)тАЩ are both mentioned.

The next three varieties can be obtained in this example also, by reading the verse as

рдмрд╣реБрд▓рд╛рд░рд┐рдЧрддреЛрд╜рдкреНрдпреЗрд╖ рд╢реНрд░реАрдорд╛рдиреБрджреНрдзрддрд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░рдордГред
рди рдирд┐рд╢рд╛рдХрд░рд╡рдЬреНрдЬрд╛рддреБ рдХрд▓рд╛рд╡реИрдХрд▓реНрдпрдорд╛рдЧрддрдГрее

рдЕрдЦрдгреНрдбрдордгреНрдбрд▓рдГрд╢реНрд░реАрдорд╛рдиреН рдкрд╢реНрдпреИрд╖ рдкреГрдерд┐рд╡реАрдкрддрд┐рдГред
рди рдирд┐рд╢рд╛рдХрд░рд╡рдЬреНрдЬрд╛рддреБ рджреГрд╢реНрдпрддрд╛рдВ рд╡рд╕реБрдзрд╛рдзрд┐рдкрдГрее

and

рдмрд╣реБрд▓рд╛рд░рд┐рдЧрддреЛрд╜рдкреНрдпреЗрд╖ рд╢реНрд░реАрдорд╛рдиреБрджреНрдзрддрд╡рд┐рдХреНрд░рдордГред
рди рдирд┐рд╢рд╛рдХрд░рд╡рдЬреНрдЬрд╛рддреБ рджреГрд╢реНрдпрддрд╛рдВ рд╡рд╕реБрдзрд╛рдзрд┐рдкрдГрее

respectively. In the first the word рдХрд▓рд╛is paronomastic, in the second, рдЕрдЦрдгреНрдбрдордгреНрдбрд▓, and in the third, рдмрд╣реБрд▓ ( meaning either рдХреГрд╖реНрдгрдкрдХреНрд╖ or рд╡рд┐рдкреБрд▓.

Pradipa, however, says that the third variety (where the grounds of superiority and inferiority are omitted simultaneously) is impossible here, because рдХрд▓рд╛рд╡реИрдХрд▓реНрдп and рдХрд▓рд╛рд╡реИрдХрд▓реНрдпрд╛рднрд╛рд╡being the grounds of superiority and inferiority here if these are not mentioned, Paronomasia will be without a resting place; whilst, the varieties based on a paronomasia occur only when a word (such as рдХрд▓рд╛рд╡реИрдХрд▓реНрдп) expressive of a property which becomes the ground of superiority or inferiority (such as рдЧреБрдг in рдЬрд┐рддреЗрдиреНрджреНрд░рд┐рдпрддрдпрд╛ etc..), or a word expressive of a thing

possessed of such a property is paronomastic. Thus, according to him,рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХ has only 23 varieties.

Serial рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХ is also possible like Serial рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╡рд╕реНрддреВрдкрдорд╛*. Its varieties also should be understood similarly (i. e. in the above mentioned manner). One only we may exemplify in a рджреГрд░рд╡рдиреНрдиetc. verse 77, in order to show the way in which others may occur.*

  • Here,рд╡рддреН is (used) in the sense of рддреБрд▓реНрдп. Thus,* resemblance is рдЖрд░реНрде*. The words* рд╡рд┐рд╖рдо etc. are paronomastic. рд╣рд░, рд╣рд░рд┐, рд░рд╡рд┐ etc. are the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рдирд╜. Here, рд╡рд┐рд╖рдорджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд┐рддреНрд╡ the ground of inferiority is mentioned;рд╕рдорджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд┐рддреНрд╡the ground of superiority is not mentioned.

The 21st variety is instanced inрдирд┐рддреНрдпреЛрджрд┐рддetc,verse 78.Here,in the absenceof such words as рдЗрд╡ etc. and рддреБрд▓реНрдп etc. resemblance is but implied. The wordрднрд╛рд╕реНрд╡рддреН is paronomastic;** so also рдкреНрд░рддрд╛рдк. The grounds of superiority, and inferiority i. e. ‘рдирд┐рддреНрдпреЛрджрд┐рддрддреНрд╡’ and ‘рд░рд╛рддреНрд░реМ рдЧрддрдкреНрд░рднрддреНрд╡’ respectively, are both mentioned in the first half of the verse.

The next three varieties can be obtained in this example also by reading the first line as рд╕рдорд░рд╛рд╕рдХреНрддрдордирд╕рд╛ рддреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рдорд╛рдореАрд▓рд┐рддрдкреНрд░рднрдГ, рдирд┐рддреНрдпреЛрджрд┐рддрдкреНрд░рддрд╛рдкреЗрди рдкрдВрдХрдЬрд╛рд╡рд▓рд┐рдирдиреНрджрдирдГ, and рд╕рдорд░рд╛рд╕рдХреНрддрдордирд╕рд╛ рдкрдВрдХрдЬрд╛рд╡рд╛рд▓рдирдиреНрджрдирдГ, respectively. Upon this Udyota, however, remarks that in the paronomastic divisions of рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХ, the word expressing the contrasting property itself should be paronomastic and not any word in the verse, as Mamma╚Ыa appers to think. Thus, in this way the three varieties in which both the grounds are simultaneously omitted are impossible, The three varieties are: Expressed, Implied, and suggested. Thus, according to him, рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХ has 21 varieties only. Prabh─Б23wrongly says

that this very opinion is expressed by Prad─лpa in рдЕрддреНрд░рд╛рдиреБрдкрд╛рджрд╛рдирддреНрд░рдпрдВ рдЪрд┐рдиреНрддреНрдпрдореН.

This variety is also possible where, even in the absence of such words as рдирд┐рд░реНрдЬрд┐рдд, рдЬрдпрддрд┐ etc., the resemblance is suggested by paronomastic adjectives; as in рд╕реНрд╡рдЪреНрдЫрд╛рддреНрдорддрд╛ etc. verse 79. Here, even though such words as рдЗрд╡ etc. and рддреБрд▓реНрдп etc. (and рдЬрдпрддрд┐ etc. also) are absent, still resemblance is apprehended as suggested in virtue of Paronomastic adjectives such asрд╣реГрджреНрдпрдЧрдВрдзetc.

Thus *other varieties also similar to these are possible, when two separate words capable of being substituted by one paronomastic word are employed, one as an adjective^(1)24*to the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп, and the other as an adjective to the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди. They, too, should be understood in this very manner. Thus, for instance in рдЕрдореГрддрдордореГрддрдВ etc., тАЩextreme sweetness’ is connected separately with the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп, i. e. тАЩthe lipsтАЩ; and the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рдирд╜, i. e. тАЩnectar, etc.’ by two separate words рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рджреБ and рдЕрдореГрдд etc.; so also in рдпрд╛ рд╢реИрд╢рд┐рд░реА рд╢реНрд░реАрдГ25, the word рддрдкрд╕реН capable of yielding the two senses of рдорд╛рдШрдорд╛рд╕ and рдХреГрдЪреНрдЫреНрд░рд╛рджрд┐ is substituted by two words рддрдкрд╕реН (meaning рдорд╛рдШрдорд╛рд╕) and рддрдкрд╕ (meaning рдХреГрдЪреНрдЫреНрд░рд╛рджрд┐), In all these examples,the form of excellence-’this is superior to that’- is implied. It is however expressed in рдЗрдВрджреЛрдГ рдкрджреНрдорд╛рдЪреНрдЪрд╛рдзрд┐рдХрдВ рдореЗ рдкреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рдпрд╛ рд╡рджрдирдВ рдорддрдореНред рд╡реЗрд▓рд╛рд╕реИрд░реНрд╣реГрджреНрдпрдЧрдВрдзреИрд╢реНрдЪ, etc.

18. PARALEPSIS (рдЖрдХреНрд╖реЗрдк).

K─Б. xx. c d, & xxi. a b:- The denial of what is (really) intended to be said, with a view to intimate something in particular, is considered Paralepsis; (and is) twofold: as pertaining to (1) what is about to be said and to (2) what has been said.

*** *The denial, i. e. the pretended denial of what is intended to be said, i. e. of what, being the matter in hand, cannot be left unsaid, for the purpose of intimating something in particular, which is (in the case of what is about to be said (impossibility of speaking (further), or (in the case of what has been said) ‘well-knownness,’ is (termed) Paralepsis; (and it is) of two kinds: (1) pertaining to what is about to be said and (2) pertaining to what has been said. The denial being merely verbal implies that the thing which is pretended to be denied is really intended to be affirmed.

Some say that the figure occurs even when something intended to be done is foregone; as instanced inрддрд╛рдВ рд╕реБрдиреНрджрд░реАрдВрд╡рд░реНрдгрдпрд┐рддреБрдВ рди рдореЗ рд╡рд╛рдгреА рдкреНрд░рд╡рд░реНрддрддреЗ. Here, the foregoing of the act of description displays the indescribableness of the object under description.

Examples in order:тАФ

The first variety is instanced inрдП рдПрд╣рд┐ etc. verse 80. Here, the fact of тАЩthe excessive misery of the heroine brought on by separation,’-which is really intended to be conveyed by the speaker who is the friend of the heroine-is suppressed by her, in order to suggest that she is unable to describe it in detail. The fact of ’excessive misery’ which is suppressed, is not told but is to be told, and therefore, the figure is рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрдорд╛рдгрд╡рд┐рд╖рдп.

The second variety is instanced in рдЬреНрдпреЛрддреНрд╕реНрдирд╛etc. verse 81. Here, the fact that ‘moonlight and other such cool substances torment the heroine under separation’тАФwhich is really intended to be conveyedтАФis denied in order to sug-

gest that the fact is well known. The fact of ’tormentтАЩ being already told, the figure is рдЙрдХреНрддрд╡рд┐рд╖рдп.

19. PECULIAR CAUSATION (рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рд╡рдирд╛).

K─Б. xxi, c d:- The manifestation of an effect, even though a cause is denied, is termed Peculiar Causation.

According to the grammarians, an action alone is a cause. Hence the word рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛in the K─Бrik─Б is used in its etymological sense of ’that by whieh anything is effected," i. e. a ‘cause.’ Thus, рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рд╡рдирд╛*(occurs) when, even in the absence of an action which is a cause there is the manifestation of its effect.* But26such a thing as рдЖрддреНрдорд╛etc. also may be a cause. Therefore, really speaking, рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рд╡рдирд╛should be defined as that where, although a cause (that is well-known) is absent, the effect is said to be present. The production of an effect without a cause is not inconsistent, for the denial of a well-known cause supposes that the effect is produced in virtue of its peculiar nature or by some other cause (which is hidden).

In **рди рдХрдареЛрд░рдореН┬▓27**etc., there is рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рд╡рдирд╛ inasmuch as the effect, i. e. ‘conquest,’ has been represented as produced in the absence of its cause i. e. ‘sharp weapons.’ рдЕрддрд┐рд╢рдпреЛрдХреНрддрд┐is subordinate there, not principal. This figure is not рд╡рд┐рд░реЛрдз, although there is apparent contradiction in the production of an effect without a cause, and its removal by the supposition of the presence of another obscure cause. For, in рд╡рд┐рд░реЛрдз, two equally powerful things are apprehended as opposing each other; whilst here, only the effect is apprehended as opposed

is an example of ‘рдЧреБрдгрд╡реИрдХрд▓реНрдпрд╡рддреА рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реЛрдХреНрддрд┐ according to рджрдгреНрдбрд┐рдиреН(рдХрд╛рд╡реНрдпрд╛рджрд░реНрд╢II,324.) and рднреЛрдЬ (рд╕рд░рд╕реНрд╡рддреАрдХрдгреНрдард╛рднрд░рдг, p.431. рдирд┐рд░реНрдгрдп .edn. )

by the absence of the cause, but the absence of the cause is not apprehended as opposed by the effect28. For, here the effect’ is fancied and the absence of the cause is real. Now what is fancied is opposed by the real, but the real cannot be opposed by what is fancied.

The figure is instanced in рдХреБрд╕реБрдорд┐рддetc. verse 82. Here, in the absence of the causes, ‘beating by the creepers etc.,’ the effects, ‘pain etc.’ are produced owing to the state of separation of the Heroine. Here, although the pain produced from the obscure cause, i. e. ‘separation,’ is different from that produced from the beating by the creepers,’ yet it is identified with it. This identification is at the bottom of this figure. It is of the nature of an рдЕрддрд┐рд╢рдпреЛрдХреНрддрд┐in the present verse; in the verse **рдирд┐рд░реБрдкрд╛рджрд╛рди рд╕рдВрднрд╛рд░рдорднрд┐рддреНрддрд╛рд╡реЗрди рддрдиреНрд╡рддреЗред рдЬрдЧрдЪреНрдЪрд┐рддреНрд░рдВ рдирдорд╕реНрддрд╕реНрдореИ рдХрд▓рд╛рд╢реНрд▓рд╛рдШреНрдпрд╛рдп рд╢реВрд▓рд┐рдиреЗрее**it is of the nature of a рд░реВрдкрдХ.

In рдЕрдкреНрдпрд▓рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд╛рд░рд╕рд╛ рд╕рд┐рдХреНрддрдВ рд░рдХреНрддрдВ рддрдЪреНрдЪрд░рдгрджреНрд╡рдпрдореН the apparent contradiction involved in ‘red feet without lac’ is due to the redness of the feet being natural. By ’the absence of the cause’ is to be understood the presence of a counteracting agent also. Thus, the figure occurs in рд╕рд╛рддрдкрддреНрд░рдВ рджрд╣рддреНрдпрд╛рд╢реБ рдкреНрд░рддрд╛рдкрджрд╣рдирд╕реНрддрд╡also, inasmuch as the effect ‘burning’ is there produced even in the presence of an ‘umbrella’ the counteracting agency.

The term рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рд╡рдирд╛etymologically means ’that which supposes another cause (of course, obscure).’ Thus, those men are wrong who say that the production of a cause from an effect is also рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рд╡рдирд╛.

The figure is of two kinds:тАФ(1) where the obscure cause is not mentioned and (2) where it is mentioned. The first kind is instanced in рдХреБрд╕реБрдорд┐рдд etc.

The second kind may be instanced in рдпрджрд╡рдзрд┐29etc. Here, ‘youth’ the obscure cause of ’tormenting’ is mentioned.

20. PECULIAR ALLEGATION (рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реЛрдХреНрддрд┐рдГ)

K─АRIK─АXXII

K─Б. xxii, a b:тАФThe non-mention of the effect in the presence of entire causes is (termed) Peculiar Allegation.

рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реЛрдХреНрддрд┐*(occurs) when even though all the (well-known) causes are (said to be) present, the effect is said to be absent.*

The plural of рдХрд╛рд░рдгреЗрд╖реБhas no particular significance here. The representation of the absence of the effect in the presence of its cause implies that the absence of the effect is due to some cause that is hidden. Thus, there is no inconsistency.

The termрд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реЛрдХреНрддрд┐literally means ‘mention to intimate some thing in particular.’

The absence of the effect is said to be due to some cause; now рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реЛрдХреНрддрд┐is three-fold: according as (this) cause is (a) not mentioned, (b) mentioned and (c) inconceivable,

  • Examples in order :тАФ*

The first variety (a) is instanced inрдирд┐рджреНрд░рд╛ etc. verse 83. Here, ’the removal of drowsiness,’ ’the rising of the Sun,’ and other like causes (that are well-known) are present, and yet their effect, ’the loosening of her clasp’ is represented as absent. This is due to ’the excess of her affection for her lover’. This cause, however, although capable of being clearly mentioned, is not mentioned here. According to Cakravarti30, the cause is ‘inability to move owing to the exhaustion caused by sexual intercourse."

The second variety is mentioned in рдХрд░реНрдкреВрд░ рдЗрд╡etc. verse 84. Here, the cause, тАЩburning of the body’ which is wellknown, is present, and yet the effect, ’the loss of power, is

absent. This is due to Cupid’s irresistible power. This cause is mentioned here.

According to Bh─Бskara, Cupid resembles ‘camphorтАЩ only in the point of ‘being burnt’, and not in the point of ‘being powerful’ also. According to Prad─лpa, he resembles ‘camphor in the point of powerfulness’ itself; ‘for’, says he ‘when camphor is slightly burnt, it produces great fragrance, as described in the verse рднреНрд░реВрднреНрдпрд╛рдореН╨╡tc.’"

The third variety is instanced in рд╕ рдПрдХрдГetc. verse 85

Here, ’the destruction of the body’ is the well-known cause of ’the loss of power.тАЩ That cause is present, and yet the effect is absent. The cause of the absence of this effect cannot be clearly stated, and hence it is inconceivable.

Although here the cause is not mentioned, as in the first variety, yet this variety is distinguished from it by the fact that there the cause which is not mentioned is such that it can be known from the context etc. whilst here it
cannot be so known.

21.RELATIVE ORDER (рдпрдерд╛рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдп)

K─Б. xxii, c d:- An orderly connection of objects successively mentioned is (termed) Relative Order.

When two or more sets of objects, mentioned in order are connected with each other in the same order in which they are mentioned, it is рдпрдерд╛рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдп.

The figure is instanced in рдПрдХрд╕реНрддреНрд░рд┐рдзрд╛etc. verse 86. Here the set of objectsтАФрджреНрд╡рд┐рд╖рдГ рд╡рд┐рджреНрд╡рд╛рдВрд╕рдГ, and **рдореГрдЧреАрджреГрд╢рдГтАФ**is, connected with another set of objects рддрд╛рдк, рд░рд╕, and рд░рддрд┐,тАУand with the third set of objectsтАФрд╢реМрд░реНрдпреЛрд╖реНрдорд╛, рд╡рд┐рдирдп, and рд▓реАрд▓рд╛,тАУin the same order in which these sets are mentioned.

Although this does not deserve to be called a figure, inasmuch as in it the element of poetic imagination that constitutes the very essence of a figure, is completely wanting, yet the respective connection of many objects in one verse constiutes a strikingness, and thus it is recognized as a figure.

22. CORROBORATION (рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдиреНрдпрд╛рд╕)

K─АRIK─АXXIII

K─Б. xxiii:тАФ When a general or a particular is strengthened by its opposite either under a resemblance or its opposite, that is (termed) Corroboration.

** When a general is corroborated by a particular, or a particular by a general, either under a resemblance or a contrast, it is рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдиреНрдпрд╛рд╕.

The termрдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдиреНрдпрд╛рд╕ a literally means ’the adducing of an example to establish either a general or a particular proposition the truth of which appears to be improbable."

This figure is distinguished from рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдиреНрддby the fact that there the strengthening is of the general by the general, and of the particular by the particular; from рдЕрдиреБрдорд╛рди by the fact that the invariable concomitance between theрд╣реЗрддреБand the рд╕рд╛рдзреНрдпis not directly expressed here; and also by the fact that inference is here drawn by the hearer, and not as in рдЕрдиреБрдорд╛рдиby the poet through the mouth of another speaker; and from рдХрд╛рд╡реНрдпрд▓рд┐рдВрдЧby the fact that there the relation of the general and the particular is absent. In**рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╡рд╕реНрддреВрдкрдорд╛,**according to рд╕рд╛рд░рдмреЛрдзрд┐рдиреА31, it is resemblance that is intended; but here corroboration. In рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рд╡рд╕реНрддреВрдкрдорд╛ and рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдиреНрдд, according to рдкреНрд░рднрд╛32,the particular is strengthened by the particular.

Examples in order :тАФ

The first variety where a general is confirmed by a particular under a resemblance is instanced in рдирд┐рдЬрджреЛрд╖рд╛рд╡реГрддetc. verse 87. Here, the general proposition stated in the first

half of the verse is confirmed by the particular illustration of a ‘man afflicted with bile.’

The second variety where the particular is confirmed by the general under a resemblance is instanced in aрд╕реБрд╕рд┐рддetc. verse 88. Here, the particular auspiciousness of the king is justified by his universal auspiciousness.

The third variety where the general is corroborated by the particular under a contrast is instanced inрдЧреБрдгрд╛рдирд╛рдореЗрд╡ etc. verse 89. Here, the generalтАФthat a competent man is appointed to the responsible post etc.тАФis strengthened by the particular illustration of ‘a bad bull.’ The contrast is simple.

The fourth variety where the particular is justified by the general under a contrast is instanced in рдЕрд╣реЛ рд╣рд┐ рдореЗetc. verse 90. Here, the particular misfortune of Yudhiс╣гс╣нhira is strengthened by the good fortune of friends in general. Here, in the presence of the wordsрдпрддреН, рдпрддрдГetc., the corroboration is Expressed, in their absence, it is Implied.

23. ANTITHESIS (рд╡рд┐рд░реЛрдз)

K─АRIK─АXXIV

K─Б. xxiv, a b:тАФThe representation (of two things) as incongruous, although there is no incongruity (between them), is termed Antithesis.

When (two things) are represented as if they are incongruous, even though there is really no incongruity between them, it is рд╡рд┐рд░реЛрдз. In fact, рд╡рд┐рд░реЛрдз occurs when two things known to occupy two different places are represented as occupying one place; or, when two things that are known to occupy one place represented as occupying two different places. Although inconsistency is apprehended as soon the general meaning of the words is understood, still, when we look to the fact that the words have a different purpose, the inconsistency disappears. Hence, this figure is also

styled ‘Semblance of рд╡рд┐рд░реЛрдз’. The contradiction here must be such as can be explained, for, it is such a contradiction that constitutes a figure, contradictions of a different character being considered faulty.

He now divides Antithesis:тАХ

K─АRIK─А XXIV & XXV

K─Б. xxiv c d, xxv a b:тАФA Universal incongruous with (the) four (things) a Universal etc.; a Quality with three (things); an Action with two, and a Substance with a Substance alone; thus, they are ten.

‘A Universal etc.’ means a Universal, a Quality, an Action, and a Substance. With three, i. e. with a Quality, an Action, and a Substance; with two, i. e. with an Action and a Substance. Although incongruity of a Quality with a Universal is possible, still, inasmuch as it is included under the incongruity of a Universal with a Quality, only three varieties of the incongruity of a Quality are mentioned. Thus, the incongruity of a Universal is four-fold; of a Quality three-fold; of an Action two-fold; and of a Substance, single. Thus, in all, there are ten varieties. Rudra╚Ыa,. however, says that as рдЬрд╛рддрд┐always resides on рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдп, there can be no рд╡рд┐рд░реЛрдз between рдЬрд╛рддрд┐ and рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдп. Therefore, there are only 9 varieties of рд╡рд┐рд░реЛрдз. рд╕рдВрдХреЗрдд does not accept this view. For, рдЬрд╛рддрд┐resides on рдЧреБрдгalso. So, if there can be a рд╡рд┐рд░реЛрдзbetweenрдЬрд╛рддрд┐ and рдЧреБрдг, then why should it not exist between рдЬрд╛рддрд┐ and рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдп?

Examples in order :тАФ

  • *The first variety where a Universal is incongruous with a Universal is instanced in рдЕрднрд┐рдирд╡etc. verse 91.Here, the Universals рдирд▓рд┐рдиреАрддреНрд╡, рдХрд┐рд╕рд▓рдпрддреНрд╡ etc. are represented as opposed to the Universal рджрд╡рджрд╣рдирддреНрд╡. This opposition is apparent only, for рдирд▓рд┐рдиреА, рдХрд┐рд╕рд▓рдп etc., inasmuch as they tend to enhance the grief produced by separation, are only meta-

phorically said to beрджрд╡рджрд╣рди.Here, the attribution of identitybetweenрджрд╣рдирддреНрд╡andрдирд▓рд┐рдиреАрддреНрд╡etc. is sub-ordinate. The poet wants to describe the sad condition of a woman under separation; and therefore it is opposition, that is here striking, not identity. In рдореБрдЦрдВ рдЪрдиреНрджреНрд░рдГetc. it is identity that is striking; for, what the poet there intends to convey is that the face is possessed of all the attributes of the moon.

The second variety where a Universal is incongruous with a Quality is instanced inрдЧрд┐рд░рдпреЛрд╜рдкреНрдпetc. verse 92. Here, the UniversalsрдЧрд┐рд░рд┐рддреНрд╡ etc. are represented as incongruous with the QualitiesрдЕрдиреБрдиреНрдирддрддреНрд╡etc. This incongruity is explained by the fact that the poet wants to convey the idea of extreme nobility on the part of the individual under description. рд╡рд┐рд╢реНрд╡рдВрднрд░рд╛рдкреНрдпрддрд┐рд▓рдШреБрдГis not an example of this variety; for,рд╡рд┐рд╢реНрд╡рдВрднрд░рд╛ is not a Universal (the earth being single is but a Substance). From the rule┬╣33 of Pata├▒jali that words denote only four things, vis. рдЬрд╛рддрд┐, рдЧреБрдг, рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛ and рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдп, it follows that aрдЧреБрдгis that which is not a Universal, an Action, or a Substance. Thus, рдЕрднрд╛рд╡ also is a рдЧреБрдг. Hence although рдЕрдиреБрдиреНрдирддрд┐,рдЕрдЪрд▓рддреНрд╡ etc. are рдЕрднрд╛рд╡рд╜, still, this is an example of рдЬрд╛рддрд┐рдЧреБрдгрд╡рд┐рд░реЛрдз. If рдЕрднрд╛рд╡ be taken as separate from рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдп, рдЧреБрдг etc., Mammata’s divisions of рд╡рд┐рд░реЛрдзwould be in complete, inasmuch as he has not mentioned those varieties where the рд╡рд┐рд░реЛрдзis betweenрдЕрднрд╛рд╡ on the one hnad, and рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдп, рдЧреБрдг, рдЬрд╛рддрд┐, or рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛ on the other. This shows that it is not necessary to take the negative particle in this verse in the sense of ‘smallness’ as is done by Udyota, Chakravarti and others. In this variety, words are used paronomastically.

The third variety where a Universal is incongruous with an Action is instanced in рдпреЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рдХрдгреНрдаetc. verse 93. Here, the

Universalрдзрд╛рд░рд╛рдзрд░рддреНрд╡is incongrouous with the Actions of рдЕрдиреБрд░рд╛рдЧ and рд╕реНрдиреЗрд╣рдкрд░рд╛рдкреНрддрд┐. This incongruity is removed when we take these words in the senses of ‘redness’ and ‘greasiness caused by contact with blood’. Similarly, the Universalрдкрд╛рдВрд╕реБрддреНрд╡ is incongruous with the Action of рдЕрд▓рдЩреНрдХрд░рдг. This incongruity is removed when we take this word in the sense of “cutting off the head.”

As for those who say that here рддреАрдХреНрд╖реНрдгрддреНрд╡is incongruous with рдЕрдиреБрд░рд╛рдЧ, they are wrong; for, according to this view, this would not be an example of рдЬрд╛рддрд┐рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рд╡рд┐рд░реЛрдзрдГ since рддреАрдХреНрд╖реНрдгрддреНрд╡ is not aрдЬрд╛рддрд┐ but a рдЧреБрдгand besides, even a cruel man being sometimes seen to be affectionate, рддреАрдХреНрд╖реНрдгрддреНрд╡is not invariably opposed to рдЕрдиреБрд░рд╛рдЧ.

The fourth variety where a Universal is incongruous with a Substance is instanced inрд╕реГрдЬрддрд┐ рдЪetc. verse 94. Here, the Substance рдЬрдирд╛рд░реНрджрди and the Universalрд╢рдлрд░рддреНрд╡ are opposed to each other. The opposition is explained by the fact that рдЬрдирд╛рд░реНрджрдиbeing a god may do anything, and may therefore, assume in sport the body of a fish. рдЬрдирд╛рд░реНрджрдиis a Substance, because рдЬрдирд╛рд░реНрджрди is рдкрд░рдорд╛рддреНрдорд╛, and рдЖрддреНрдорд╛ is regarded by the Vai┼Ыeс╣гikas as a Substance.

The fifth variety where a Quality is incongruous with a Quality is instanced in a рд╕рддрддрдВetc. verse 95. Here, ‘softness’ and ‘hardness’ are opposed to each other. The opposition is to be removed as follows:тАФBy your giving them wealth, they may give up domestic work, and thus their hands which were hitherto hard, may now become soft.

The sixth variety where a Quality is incongruous with an Action is instanced in рдкреЗрд╢рд▓рдордкрд┐╨╡tc. verse 96. Here, the Qualities of тАЩsoftness’ and ‘hardness’ are opposed to the Actions of ‘burning’ and ‘delighting.’ The opposition is to be removed by taking the wordsрдкреЗрд╢рд▓ and рдкрд░реБрд╖in the senses

of ‘pleasantness’ and ‘unpleasantness,’ and the word рджрд╣рддрд┐in the sense of ‘paining’.

The same variety is again instanced by рдкреНрд░рджреАрдк in рд╕рд░реНрд╡рддрдГ etc.

Here, the actions рджрд░реНрд╢рди and рдЧрдордиare opposed to the qualities рдЧрдордирд╛рднрд╛рд╡ and рднреБрдЬрднрд╛рдЬрдирддреНрд╡рд╛рднрд╛рд╡, respectively. It has been shown already how рдЧрдордирд╛рднрд╛рд╡ and рднреБрдЬрднрд╛рдЬрдирддреНрд╡рд╛рднрд╛рд╡ are qualities.

The seventh variety where a Quality is opposed to a Substance is instanced inрдХреНрд░реМрдЮреНрдЪрд╛рджреНрд░рд┐etc. verse 97. Here, the Quality ‘softness’ is opposed to the Substance- the рдХреНрд░реМрдЮреНрдЪmountain. The inconsistency is to be removed by takingрдЕрднрд┐рдЬрд╛рддin the sense of ‘capable of being easily pierced owing to the prowess of Bhargava.’

The eighth variety where an Action is opposed to an. Action is instanced in рдкрд░рд┐рдЪреНрдЫреЗрджрд╛рддреАрддetc. verse 98. Here, the Actions of ‘cooling’ and ‘heating’ are opposed to each other. The opposition is to be removed by supposing the two actions to be the wonderful effects of the ‘state of separation’ pro duced at different times.

The ninth variety where an Action is opposed to a Substance is instanced in рдЕрдпрдВ рд╡рд╛рд░рд╛рдореЗрдХреЛetc. verse 99. Here, the Action ‘drinking’ is opposed to the Substance, the subject of the verb ‘drinking,’ and to the Substance **рдЕрдЧрд╕реНрддреНрдп,**the object of the verb ‘drinking.’ The inconsistency is removed by the fact that every thing is possible in the case of Agastya owing to the greatness of his penance. Although, there being a plurality of oceans,рдЬрд▓рдирд┐рдзрд┐ is a Universal, and thus this verse does not, in this respect, deserve to be an example of рджреНрд░рд╡реНрдпрдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рд╡рд┐рд░реЛрдз, still, the example may be shown to be appropriate by taking the various oceans as one reservoir of salt-water.

The tenth variety where a Substance is opposed to a Substance is instanced inрд╕рдорджрдорддрдВрдЧрдЬ╨╡tc. verse 100. Here, the two Substances рдЧрдВрдЧрд╛andрдпрдореБрдирд╛are opposed to each other. The inconsistency is to be removed by taking рдХрд╛рд▓рд┐рдиреНрджреАin the sense of ‘dark-lustred’ only.

24. DESCRIPTION OF NATURE (рд╕реНрд╡рднрд╛рд╡реЛрдХреНрддрд┐)

K─Б. xxv. c d:тАФThe Description of Nature is the description of the peculiar action or appearance of (an object such as) a boy and the like.

** рд╕реНрд╡**(means) belonging to an object, and to that object only i. e. peculiar to it. Thus, the description of a property, that is not peculiar, but common to others also, is notрд╕реНрд╡рднрд╛рд╡реЛрдХреНрддрд┐.

** рд░реВрдк**(means) color, and arrangement of limbs or posture.

The action or appearance must be striking i. e. such as is perceived by the poet alone. Hence, such a verse asрдЧреЛрд░рдкрддреНрдпрдореНetc. is no example of this figure. Another name of this figure is рдЬрд╛рддрд┐.

The figure is instanced in рдкрд╢реНрдЪрд╛рджрдВрдШреНрд░реАetc. verse 101. Here, the peculiar posture and action of a horse are described by the poet, in such words as рдкрд╢реНрдЪрд╛рддреНetc. andрдШрд╛рд╕рдЧреНрд░рд╛рд╕ etc., respectively. The description of a peculiar color is exemplified in рдкреНрд░рдердо┬╣etc. where the color of the moon is described by the poet.

25. ARTFUL PRAISE (рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЬрд╕реНрддреБрддрд┐рдГ)

K─АRIK─АXXVI

K─Б. xxvi. *a b:тАФ*When in the beginning there is blameor praise, and the ultimate result is otherwise, it is (termed) Artful Praise.

‘Otherwise’ means praise or blame.

рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЬрд╕реНрддреБрддрд┐ is of two kinds:тАФ(1) when apparent blame ultimately results in real praise and (2) when apparent praise ultimately results in real blame. In the first kind, the compound рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЬрд╕реНрддреБрддрд┐ is to be solved and interpreted as рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЬреЗрди рд╕реНрддреБрддрд┐рдГpraise by means of an artifice, i. e. by means of a pretended

┬╣. рд╡рд░реНрдгрд╕реНрд╡рднрд╛рд╡рд╛реЛрдХреНрддрд┐рдГ
тАЩрдкреНрд░рдердордорд░реБрдгрдЪреНрдЫрд╛рдпрд╕реНрддрд╛рд╡рддреНрддрддрдГ рдХрдирдХрджреНрдпреБрддрд┐рдГ,
рддрджрдиреБ рд╡рд┐рд░рд╣реЛрддреНрддрд╛рдореНрдпрддреНрддрдиреНрд╡реАрдХрдкреЛрд▓рддрд▓рдкреНрд░рднрдГред
рдЙрджрдпрддрд┐ рддрддреЛ рдзреНрд╡рд╛рдиреНрддрдзреНрд╡рдВрд╕рдХреНрд╖рдордГ рдХреНрд╖рдгрджрд╛рдореБрдЦреЗ,
рд╕рд░рд╕рдмрд┐рд╕рд┐рдиреАрдХрдиреНрджрдЪреНрдЫреЗрджрдЪреНрдЫрд╡рд┐рд░реНрдореГрдЧрд▓рд╛рдВрдЫрдирдГ’ рдЗрддреНрдпрд╛рджреМрдмреЛрдзреНрдпрд╛ред рдкреНрд░рднрд╛.

blame. And in the second kind, the compound is to be solved and interpreted as рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЬрд░реВрдкрд╛ рд╕реНрддреБрддрд┐рдГpraise consisting in an artifice in other words, a pretended praise.

Examples in order:тАФ

  • *The first variety is instanced in рд╣рд┐рддреНрд╡рд╛ рддреНрд╡рд╛рдВetc. verse 102. Here, the apparent blame of the ‘king’ consists in representing him as denying shelter to those who seek it; whilst, the praise that is really intended is that he is wealthy, although so charitable.

The second is instanced inрд╣реЗ рд╣реЗрд▓рд╛рдЬрд┐рддetc. verse 103. Here, the apparent praise of the ‘ocean’ consists in representing him as a very obliging person. The blame that is really intended is that he is unobliging, inasmuch as he does not satisfy the thirst of travellers. This is not рдЕрдкреНрд░рд╕реНрддреБрддрдкреНрд░рд╢рдВрд╕рд╛; for, here there is a particular strikingness, consisting in either blame or praise: besides, it cannot fall under any of the five divisions into which рдЕрдкреНрд░рд╕реНрддреБрддрдкреНрд░рд╢рдВрд╕рд╛has been divided.

26. A SPEECH ‘WITH’ (рд╕рд╣реЛрдХреНрддрд┐рдГ)

K─Б. xxvi. c d:- When a single (expression), by the force of the meaning of ‘with’, conveys two meanings, it is (termed) a Speech with ‘With.’

When a word, conveying in virtue of the power of denotation possessed by it, a meaning connected with one thing, also conveys a meaning connected with both the things, by the force of the meaning of ‘with,’ it is рд╕рд╣реЛрдХреНрддрд┐.рд╕рд╣ denotes ‘conjunction of two actions, that are of one and the same sort, and are simultaneous in time,’ as in рдкреБрддреНрд░реЗрдг рд╕рд╣рд╛рдЧрддрдГ рдкрд┐рддрд╛. Here, the word рдЖрдЧрддрдГsignifies an act of coming, that is connected with both the father and the son. The idea conveyed is that of the father coming at the same time as the son. The noun in the nominative case is principal, that in the instrumental case is subordinate. The connection, therefore, with the former is expressed, with the latter, implied. In

рд╕рдореБрдЪреНрдЪрдп, instanced in рдЪреИрддреНрд░рдореИрддреНрд░реМрдЧрдЪреНрдЫрддрдГ, both the words рдЪреИрддреНрд░ and рдореИрддреНрд░are principal, and the connection with both is expressed. The figure is striking only when it is based upon a Hyperbole. Thus, рдкреБрддреНрд░реЗрдг рд╕рд╣etc. is no example of this figure.

The figure is instanced in рд╕рд╣ рджрд┐рд╡рд╕рдирд┐рд╢рд╛рднрд┐рдГetc. verse 104. HereрджреАрд░реНрдШрддреНрд╡ etc. ofрд╢реНрд╡рд╛рд╕рджрдВрдбare (understood from words whose connection is) expressed, of рджрд┐рд╡рд╕рдирд┐рд╢рд╛etc., however, are understood by the force of the meaning of the word рд╕рд╣. The figure is based upon a complete identification between the рджреАрд░реНрдШрддреНрд╡of рд╢реНрд╡рд╛рд╕рджрдВрдб and the рджреАрд░реНрдШрддреНрд╡ of рджрд┐рд╡рд╕рдирд┐рд╢рд╛. The figure34is possible in a series also; as inрдЙрддреНрдХреНрд╖рд┐рдкреНрддрдВ рд╕рд╣etc.

27. A SPEECH WITH ‘WITHOUT’ (рд╡рд┐рдиреЛрдХреНрддрд┐рдГ)

K─АRIK─АXXVII

K─Б. xxvii. *a b:тАФ*When a thing, in the absence of another is not agreeable or is not otherwise, it is termed a Speech with ‘Without.’

‘Not agreeable’ means disagreeable, ’not otherwise’ means not dis-agreeable i. e. agreeable. Thus,рд╡рд┐рдиреЛрдХреНрддрд┐ occurs when one thing is represented as sometimes disagreeable, (or) sometimes agreeable, in the absence of another, and is thus two-fold.

Here, only the sense of the word рд╡рд┐рдирд╛is required. Hence any other word bearing that sense (such as рдЛрддреЗ, рд░рд╣рд┐рдд etc.) may do.

Examples in order:тАФ

The first variety is instanced in рдЕрд░реБрдЪрд┐etc. verse 105. Here, the ‘Moon etc.’ without the ’night etc.’ are apprehended as disagreeable.

The second variety is instanced in рдореГрдЧрд▓реЛрдЪрдирдпрд╛etc. verse 106. Here, the ‘prince’ without his ‘wicked friend’ and the ‘deer-eyed lady’ appears to advantage, inasmuch as without the former he is described as being pure-minded, and without the latter as expert in business.

┬╣35Althoughthe ultimate meaning of the phrase рди рдЕрд╢реЛрднрдирдГis ‘agreeable,’ yet the expressing of the quality of agreeableness through the negation of that of disagreeableness, is intended to import that the apparent disagreeableness or loss of beauty of the object, under description, is the fault of the presence of another object, the former being indeed essentially fair.

28.THE BARTER (рдкрд░рд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐).

K─Б. xxvii. c d:тАФ The Barter is the exchange of things for what are (a) equal or (b) unequal.

(The word) рдкрд░рд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐is (the designation of) the figure to be defined, as known from the practice of ancient rhetoricians. Thus, there is no room for a doubt as to whetherрдкрд░рд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐ is here the thing to be defined or the definition. The wordрд╕рдорд╛рд╕рдореИ: gives us the two varieties of this figure.

Two things are said to be ’equal’, when both of them are to be received. When one of them however is fit to be received, and the other unfit, they are said to be ‘unequal.’ The unequal is either the ’lesser’ or the ‘greater.’ Thus, this variety is two-fold. The plural of рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рдирд╛рдореНis insignificant. According to Udyota, exchange is (1) the receiving of one thing for another given, or (2) the giving of one thing for another received. The giver and the receiver must be different persons. Hence рдХрд┐рдорд┐рддреНрдпрдкрд╛рд╕реНрдпрд╛рднрд░рдгрд╛рдирд┐ рдпреМрд╡рдиреЗ рдзреГрддрдВ рддреНрд╡рдпрд╛ рд╡рд╛рд░реНрдзрдХрд╢реЛрднрд┐ рд╡рд▓реНрдХрд▓рдВis no example, the giver and the receiver being there

identical. The exchange here is not real but fancied by the poet. Thus, **рдХреНрд░реАрдгрдиреНрддрд┐ рдпрддреНрд░ рдореБрдХреНрддрд╛рднрд┐рд░реНрд╡рджрд░рд╛рдгреНрдпрдкрд┐ рдмрд╛рд▓рд┐рдХрд╛рдГред**is no example.

The first two varieties are instanced inрд▓рддрд╛рдирд╛рдореЗрддрд╛etc. verse 107. Here, in the first half, one thing, viz. dancing, (is exchanged) for another, its equal, viz. fragrance. In the second, the ’eyes’ - the greater (are exchanged) for a ‘multitude of miseries’тАФthe lesser. The exchange is fancied, since ‘dancing of creepers’ is observed as owing to contact with the wind, and the ‘miseries of travellers’ as owing to the sight of creepers.

The third variety is instanced in рдирд╛рдирд╛рд╡рд┐рдз etc. verse 108. Here, ‘blows’тАФthe lesser (are exchanged) for earth’тАФthe greater.

Mamma╚Ыa appears to admit both the meanings ofрд╡рд┐рдирд┐рдордпgiven above, in conformity with the examples cited by him. Thus, in the second example, for instance, he takes рд╡рд┐рдирд┐рдордпin the second sense. Hence his Vс╣Ыtti on this part of the verse is рдЙрддреНрддрдореЗрди рдиреНрдпреВрдирд╕реНрдп which means: giving the lesser (i. e. рдЖрдзрд┐рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдзрд┐) for the greater (i. e.рджреГрдХреН) received. Pradipa, however, admits only the first meaning, and takesрд▓рддрд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд╡рдзреНрд╡рдиреНрдпрддрд╛рдореНetc., as an example of рдиреНрдпреВрдиреЗрди рдЙрддреНрддрдорд╕реНрдптАФ36receiving the greater тАФрджреГрдХреНfor the lesserтАФрдЕрдзрд┐рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдзрд┐given. The language of his comment on this part of the verse, however, is inconsistent with his meaning of рд╡рд┐рдирд┐рдордп, and his order of examples. It would be more appropriate to write рджреНрд╡рд┐рддреАрдпрд╛рд░реНрдереЗ рдЕрдиреБрдкрд╛рджреЗрдпрддрдпрд╛ рдиреНрдпреВрдиреИрдГ рдЖрдзрд┐рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдзрд┐рднрд┐рдГ рдЙрдкрд╛рджреЗрдпрддрдпрд╛ рдЙрддреНрддрдорд╛рдпрд╛ рджреГрд╢рдГ рд╡рд┐рдирд┐рдордпрдГ for what he has written.

Some37 hold that two things may be said to be ’equal,’ even when both of them are unfit to be received; as in рдЕрд╕реНрдерд┐рдорд╛рд▓рд╛ etc. Thus, according to these men, рд╡рд┐рдирд┐рдордп is not three-fold but four-fold.

29. THE VISION(рднрд╛рд╡рд┐рдХ)

K─АRIK─А XXVIII

K─Б. xxviii. a b c :- When things past and future are represented as if they were present, it is (termed) the Vision.

** рднреВрддрднрд╛рд╡рд┐рди**: is a Dvandva compound (рднреВрддрд╛рд╢реНрдЪ рднрд╛рд╡рд┐рдирд╢реНрдЪ) meaning ‘past and future.’ Had it been рдХрд░реНрдордзрд╛рд░рдп (рднреВрддрд╛ рдПрд╡ рднрд╛рд╡рд┐рдирдГ), it would have meant ‘past things which are future’ -which involves an obvious contradiction. The figure is calledрднрд╛рд╡рд┐рдХ,because there is in it an intention of the poet (to represent past or future things as perceptible to the senses). This is not the figure рднреНрд░рд╛рдиреНрддрд┐рдорд╛рдиреН; for, what is past or future is here mentioned as nothing but past or future. The employment of the past tense serves the purpose of bringing out the excellent beauty of the eyes, even though devoid of collyrium. Nor is thisрд╕реНрд╡рднрд╛рд╡реЛрдХреНрддрд┐; for, there the natural characteristic of an object is what is striking, here, it is the intention of the poet or of the speaker introduced by him that is striking.

Both the varieties are instanced inрдЖрд╕реАрджрдЮреНрдЬetc. verse 109.

Here, in the first (half) the past (object), viz. ‘collyrium,’ and in the second (half) the future (object), viz. ‘ornaments’ are (represented as if they were) present before our eyes. What is suggested here is: “your body in virtue of its peculiar nature appears beautiful even without ‘collyrium’ and ‘ornaments.’ These things are, therefore, useless.” Here actual words (i. e. рдЖрд╕реАрддреНetc.) are employed to show that the things, that are represented as if they were present, are really past or future. Sometimes, such words are not employed; as in рдЕрд╣рдВ рд╡рд┐рд▓реЛрдХрдпреЗрд╜рджреНрдпрд╛рдкрд┐ рдпреБрдзреНрдпрддреЗрд╜рддреНрд░ рд╕реБрд░рд╛рд╕реБрд░рд╛рдГред

Udyota says that this figure really comes under the third kind of Hyperbole, inasmuch as here a thing is represented as connected with the present time, although it is not really so connected.

30. THE POETICAL REASON (рдХрд╛рд╡реНрдпрд▓рд┐рдВрдЧ)

K─Б. xxviii. d:- The Poetical Reason is (the statement of) a reason in the form of the meaning (a) of a sentence or (b) of a word or (c) of words.

** **Here, by making the necessary distinction, we should understand the word рд╣реЗрддреБalone as giving us the definition, and рд╡рд╛рдХреНрдпрдкрджрд╛рд░реНрдерддрд╛ as giving us the divisions of рдХрд╛рд╡реНрдпрд▓рд┐рдВрдЧ. The reason stated here is such as accounts for a fact, which, by itself, is unintelligible.

The first variety (a) is instanced in рд╡рдкреБрдГ рдкреНрд░рд╛рджреБetc. verse 110. Here, the factтАФI never saluted you beforeтАФand the factтАУI will never salute you even in the futureтАФconstitute the reason for the sins committed. The two facts are expressed by two sentences. Thus, the reason is in the form of the sense of a sentence. Although ’non-salutation’ itself is the рдЕрдкрд░рд╛рдз, and thus the relation of cause and effect does not hold good between them, still by ‘рдЕрдкрд░рд╛рдз’ we should understand here ‘Sin,’ and ‘**рдХреНрд╖рдордгтАЩ**should by Indication mean ‘destruction.’ Thus, ’non-salutation’ becomes the reason of the sins committed.

The next two varieties may be instanced in this very example as follows:тАФThe fact of ’non-assumption of the bodyтАЩтАФwhich is expressed by one word only, viz. **рдЕрддрдиреБрдГтАФ**is the reason for ’non-salutation’ in the future; and the fact of ‘final release,’ the result of salutation-which is expressed by two words **рдирдордиреН рдореБрдХреНрддрдГтАФ**is the reason for тАЩnon-assumption of the body in the future.’

The third variety (c) is instanced in рдкреНрд░рдгрдпрд┐ etc. vesse 111. Here, the fact of the ‘discharge of the weapon,’ expressed by the words рд╢рд╕реНрддреНрд░рдореБрдкрдХреНрд╖рд┐рддрдГis the reason for the ‘fall of the arm.’ Neither the words рд╢рд╕реНрддреНрд░рдореБрдкрдХреНрд╖рд┐рдкрддрдГ nor the words рддрддреНрд░ рд╡рдкреБрд╖рд┐рд╡рдзрд╛рдп рд╢рд╕реНрддреНрд░рдореБрдкрдХреНрд╖рд┐рдкрддрдГ. constitute a sentence; for, they are adjec-

tives, and do not express a complete thought without the noun рддрд╡which they qualify.

The second variety (b) is instanced in рднрд╕реНрдореЛetc. verse 112. Here, рд╕реБрдЦрд╛рд▓реЛрдХреЛрдЪреНрдЫреЛрджрд┐рддреНрд╡ constitutes the reason for the ‘great darkness of final emancipation.’ рдпреБрд╖реНрдорддреНрд╕рдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рд╕реБрдЦрд╛рд▓реЛрдХреЛрдЪреНрдЫрд┐рддреНрддрд┐, being a compound, is but one word.

Thus, in these (three exampls), ’non-salutation in previous and future births,’ ‘discharge of the weapon,’ and ‘deprivation of the light of happiness,’ constitute reasons of the above-mentioned characters for ’the two sinsтАЩ, for ’the fall of the armтАЩ, and for ’the great darkness (of final emancipation),’ respectively.

According to Prad─лpa, the distinction betweenрдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдиреНрдпрд╛рд╕and this figure is that in the former, the second statement is made independently of, i. e. as unconnected with the first statement, and is ultimately apprehended as the reason for (corroborating) the first statement. Whilst here one statement is directly mentioned as a reason for the other, by the employment of a noun or pronoun in the ablative or any other case showing reason.

Upon this Prabh─Б observes that Pradipa’s word рд╣реЗрддреБрд╡рд┐рднрдХреНрддреНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛38is wrong; for, in the example here given, a word showing reason is absent. Besides, if the reason be expressed by a word in the ablative case, then such verses as рдЕрд▓рдорд┐рддрд┐etc. and рдкреНрд░рдЬрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рд╡рд┐рдирдпрд╛ etc. would be examples of рдХрд╛рд╡реНрдпрд▓рд┐рдВрдЧ which they are not. Again, it is only a reason which is implied and not expressed by a word in the ablative case, that has been regarded by the ancients as pleasing, and as such has been admitted by them as constituting рдХрд╛рд╡реНрдпрд▓рд┐рдВрдЧ.
