Hence it is that

in рд╡рдкреБрдГрдкреНрд░рд╛рджреБрд░реНрднрд╛рд╡рд╛рджрдиреБрдорд┐рддрдореН (the first part of the first line) there is no рдХрд╛рд╡реНрдпрд▓рд┐рдВрдЧ. Udyota regards the word рд╣реЗрддреБрд╡рд┐рднрдХреНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рдирд╛ as but a mis-reading.

This figure is not рдЕрдиреБрдорд╛рди; for, theрд╣реЗрддреБ is not here stated as invariably associated with the рд╕рд╛рдзреНрдп, and as connected with the рдкрдХреНрд╖, as it is in рдЕрдиреБрдорд╛рди. According to others, in рдЕрдиреБрдорд╛рди, the poet composes his verse in such a manner, (i. e. by stating the рд╣реЗрддреБ as possessed of рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдкреНрддрд┐ and рдкрдХреНрд╖рдзрд░реНрдорддрд╛), that his intention is that the reader should know from the peculiar structure of the verse, that an inference has been drawn by the poet himself. Whilst in рдХрд╛рд╡реНрдпрд▓рд┐рдВрдЧ, the poet’s intention is that the inference should be drawn by the reader himself, and not simply known by him as drawn by the poet.

According to рдкреНрд░рднрд╛, рдХрд╛рд╡реНрдпрд▓рд┐рдВрдЧ┬╣39is when a рдХрд╛рд░рдХрд╣реЗрддреБ is implied by words, directly or indirectly. A рдХрд╛рд░рдХрд╣реЗрддреБis an efficient causeтАФ a cause that produces something,asрджрдгреНрдб, рдЪрдХреНрд░etc. produce a рдШрдЯ. рдЕрдиреБрдорд╛рди is when a рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдкрдХрд╣реЗрддреБ is mentioned. AрдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдкрдХрд╣реЗрддреБis an indicatory reason- a mark- which enables us to infer something as a lamp enables us to see aрдШрдЯ. рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдиреНрдпрд╛рд╕is when a proposition is put forth to corroborate another proposition. In рдирд┐рдЬрджреЛрд╖рд╛рд╡реГрддetc. for instance, the particular is not theрдХрд╛рд░рдХрд╣реЗрддреБ of the general. Hence the verse is not an example ofрдХрд╛рд╡реНрдпрд▓рд┐рдВрдЧ. In рдкрд░рд┐рдХрд░┬▓40the sense suggested through the force of the sense of the sentence or of a word. or words, contributes to the expressed sense; here the sense of the sentence or of the word itself constitutes the reason.

31. PERIPHRASIS (рдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рдпреЛрдХреНрдд)

K─АRIK─АXXIX

K─Б. xxix. a b:- The statement (of a fact) without the relation of the expressed and the expresser (between that fact and the words which bring it out) is (termed) Periphrasis.

When a fact (that is intended to be expressed) is conveyed through the power of suggestion which is different from the relation of the expressed and the expresser (i. e. from the power of Denotation of the words), it is рдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рдпреЛрдХреНрдд*, (so called) because the (intended) fact is stated in a different manner.* In other words, рдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рдпреЛрдХреНрддis when a fact which is intended to be expressed is conveyed by words which do not express it but by words which suggest it. This figure is distinguished from Suggestive Poetry by the fact that in the former, the expressed sense is identical with the suggested sense, whilst, in the latter, it is different from it; or, according to Udyota, by the fact that in the former, the suggested sense is quite plain and is not more striking than the expressed sense; whilst, in the latter, it is not so.

The figure is instanced inрдпрдВ рдкреНрд░реЗрдХреНрд╖реНрдп рдЪрд┐рд░far etc. verse 113. Here рдореЛрдЪрди and рдирд┐рд╡рд╛рд╕рдкреНрд░реАрддрд┐рддреНрдпрд╛рдЧтАФthe suggested and expressed senses of the verse, respectively, are ultimately identical with each other. One and the same sense is, therefore, conveyed by the verse through the power of Suggestion in the form; рдРрд░рд╛рд╡рдгрд╢рдХреНрд░реМ рдорджрдорд╛рдирд╡рд┐рдореБрдХреНрддреМ рдЬрд╛рддреМ, and through the power of Expression in the form: рдорджрдорд╛рдирд╛рднреНрдпрд╛рдВ рддрдпреЛрд░рдзрд┐рдХрд░рдгрдпреЛрд░реНрдирд┐рд╡рд╛рд╕рдкреНрд░реАрддрд┐рд░реБрдЬреНрдЭрд┐рддрд╛. In other words, (the sense) рдРрд░рд╛рд╡рдгрд╢рдХреНрд░реМрдорджрдорд╛рдирдореБрдХреНрддреМ рдЬрд╛рддреМ, although suggested, is yet expressed by (the) words (of the verse). Thus, what is expressed is what is suggested.

If it be said that the knowledge of a thing which is already known being useless, there is no need of one and the same sense being conveyed by means of the two powers of a word,

i. e. the power of Expression and the power of Suggestion, we reply:тАФTrue that one and the same sense is expressed and suggested by the verse, but the form in which that sense is suggested is not the same as that in which it is expressed. The thing may be the same and yet modes may be different, as in the following example:тАФWhen a ‘white walking cow’ is perceived, there is the determination that it is a white walking cow. Thus, what one perceives, is what one determines, but one does not determine it in the manner in which one perceives it; for, one perceives (a white walking cow) as (a cow) undistinguished and unconnected; whilst, one determines it to be (a cow) possessed of distinction and connection.

рджрд░реНрд╢рди and рд╡рд┐рдХрд▓реНрдк mentioned by Mammaс╣нa in his Vс╣Ыtti here mean рдирд┐рд░реНрд╡рд┐рдХрд▓реНрдкрдХрдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдХреНрд╖ and рд╕рд╡рд┐рдХрд▓реНрдкрдХрдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдХреНрд╖, respectively.

According to the Naiy─Бyikas in a рдирд┐рд░реНрд╡рд┐рдХрд▓реНрдкрдХрдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдХреНрд╖, an object is perceived as unconnected with such attributes as class (рдЬрд╛рддрд┐), quality (рдЧреБрдг), action (рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛) etc. A рдЧреЛ, for instance, is perceived as unconnected with рдЧреЛрддреНрд╡, рд╢реБрдХреНрд▓рддреНрд╡, рдЪрд▓рди etc. All the things, i. e. the object, рдЧреЛрддреНрд╡, рд╢реБрдХреНрд▓рддреНрд╡, рдЪрд▓рдиetc. are here perceived as independent of, and unconnected with, one another.

In common language we may say that we perceive a рдЧреЛhere, but we do not recognise to ourselves what thatрдЧреЛ is; that is we do not know to which class of beasts it belongs, by which name it is called, whether it is white or black, walking or not etc. In fact, we perceive it as something ( рдЗрджрдВ рдХрд┐рдВрдЪрд┐рддреН ).

In aрд╕рд╡рд┐рдХрд▓реНрдкрдХрдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдХреНрд╖on the other hand, an object is perceived as connected with such attributes as class, quality etc. A рдЧреЛ, for instance, is perceived as connected with рдЧреЛрддреНрд╡,рд╢реБрдХреНрд▓рддреНрд╡etc. All the things. i.e. the object, рдЧреЛрддреНрд╡, рд╢реБрдХреНрд▓рддреНрд╡ etc. are here perceived as connected with one another. In ordinary lannuage we may say that here we perceive a and recognize it for what it is. In other words, we know that it

belongs to the class of рдЧреЛs, that it is white, that it is walking etc.

According to the Bauddhas, in a рдирд┐рд░реНрд╡рд┐рдХрд▓реНрдкрдХ, an object is perceived as undistinguished, whilst, in a рд╕рд╡рд┐рдХрд▓реНрдкрдХ, as distinguished, from others of a different class. For instance, a рдЧреЛis perceived in the former as not different from others that are notтАФрдЧреЛ; whilst, it is perceived in the latter as different from others that are notтАФрдЧреЛ. These two kinds of Perception, Indeterminate (рдирд┐рд░реНрд╡рд┐рдХрд▓реНрдкрдХ) and Determinate (рд╕рд╡рд┐рдХрд▓реНрдкрдХ) are referred to here by Mammaс╣нa under the words Perception (рджрд░реНрд╢рди) and Determination (рд╡рд┐рдХрд▓реНрдк). The dualрднреЗрджрд╕рдВрд╕рд░реНрдЧрд╛рднреНрдпрд╛рдореН shows that Mammaс╣нa here combines the Naiy─Бyika and the Buddhist view into one.

Thus, just as the object of both the kinds of Perception is one and the same, and yet the modes of perceiving it are different-one Indeterminate, the other Determinate: so the sense to be conveyed in рдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рдпреЛрдХреНрддis one and the same, and yet the modes of conveying it are differentтАФone of Expression and the other of Suggestion.

32. THE EXALTED (рдЙрджрд╛рддреНрдд)

K─Б. xxix. c:тАФ(A description of) the prosperity of a thing is (termed) the Exalted.

‘Prosperity (of a thing)’ means ‘connection of that thing with the plenty of anything.’ It does not mean┬╣41 ‘abundance’ of that thing itself. For, if it would mean that, the definition would extend to such a verse asрд╡рджрд░рд╛ etc. which is an instance of рдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рдп.

The figure is instanced in рдореБрдХреНрддрд╛рдГetc. verse 114. Here the houses of the learned are described as connected with

the abundance of wealth in the form of pearls etc. From this, the excessive prosperity of king BhojaтАФ the object under description, is apprehended.

K─Б. xxix. d:тАФ Also the subordination to the great is (termed the Exalted).

** **The subordination (of the great), i. e., the representation (of the great) as collateral, of course, to the subject in hand, is also (termed) the Exalted.

The figure is instanced in рддрджрд┐рджрдорд░рдгреНрдпрдореНetc. verse 115. Here, the great R─Бma is represented collaterally to the Daс╣Зс╕Нaka forestтАФ the matter under description, in order that the representation may bring out the great importance of that forest.

If it be said:тАФ Here, strikingness is due to R─Бma’s great energy ifself which is here principal. No other point of strikingness exists in the verse. Thus, this does not deserve to be called a figure, but Suggestive Poetry; we reply:тАФThe Heroic Flavour is not here (principal), because it serves to glorify R─Бma who is here subordinated (to the Daс╣Зс╕Нaka forest). Here R─Бma, who is the basis of рд╡реАрд░рд░рд╕, is Subordinate. Therefore, there can be no talk of рд░рд╕being predominant. If it be saidтАФ well, as рд░рд╕is subordinate here we shall call itрд░рд╕рд╡рджрд▓рдЩреНрдХрд╛рд░; we reply- No. The figure рдЙрджрд╛реНрддреНрддsupersedes it.If it were not so, then there would be no room for рдЙрджрд╛рддреНрддрд╛рд▓рдЩреНрдХрд╛рд░.

33. THE CONJUNCTION(рд╕рдореБрдЪреНрдЪрдп).

K─АRIK─А XXX.

K─Б. xxx. a b:- When, one cause of the production of an effect being present, others (are said to) produce that (effect), it is (termed) the Conjunction.

When, one cause capable of producing the effect in question being present, other causes are (represented to be) present, it is рд╕рдореБрдЪреНрдЪрдп.

The singular number of рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреН is insignificant here.

In рд╕рдорд╛рдзрд┐, the causes are of unequal power; the effect which is to be brought about by one cause, becomes simply easy through the accidental operation of another cause. Here, all the causes are equally powerful. They jointly operate in the production of the effect, just as pigeons alight together upon a threshing-floor. The facilitation of the effect is here absent.

InрдХрд╛рд╡реНрдпрд▓рд┐рдВрдЧthe causes only are intended; whether they are one or many, or whether one of them is principal and the others subordinate, is not the object under consideration. Here, whilst one cause able to produce an effect is engaged in its production, others only help it.

The figure is instanced in рджреБрд░реНрд╡рд╛рд░рд╛рдГetc. verse 116. Here, the (irresisitble) arrows of Cupid, themselves, make the ‘state of separation’ insupportable; over and above these (such causes as) the ’lover’s being at a distance etc.’ are mentioned as doing the same.

Rudra╚Ыa┬╣42 has divided this figure into three kinds, i. e. Combination (1) of good things, (2) of bad things, and (3) of good and bad things, and defined them separately. But, inasmuch as this very (figure, i. e.) Conjunction holds good in all these kinds*,* that is, where the combination is of good things, where the combination is of bad things, and where the combination is of good and bad things, we have not defined these separately.

The first kind is instanced in рдХреБрд▓рдордорд▓рд┐рдирдВetc. verse 117. Here, notwithstanding the existence of one cause, i. e- ‘pure family’ capable of producing the effects, i. e. ‘pride’ and the ‘absense of it,’ other causes such as ‘a handsome figure etc.’ are mentioned. All these causes being good things (since the things are naturally agreeable), the Conjunction here is of good things.

  • But in the example (first) mentioned,* i. e. in рддреБрд░реНрд╡рд╛рд░рд╛рдГetc., the Conjunction is of such bad things as ’the arrows of Cupid etc.’ These things are bad, because they cause pain to a ‘woman under separation’ who is the subject under discourse.

The third kind is instanced inрд╢рд╢реА рджрд┐рд╡рд╕рдзреВрд╕рд░рдГetc. verse 118. Here, the ‘moon dimmed (by day)тАЩ is alone sufficient to become a sore affliction (to my heart); yet other sore afflictions (are mentioned). Thus, inasmuch as a ‘wicked person’ is bad, and the ‘moon’ good*, there is (here) a Conjunction of both good and bad things.*

тАЩThis requires consideration,тАЩ ┬╣43says Prad─лpa. ‘For, just as in the previous example (viz. рджреБрд░реНрд╡рд╛рд░рд╛рдГetc.), the lover, although naturally good, becomes bad in virtue of his being at a distance, so here also, the moon although naturally good, becomes bad in virtue of his being dimmed by day. Thus, this verse also, like рджреБрд░реНрд╡рд╛рд░рд╛рдГetc., deserves to be an example of рдЕрд╕рджреНрдпреЛрдЧ and not of рд╕рджрд╕рджреНрдпреЛрдЧ as said by Mammaс╣нa.’

Pradipa takesрд╕рджрд╕рджреНрдпреЛрдЧ as a рджреНрд╡рдВрджреНрд╡Compound and interprets it as ‘Conjunction of good and bad things.’ But this interpretation is wrong. For, firstly, if we accept it, the verse becomes open to the fault of aрд╕рд╣рдЪрд░рднрд┐рдиреНрдирддреНрд╡(Dissimilarity of the

associated), inasmuch as it contains the association of good and bad things which are opposed to each other. And secondly, according to this interpretation, the example, as Prad─лpa himself says, becomes identical with the example рджреБрд░реНрд╡рд╛рд░рд╛рдГ etc.

We should, therefore, take рд╕рджрд╕рджреНрдпреЛрдЧas a рдХрд░реНрдордзрд╛рд░рдп Compound (рд╕рдВрддрд╢реНрдЪ рддреЗ рдЕрд╕рдиреНрддрд╢реНрдЪ, рддреЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рдпреЛрдЧрдГ) and interpret it as ‘Conjunction of things that are both good and bad.’ Now, the fault ofрд╕рд╣рдЪрд░рднрд┐рдиреНрдирддреНрд╡ vanishes; for, each of the things combined in the verse being both good and bad- good by itself, and bad in a particular state,тАФthe combination is not unequal. The example also may be differeet from рджреБрд░реНрд╡рд╛рд░рд╛рдГetc. thus:- InрджреБрд░реНрд╡рд╛рд░рд╛рдГ44etc. although a ’lover etc.’ are naturally good things, still they are intended by the poet to appear as simply bad to the woman under separation. Whilst, here the ‘moon etc.’ are intended to appear as both good and bad-good in virtue of their beauty and bad in virtue of their distressing the mind etc. Or thus:- In рджреБрд░реНрд╡рд╛рд░рд╛рдГ etc., although one thing, i. e. the ’lover’ is good naturally, but bad when he is at a distance, still, all the other things mentioned in the verse, i. e.рдорд╛рд░реНрдЧрдг,рд╡рдпрдГ, рд╡рд╕рдВрдд etc., are painful to the woman under separation even naturally.

Thus, inasmuch as all the things in the verse (рджреБрд░реНрд╡рд╛рд░рд╛рдГetc.) except рдкреНрд░рд┐рдпрддрдоare bad, the verse is nothing but an example of рдЕрд╕рджреНрдпреЛрдЧ. But, here all the things are both good and badтАФ good naturally but bad in virtue of the attributesрдзреВрд╕рд░рддреНрд╡etc.; therefore, this is an example of **рд╕рджрд╕рджреНрдпреЛрдЧ.**Everywhere in the verse the рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реНрдпрд╜ such as рд╢рд╢реАetc. are good, and the рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдгрд╜ such as рдзреВрд╕рд░etc. are bad. This uniformity is, however, violated in рдиреГрдкрд╛рдВрдЧрдгрдЧрддрдГ рдЦрд▓рдГ where the рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реНрдп, i. e. рдЦрд▓ is

bad, but the рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдг, i. e. рдиреГрдкрд╛рдВрдЧрдг is good. But, inasmuch┬╣45as here also we get a thing, i. e. рдЦрд▓that is both good and bad (whether the рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реНрдп is good or the рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдг is good is here in significant), the whole verse is a good example of рд╕рджрд╕рджреНрдпреЛрдЧ.

Some,┬▓46 рддрджрдВрд╢рдореБрдкреЗрдХреНрд╖реНрдпреИрд╡ рдЕрд▓рдВрдХрд╛рд░реЛрджрд╛рд╣рд░рдгрддрд╛ред Chan.") however, say that inasmuch as the verse contains рднрдЧреНрдирдкреНрд░рдХреНрд░рдорддреНрд╡, it is unfit to become an example of this figure. They, therefore, regard the first three lines only of the verse as an example of рд╕рджрд╕рджреНрдпреЛрдЧ. Udyota wishes to avoid the fault altogether by proposing to read рдиреГрдкрд╛рдВрдЧрдгрдорд╕рджреНрдпреБрддрдореН for рдиреГрдкрд╛рдВрдЧрдгрдЧрддрдГ рдЦрд▓рдГ.

** **K─Б. xxx. d:тАФ That is another ( kind of Conjunction ) where Qualities and Actions are sim ultaneous.

** The Compound рдЧреБрдгрдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рдГ may be solved, according to some, as рдЧреБрдгреМ рдЪ рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпреЗ рдЪ = рдЧреБрдгрдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рдГ, рдЧреБрдгрд╢реНрдЪ рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛ рдЪ = рдЧреБрдгрдХреНрд░рд┐рдпреЗ, and then by рдПрдХрд╢реЗрд╖, рдЧреБрдгрдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рд╢реНрдЪ рдЧреБрдгрдХреНрд░рд┐рдпреЗ рдЪ = рдЧреБрдгрдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рдГ. Here, the number of the things conjoined is not the point. Hence, the dual number of рдЧреБрдгреМandрдХреНрд░рд┐рдпреЗ** is insignificant. Thus, those men┬│47 are not right who suppose that the dual number is significant as showing that the things combined, must be

two and two only. For, it is a general rule that the number of the words that are compounded with others is always singular. The supposition, therefore, that the number рдЧреБрдгandрдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛ is dual here is far-fetched. Or the Compound may be solved (according to Pradipa) as рдЧреБрдгрд╛рдГ рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рд╢реНрдЪ. Here also, neither number nor homogeneity of the simultaneous things is the point. Hence simultaneity of heterogeneous things (or of homogeneous things more than two) is also included under this figure.

We thus get three Varieties here:тАФSimultaneity (1) of two or (or many) Qualities, (2) of two (or many) Actions, and (3) of a Quality and an Action. The word ‘Simultaneous’ distinguishes this figure fromрджреАрдкрдХ where the many Actions are not simultaneous, but successive.

Examples in order :тАФ

The Simultaneity of two Qualities (1) is instanced in рд╡рд┐рджрд▓рд┐рддetc. (рд░реБрджреНрд░рдЯ VII. 28) verse 119. Here, the simultaneity is of two Qualities, i, e. brightness and darkness.

Simultaneity of many Qualities is instanced in рдкреНрд░рд╛рджреБрд░реНрднрд╡рддрд┐┬╣48etc.

The Simultaneity of two Actions is instanced inрдЕрдпрдореЗрдХetc. verse 120. Here, the Simultaneity is of two Actions, i. e. arriving and becoming.

The Simultaneity of many Actions is instanced inрдЙрджрд┐рддрдВ49etc.

The Simultaneity of a Quality and Action is instanced. in рдХрд▓реБрд╖рдВ рдЪetc. vorse 121. Here, the Quality ’turbidity’ and the Action ‘falling’ are simultaneous.

It should not be said, as Rudrata does, that (this Conjunction is possible only) when the abodes (of the simultaneoue things) are different, nor (should it be said that it is possibls only) when the abode is one and the same; for, (such verses as)рдзреБрдиреЛрддрд┐etc. and рдХреГрдкрд╛рдгрдкрд╛рдгрд┐: etc. are found, in the former of which, the ActionрдзреБрдиреЛрддрд┐ andрддрдиреЛрддрд┐ are simultaneous, although their abode is one and the same, and in the latter, the Actions рдкрд╛рдгреМ рдХреГрдкрд╛рдгрдХрд░рдг and рд╕рд╛рдзреБрд╡рд╛рджрдХрд░рдг are simultaneous, although their abodes are different. All these┬╣50varieties of Conjunction are as a rule founded upon a Hyperbole consisting in the inversion of the necessary sequence of cause and effect. Thus, Hyperbole is not the figure here, but Conjunction, Hyperbole being only subordinate to it.

34. THE SEQUENCE (рдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рдп)

K─АRIK─АXXXI

K─Б. xxxi. a:тАФOne (thing) in many (places) successively is (termed) the Sequence.

** **When a thing (intended as) one (1) is, or (2) is made to be in many (places), in succession, that is рдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рдп.

The words ‘in succession’ exclude рд╕рдореБрдЪреНрдЪрдпand the second kind of рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖in both of which there is Simultaneity. The word рднрд╡рддрд┐in the Vс╣Ыtti does not denote ’natural existence’; for, рдХрд╛рд▓рдХреВрдЯ does not naturally exist on the throat of ┼Ъiva; thus, if рднрд╡рддрд┐would mean ’natural existence’, the verseрдирдиреНрд╡рд╛рд╢реНрд░рдпetc. would not be an example of рднрд╡рддрд┐. So рдХрд░реЛрддрд┐also does not denote ‘artificial existence’. These words mean here ’nonmention and mention of a causal agency,’ respectively.

Examples in order:тАФ

The first variety (1) is instanced in рдирдиреНрд╡рд╛рд╢реНрд░рдпрд╕реНрдерд┐рддрд┐etc. verse 122. Here, рдХрд╛рд▓рдХреВрдЯ, which is really one, is said to reside

in places that are several. No cause, however, as to why it resides in many places is mentioned. Here, the unity ofрдХрд╛рд▓рдХреВрдЯis real; sometimes it may be due to a fancied identity; as in рдмрд┐рдореНрдмреЛрд╖реНрдаetc., verse 123. Here also no cause as to why one thing, i. e. рд░рд╛рдЧ resides in two places, i. e. рдУрд╖реНрдаand рд╣реГрджрдп, is mentioned. Althoughрд░рд╛рдЧ (residing in the lips, in the shape of ‘redness’) is really different fromрд░рд╛рдЧ (residing in the heart, in the shape of ’love’) still inasmuch as (the two рд░рд╛рдЧрд╜*) are ascertained as identical with each other, the unity (intended in the K─Бrik─Б) is not (here) contradicted.*

  • *The second variety (2) is instanced in рддрддреНрддреЗрд╖рд╛рдВetc. verse124. Here, one and the same ‘heart’ is made to reside in two places, i. e. рд╡рд┐рд╖реНрдгреБ and рдмрд┐рдореНрдмрд╛рдзрд░. The causal agency, i. e. тАЩCupid’ is mentioned.,

The verse рд╢реНрд░реЛрдгреАрднрд╛рдЧрдГetc. commented upon by Udyota, is found in some books of the K─Бvyaprak─Б┼Ыa. Many commentators such as M─Бс╣Зikya-Candra and others regard it as an example of the first variety of рдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рдпрдГ, inasmuch┬╣51as in the first line of it, one thing, i. e. рддрдиреБрддреНрд╡is said to reside in the two places рд╢реНрд░реЛрдгреАрднрд╛рдЧ and рдордзреНрдпрднрд╛рдЧ, and in the second line, one thing, i. e. рддрд░рд▓рдЧрддрд┐ is said to reside in the two places рдкрд╛рдж and рд▓реЛрдЪрди. In this example, one thing resides in two places; in the nextрдирдиреНрд╡рд╛рд╢реНрд░рдпetc., one thing resides in many places. This, according to Sanketa, is the distinction between the two examples. But Sudh─Бs─Бgara and others regard this verse as an interpolation, probably on the ground that this example is unnecessary and also on the ground that this does not become an example of рдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рдп since the word рд╡рд┐рдирд┐рдордп in the verse shows that рдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рдпis not intended by the poet.

K─Б. xxxi. b:тАФThe reverse of that is another (Sequence).

The reverse of the former is the second kind of рдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рдп; in other words, when many (things) (1) are, or (2) are made to be, in one (place), in succession, that is another рдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рдп. Here also the words ‘in succession’ exclude рд╕рдореБрдЪреНрдЪрдп.

Examples in order:тАХ

The first variety (1) is instanced in рдордзреБрд░рд┐рдоetc. verse 125.

Here, ’the manifestation of nectar’ and ’the announcement of poison’ are successively on the part of one and the same thing i. e. ’the words of the wicked.’ The causal agency is not mentioned.

The second variety (2) is instanced in рддрджреНрдЧреЗрд╣рдВetc. verse 126. Here, the ‘house’ and the ‘palace,’ are successively made to belong to one: and the same person i. e. ’this Br─Бhmin.’ The causal agency, i. e. ‘days’ is mentioned.

Here (i. e. in both the varieties of this figure), there is no Barter. For, although┬╣52in the first variety of this figure the fact that one and the same thing should be abandoned by one person and received by another is intended as in Barter, still, the additional fact that one and the same (person) should abandon (one thing) and receive (another), is not intended as it is in Barter.

Thus, for instance, in рдирдиреНрд╡рд╛рд╢реНрд░рдп╨╡tc., verse 122, although the fact thatрдХрд╛рд▓рдХреВрдЯshould be abandoned by рдЕрд░реНрдгрд╡and receivedbyрд╢рдВрдХрд░is intended as in Barter, still, the additional factthatрдЕрд░реНрдгрд╡should abandonрдХрд╛рд▓рдХреВрдЯ and receive something else, or that рд╢рдВрдХрд░should receiveрдХрд╛рд▓рдХреВрдЯ and abandon something else, is not intended as it is in Barter.

Although┬╣53

рдХрд╛рд▓рдХреВрдЯ

is abandoned by рдЕрд░реНрдгрд╡, still, something else is not received by him; so also althoughрдХрд╛рд▓рдХреВрдЯis received by рд╢рдВрдХрд░, still, something else is not abandoned by him.

Similarly, in the second variety of this figure, although the fact that one and the same person should abandon one thing and receive another is intended as in Barter, still, the additional fact that one and the same (thing) should be abandoned (by one person) and received (by another) is not intended as it is in Barter.

Thus, for instance, in рддрджреНрдЧреЗрд╣рдВetc. verse 126, although the fact that рджреНрд╡рд┐рдЬshould abandonрдЧреЗрд╣ and receiveрдордиреНрджрд┐рд░ is intended as in Barter, still, the additional fact that рдЧреЗрд╣should be abandoned by рджреНрд╡рд┐рдЬ and received by рджрд┐рд╡рд╕, or that рдордиреНрджрд┐рд░ should be received byрджреНрд╡рд┐рдЬ and abandoned by рджрд┐рд╡рд╕, is not intended as it is in Barter.

AlthoughрдЧреЗрд╣ is abandoned by рджреНрд╡рд┐рдЬstill it is not intended to be received by рджрд┐рд╡рд╕; so also althoughрдордиреНрджрд┐рд░ is received by рджреНрд╡рд┐рдЬ still it is not intended to be abandoned by рджрд┐рд╡рд╕.

In рдкрд░рд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐ there is рдПрдХрдХрд░реНрддреГрдХрднрд┐рдиреНрдирдХрд░реНрдордХ рд╣рд╛рдиреЛрдкрд╛рджрд╛рди, and рдПрдХрдХрд░реНрдордХрднрд┐рдиреНрдирдХрд░реНрддреГрдХ рд╣рд╛рдиреЛрдкрд╛рджрд╛рди also. In the first variety of рдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рдп, although there is рдПрдХрдХрд░реНрдордХрднрд┐рдиреНрдирдХрд░реНрддреГрдХ рд╣рд╛рдиреЛрдкрд╛рджрд╛рди, still there is no рдПрдХрдХрд░реНрддреГрдХрд╛рднрд┐рдиреНрдирдХрд░реНрдордХ рд╣рд╛рдиреЛрдкрд╛рджрд╛рди. Similarly, in the second variety of рдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рдп, although there is рдПрдХрдХрд░реНрддреГрдХрднрд┐рдиреНрдирдХрд░реНрдордХ рд╣рд╛рдиреЛрдкрд╛рджрд╛рди, still there is no рдПрдХрдХрд░реНрдордХрднрд┐рдиреНрдирдХрд░реНрддреГрдХ рд╣рд╛рдиреЛрдкрд╛рджрд╛рди. This is the distinction between рдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рдп and рдкрд░рд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐.

Prad─лpa, however, simply says:тАФ

This is not Barter, since ‘abandoning’ and ‘receiving’ (although present) are not (yet) intended here (by the poet).

35. INFERENCE(рдЕрдиреБрдорд╛рди).

K─Б. xxxi. c d:тАФThe statement of a (logical) Reason and a Conclusion is said to be Inference.

рд╕рд╛рдзрдиis that which proves the existence of one thing upon another, as in the stock example рдкрд░реНрд╡рддреЛ рд╡рд╣реНрдирд┐рдорд╛рдиреН рдзреВрдорд╛рддреН, рдзреВрдо is the рд╕рд╛рдзрди, because it proves the existence of рд╡рд╣реНрдирд┐on the mountain. рд╕рд╛рдзреНрдп is that whose existence is to be proved by means of the рд╕рд╛рдзрди. As in the above example, ‘fire’ is the рд╕рд╛рдзреНрдп, because its existence is to be proved on the ‘mountain’ by means of the рд╕рд╛рдзрди тАШsmoke’. рдкрдХреНрд╖ is a рдзрд░реНрдореА, i. e. that which has theрд╕рд╛рдзреНрдп for its attribute, that is, that on which the existence of the рд╕рд╛рдзреНрдпis proved; as mountain’ is the рдкрдХреНрд╖, because on it the existence of ‘fire’ is proved.

For a true Inference, the рд╣реЗрддреБought to be invariably accompanied by the рд╕рд╛рдзреНрдп. As in the true inference **рдкрд░реНрд╡рддреЛ рд╡рд╣реНрдирд┐рдорд╛рдиреН рдзреВрдорд╛рддреН, рдзреВрдотАФ**the рд╣реЗрддреБ is invariably accompanied by **рд╡рд╣реНрдирд┐тАФ**the рд╕рд╛рдзреНрдп. Hence the рд╣реЗрддреБ is called the рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдкреНрдп and the рд╕рд╛рдзреНрдпthe рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдкрдХ.

The (logical) Reason (рд╕рд╛рдзрди) is a mark possessed of the three qualifications рдкрдХреНрд╖рдзрд░реНрдорддреНрд╡, рдЕрдиреНрд╡рдпрд┐рддреНрд╡ and рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХрд┐рддреНрд╡.

The mark must have (1) рдкрдХреНрд╖рдзрд░реНрдорддреНрд╡, i. e. must be an attribute of the рдкрдХреНрд╖, i. e. must be connected with the рдкрдХреНрд╖. It must have (2) рдЕрдиреНрд╡рд┐рдпрддреНрд╡, i. e. **рд╕рдкрдХреНрд╖рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐рддреНрд╡,**i. e. must be found to exist in similar instances, i. e. in those instances where the рд╕рд╛рдзреНрдпis ascertained to exist. As ‘smoke’ is рд╕рдкрдХреНрд╖рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐, because it is found to exist in such instances as a ‘kitchen-house etc." where ‘fire’ is ascertained to exist.

Again, the mark must have ( 3 ) рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХрд┐рддреНрд╡ i. e. рд╡рд┐рдкрдХреНрд╖рд╛рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐рддреНрд╡, i. e. must not be found to exist in dissimilar instances, i. e. in those instances where the рд╕рд╛рдзреНрдпis ascertained not to exist. As ‘smoke’ is рд╡рд┐рдкрдХреНрд╖рд╛рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐, because it is not found to exist in such instances as a ’lake etc.’ where ‘fire’ is ascertained not to exist.

The Conclusion (рд╕рд╛рдзреНрдп) is a┬╣54necessary connection of the рд╕рд╛рдзреН.(which invariably accompanies the рд╣реЗрддреБ), with the рдкрдХреНрд╖.

A poetical representation of both the Reason and the Conclusion, of the character described above, is Inference.

The figure is instanced in рдпрддреНрд░реИрддрд╛: etc. verse 127. Here, in the first half, the Reason, and in the second half, the Conclusion, are stated. The argument may be put in the following form:тАФ

The conclusion:тАФ

These women (рдкрдХреНрд╖) have Cupid always running before them, furnished with a bent bow etc. (рд╕рд╛рдзреНрдп).

The Reason:тАФBecause they direct arrows in the form of the movements of their eye-brows towards a young man. (рд╣реЗрддреБ)тАФa fact which is invariably accompanied by another fact i. e. ‘Cupid always running before them.’ (рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдкреНрддрд┐)

If it be said: the Conclusion may also be stated first, a in рдордзреБ рддрд┐рд╖реНрдарддрд┐etc., just as it is stated afterwards, in the present verse. Why has the Inference been treated generally instead of being described particularly55┬▓, i. e. as possessed of two kinds. Besides56┬│, the reversed order of the Reason and the Conclusion should also be admitted (as it has been admitted by Rudra╚Ыa) as a figure; as the reversed order of Cause and Effect has been recognized as a figure (i. e. Hyperbole).

We reply that in Hyperbole where the order of cause and effect is reversed, there is a strikingness consisting in the apprehension of the instantaneous production of the effect by the cause, owing to the reversed position of cause

and effect. There is no such strikingness (however), in the inversion of the sequence of the Reason and the Conclusion. Therefore, Inference is not (here specifically) declared as (possessed) of this kind. The termination рд▓реНрдпреБрдЯреНofрдЕрдиреБрдорд╛рдиdenotes an act, not an instrument, of inference. Thus, an inference, the result of an inferential process, is the figure here.

When such words as рдордиреНрдпреЗ, рд╢рдВрдХреЗ, etc. occur in a verse, Inference is Expressed; these words intimate an inference only when a Reason and a Conclusion are stated. They intimate Poetical Probability, when simply the reason such as resemblance etc. is present. When such words as рд╡рдХреНрддрд┐etc. occur, Inference is indicated. When both the kinds of words are not expressed and the inference is suggested by the statement of a Reason and a Conclusion, Inference is suggested.

36. THE SIGNIFICANT (рдкрд░рд┐рдХрд░).

K─Б. xxxii. a b:- A description with significant epithets is (termed) the significant.

** **‘Significant’ means ‘suggestive.’ The description is, ofcourse, of the subject, instanced in рдорд╣реМрдЬрд╕реЛetc. verse 128.

Here, the epithetsрдорд╣реМрдЬрд╕реНрддреНрд╡etc.suggest that the warriors are irresistible etc.

If it be said: A ‘Non-Significant’ word has been declared to be a fault, i. e. рдЕрдкреБрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рд░реНрдерддреНрд╡; from this, it, of course, follows that an epithet must be significant. Thus, the Significant is simply the absence of the fault ‘рдЕрдкреБрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рд░реНрдерддреНрд╡’ ‘and does not deserve to be a distinct figure. The Traditionalists reply;тАФAlthough a non-significant epithet being declared to be a fault, its rejection leads to the (tacit) admission that an epithet must be significant, still, the employment of many (significant) epithets in connection with one and the same (subject as in the present verse) has a (peculiar) strikingness which is known

to all, and is not simply the absence of a fault. Hence, the Significant has been ranked in (the class of) figures. According to these men, the plural рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдгреИрдГis significant as showing that a plurality of significant epithets is required for this figure.

On this Prad─лpa:тАФThe figure occurs even when only one significant epithet is employed; as inрдЕрдпрд┐ рд▓рд╛рд╡рдгреНрдпetc. Absence of the fault ‘рдЕрдкреБрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рд░реНрде’ is possible not only when a significant epithet is employed, but even when no epithet is employed. Thus, the fact that an epithet is not рдЕрдкреБрд╖реНрдЯdoes not necessarily imply that it is significant. Although┬╣57in some cases, as in the present verse, absence of the fault рдЕрдкреБрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рд░реНрдерддреНрд╡ and the presence of the figure рдкрд░рд┐рдХрд░ may both be found together, still, the grounds why the fault is absent and the figure is present are distinct. The fault is absent, because diminution of (the) pleasure (derived from a verse), which constitutes the very essence of a fault, is here absent. The figure is present, because it invests the verse with a peculiar charm. The peculiar charm or strikingness of a significant epithet is experienced by all and cannot, therefore, be denied; as in рд╢реБрджреНрдзреЗ рд╕рджреНрдордирд┐58┬▓etc.

The author┬│59of Nidar┼Ыana says that up to this point, the Kavyaprak─Б┼Ыa is composed by Mamma╚Ыa; what follows afterwards is the composition of another man named Alla╚Ыa.

37. THE DISSEMBLER (рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЬреЛрдХреНрддрд┐)

K─Б. xxxii. c d:тАФThe artful concealment of the nature of an object, though discovered, is (termed ) the Dissembler.

** When, the nature of an object which, even though hidden is discovered somehow or other, is concealed under some pretence, that is рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЬреЛрдХреНрддрд┐.

This is not рдЕрдкрд╣реНрдиреБрддрд┐for, resemblance between both theрдкреНрд░рдХреГрддand theрдЕрдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд, which is present inрдЕрдкрд╣реНрдиреБрддрд┐is here impossible. Although resemblance is present here,still, it60┬╣ is between рд░рддрд┐ and рд╢реИрддреНрдп of the Him─Бlaya, which are both рдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд here.

If it be said: In рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЬреЛрдХреНрддрд┐, there is the concealment of a thing that is first hidden and is afterwards discovered; thus, inasmuch as the circumstances only of a thing concealed are here different, рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЬреЛрдХреНрддрд┐ is different from рдЕрдкрд╣реНрдиреБрддрд┐. We reply that even in these cases (where the circumstances are different), there will be nothing but рдЕрдкрд╣реНрдиреБрддрд┐if resemblance is possible in them, as in рд╕реАрддреНрдХрд╛рд░┬▓61etc.

If it again be said that where resemblance is stated for the sake of concealment, there is рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЬреЛрдХреНрддрд┐; but where concealment is stated for the sake of resemblance, there is рдЕрдкрд╣реНрдиреБрддрд┐; we reply that in both the cases, there is nothing but рдЕрдкрд╣реНрдиреБрддрд┐, because in both62┬│, there is resemblance; whether concealment is predominant or subordinate is not the point.

The same is the opinion63┬╣of the followers of Udbha╚Ыa and others.

According to Udyota, in рдЕрдкрд╣реНрдиреБрддрд┐, the affirmation of the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рдиis accompanied by the denial of the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп. Here, nothing is denied, but something is made known as brought about by some other cause.

The figure is instanced inрд╢реИрд▓реЗрдиреНрджреНрд░ etc. verse 129. Here, horripilation (рдкреБрд▓рдХ) and tremor (рд╡реЗрдкрдереБ) manifest themselves (on the body of S’iva) as the Involuntary Indication (of his love for P─Бrvat─л); their natures, however, are concealed by their being represented as proceeding from cold.

Prad─лpa remarks64┬▓, however, that ‘horripilation’ and ’tremor’ are not first hidden, so that they cannot be said to be afterwards discovered. Thus, the example would be inconsistent with the Vс╣Ыtti of Mamma╚Ыa explaining the definition of рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЬреЛрдХреНрддрд┐. He, therefore, says that here the love for P─Бrvati that was hidden is discovered by the Involuntary Indications of love, i. e. horripilation and tremor; it is then concealed under the pretence that these Indications proceed from cold.

38. SPECIAL MENTION (рдкрд░рд┐рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрд╛)

K─Б. xxxiii. :тАФWhen the mention of something, with or without a query, results in the exclusion of something else, similar to it, it is considered to be Special Mention.

** **If it be said :тАФHow can the mention of one thing result in the rejection of another? It is replied that when a thing, although known from another means of proof, is yet made the subject of a special assertion, it terminates in the exclusion, of

another thing, similar to it, there being no other purpose which it can serve. Thus the mention of such a thing is рдкрд░рд┐рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрд╛.

The words рдкреГрд╖реНрдЯрдордкреГрд╖реНрдЯрдВ рдЪ give us the divisions of **рдкрд░рд┐рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрд╛тАФThe (Special) Mention here is sometimes (a) seen to be preceded by a question, and sometimes, (b) seen to be otherwise, i. e. not preceded by a question, Thus, we get two divisions. Similarly, in both these places, the thing to be excluded is (sometimes) (1) Implied and (sometimes) (2) Expressed. Thus, we get four divisions.

The word рдкрд░рд┐рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрд╛┬╣65literally means тАЩknowledge (рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрд╛) of exclusion (рдкрд░рд┐).

Examples in order :тАФ

(a) 1 is instanced in рдХрд┐рдорд╛рд╕реЗрд╡реНрдпрдВetc. verse 130.Here,

the fact that the banks of the Ganges should be resorted to, is well-known. It is made the subject of a special assertion here, for the purpose of intimating that the banks of other rivers should not be resorted to. ‘The vicinity of another river than the Ganges etc.’ are thus the things to be excluded; and they are here implied.

(a) 2 is instanced in рдХрд┐рдВ рднреВрд╖рдгрдВetc. verse 131. Here, the things to be denied are ’the jewel’s being an ornament etc.;’ and they are here expressed.

(b) 1 is instanced inрдХреМрдЯрд┐рд▓реНрдпрдВ etc. verse 132. Here, what are denied are ’the crookedness residing in any thing other than a woman’s hair, etc.’

(6) 2 is instanced in рднрдХреНрддрд┐рд░реНрднрд╡реЗetc. verse 133. Here, the things to be denied are ‘devotion’s being entertained for wealth, etc.’

The figure occurs, only when the exclusion of another is imagined by the poet. Thus, рдкрдЮреНрдЪ рдкрдЮреНрдЪрдирдЦрд╛ рднрдХреНрд╖реНрдпрд╛рдГ which is an example of our is not an example of this figure.

рдкрд░рд┐рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрд╛┬╣66is a kind of рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐ which, according to the P┼лrvaM─лm─Бс╣Бsakas, means ‘Restriction to one in exclusion of the other, out of two things both of which are possible.’ As the sentence, “The five five-nailed animals should be eaten,’ lays down an injunction that a man should eat five-nailed animals only, in exclusion of those that are not five-nailed, although by his natural appetite he is impelled to the eating of both.

рдирд┐рдпрдоis another kind of рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐which means ‘Restriction to one in exclusion of the other, out of two things either of which is possible.’ As the sentenceрд╕рдореЗ рджреЗрд╢реЗ рдпрдЬреЗрддlays down an injunction that a man should sacrifice in an even place, when either alternative, i. e. sacrificing in an even place or sacrificing in an odd place was possible to him.

Inasmuch as, however, in both these kinds of рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐, рдЗрддрд░рд╡реНрдпрд╛рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐ is the same, the definition of the figure рдкрд░рд┐рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрд╛applies to both. Thus67┬▓, рдкрд░рд┐рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрд╛ and рдирд┐рдпрдо are regarded as identical in the Science of Rhetoric, in disregard of the minor distinctions of рдкрд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдХрдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддрд┐ and рдпреБрдЧрдкрддреНрдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддрд┐ between them. The figure is, sometimes, found as based upon a Paronomasia also; as in рдЪрд┐рддреНрд░реЗрд╖реБ рд╡рд░реНрдгрд╕рдВрдХрд░рд╛рдГetc., which means : ’the mixture of рд╡рд░реНрдг(colours) was to be found in paintings (but the mixture of рд╡рд░реНрдг(castes) was not to be found among the subjects etc.).’

39. THE GARLAND OF CAUSES (рдХрд╛рд░рдгрдорд╛рд▓рд╛)

K─Б. xxxiv. a b c:- When each preceding object is (spoken of as) the cause of each succeeding object, it is (termed) the Garland of causes.

** The word inрдпрдерд╛**in рдпрдереЛрддреНрддрд░denotes ‘repetition.’ Thus рдпрдереЛрддреНрддрд░(means) each succeeding (object).

The figure occurs, also when something mentioned afterwards is successively spoken of as the cause of what precedes; as in рднрд╡рдиреНрддрд┐ рдирд░рдХрд╛рдГ etc68┬╣.In рдорд╛рд▓рд╛рджреАрдкрдХ┬▓, although each preceding thing is the cause of the suceeding, still, all the things are connected with one action. Here, they are not so connected. Thus the two figures are distinct.

The figure is instanced in рдЬрд┐рддреЗрдиреНрджреНрд░рд┐рдпрддреНрд╡рдВetc. verse 134. Here рдЬрд┐рддреЗрдиреНрджреНрд░рд┐рдпрддреНрд╡рдВetc. are successively spoken of as the causes ofрд╡рд┐рдирдпetc. The verse is not a good example of this figure; for it is open to the fault of **рднрдЧреНрдирдкреНрд░рдХреНрд░рдорддреНрд╡.**When it is learnt that рдЬрд┐рд░реНрддреЗрджреНрд░рд┐рдпрддреНрд╡ is the cause of рд╡рд┐рдирдп, an expectation arises that рд╡рд┐рдирдпtoo must be the cause of something else. Now, this expectation is, no doubt, fulfilled by what is said in the second line. of the verse. But, inasmuch as it is there fulfilled indirectly, i. e. by saying рдЧреБрдгрдкреНрд░рдХрд░реНрд╖реЛ рд╡рд┐рдирдпрд╛рджрд╛рд╡рд╛рдкреНрдпрддреЗ, instead of directly, i. e. by saying рд╡рд┐рдирдпреЛ рдЧреБрдгрдкреНрд░рдХрд░реНрд╖рд╕реНрдп рдХрд╛рд░рдгрдореН, uniformity, is said to be violated here.

The figure (called) ’the Cause’ which Udbhaс╣нa has (defined) as “that which occurs when a cause is represented as identical with an effect” has not been here defined by us, although we are treating here of such figures as are based upon the relation of cause and effect; for, this (рд╣реЗрддреБ) whose form isрдЖрдпреБрд░реНрдШреГрддрдореН** etc. does not at all deserve to be (recognised as) a figure, inasmuch as no (particular) beauty is (apprehended) from the employment of (a word denoting) an effect to express a cause, as (the employment of the word рдЖрдпреБрдГto denote рдШреГрддрдореН) in the expression рдЖрдпреБрд░реНрдШреГрддрдореН.

If it be said:тАФThe verse 135 рдЕрд╡рд┐рд░рд▓etc. is an example of ’the Cause.’ Now, if this figure be not admitted, there would be no figure in this verse, and thus the verse would cease to be a poem, inasmuch as it is wanting in a figure. But this would be inconsistent with the recognition of it as a poem by the ancient rhetoricians such as рднрд╛рдорд╣etc. We reply that the verse рдЕрд╡рд┐рд░рд▓etc. was declared (by them) to be a poem, in virtue of its possessing an Alliteration of soft letters (and of two other figures, i. e. рдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рдпреЛрдХреНрдд and рдЕрддрд┐рд╢рдпреЛрдХреНрдд ) only, and not because they thought that it contained the figureрд╣реЗрддреБ.

** Thus,рд╣реЗрддреБ is but (another name of)рдХрд╛рд╡реНрдпрд▓рд┐рдВрдЧitself, which has been described before.

S─Бrabodhin─л┬╣69says, however, that a distinct beauty is apprehended from the verse рдЕрд╡рд┐рд░рд▓etc., and that the opinion of Udbhaс╣нa who admitsрд╣реЗрддреБ as a distinct figure, is thus right70┬▓.

40. THE RECIPROCAL (рдЕрдиреНрдпреЛрдиреНрдп)

K─Б. xxxiv. d, xxxv a:тАФWhen two things produce. each other through an act, is (termed) the Reciprocal.

** **The Vс╣Ыtti here is simple.

The reciprocal relation of cause and effect is not possible between two things; for, two things cannot exist before and after themselves. Therefore, the words ’through an act’ are employed. “Through an act’ means ’through the production of identical acts.’ An object existing┬│71without beauty, is as though it does not exist. Thus, two objects are metaphorically said to produce each other, when, really speaking, they produce identical acts causing each other’s excellence.

The figure is instanced in рд╣рдВрд╕рд╛рдирд╛рдВetc. verse 136. Here the ’lake’ is the cause of the ‘swans possessed of a peculiar beauty,’ and the ‘swans’ are the cause of the ’lake possessed of a peculiar beauty.’ Thus, here, both (the lake and the swans are said to) produce each other, through their effecting the heightenment of each other’s beauty. The strikingness consists in the apprehension of the mutual obligation of two things through mutual acts.

41. THE REPLY (рдЙрддреНрддрд░)

K─Б. xxxv. bcd, xxxvi. ab:тАФThe Reply is (a) when a question is inferred from the mere hearing of an answer; or (b) when, to a number of questions, a number of incomprehensible answers is given.

** **When, from the mere getting of an answer the preceding (interrogative) sentence is inferred, that is one (kind of) Reply.

The first kind is instanced in рд╡рд╛рдгрд┐рдЕрдЕetc. verse 137. Here, from the answer given in this sentence (i. e. verse), the speech of the purchaser to the effect:тАФ‘Iwant elephants’ teeth and tiger-skins, sell them to me,’ is inferred.

  • *The word рдкреНрд░рд╢реНрдиin the K─Бrik─Б means a ‘preceding sentence’ simply. Thus, although here no question is inferred, the verse is still regarded as an example of this figure; or, we may suppose that what is here inferred is a question, namely, ‘Have you got elephants’ teeth and tiger-skins?’

This is not рдХрд╛рд╡реНрдпрд▓рд┐рдВрдЧ, although the answer is here the cause of the question; for, the (figure) Reply is not identical with that (figure, i. e. рдХрд╛рд╡реНрдпрд▓рд┐рдВрдЧ). A reply is not indeed an efficient cause (рдХрд╛рд░рдХрд╣реЗрддреБ) of a question, but simply a mark (рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдкрдХрд╣реЗрддреБ) indicating the presence of it.

Nor is this рдЕрдиреБрдорд╛рдиalso, although it, too, contains an indicatory mark; for here theрд╕рд╛рдзреНрдпand theрд╕рд╛рдзрди are not stated as

┬╣.

рди рдЪреЗрджрдордиреБрдорд╛рдирдореНред рд╕рд╛рдзреНрдпрд╕рд╛рдзрдирдпреЛрд░реНрджреНрд╡рдпреЛрд░реНрдирд┐рд░реНрджреЗрд╢реЗ рдПрд╡ рддрд╕реНрдп рдЕрдВрдЧреАрдХрд╛рд░рд╛рддреНред S. D.

residing in one and the same рдкрдХреНрд╖, as they are in рдЕрдиреБрдорд╛рди. The**рд╕рд╛рдзреНрдптАФthe questionтАФbelongs to the purchaser, and theрд╕рд╛рдзрдитАФ**the answerтАФbelongs to the old hunter. Or, according to S. D., in an Inference, the рд╕рд╛рдзреНрдп and the рд╕рд╛рдзрди are both mentioned; but here the query is not mentioned.

Thus, the Reply deserves to be a distinct figure. AlthoughрдХрд╛рд╡реНрдпрд▓рд┐рдВрдЧis possible here, inasmuch as ‘staying of the daughter-in-law in the house’ may serve as an efficient cause of the absence of ’elephants’ teeth etc.,’ still, as strikingness consists in the inference of a question, it is this inference that constitutes the figure, although рдХрд╛рд╡реНрдпрд▓рд┐рдВрдЧ, no doubt, exists in the verse.

When, after a question (is asked), there is an answer which is incomprehensible, being beyond the reach of any other means of proof, that is another (kind of) Reply.

  • The wordрдЕрд╕рдХреГрддреНhas been employed* to show that the questions and the answers must be many in this variety; for, no strikingness is apprehended from the statement of a single question and a single answer. In the first kind of Reply where the question is inferred, even a single answer is striking.

рдЕрд╕рдВрднрд╛рд╡реНрдпmeans, according to some, ’extra-ordinary,’ but according to Pradipa, ’not known ordinarily, being beyond the reach of any other means of proof.’ In рдкреНрд░рд╢реНрдирдкрд░рд┐рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрд╛, the answer, being well-known, aims at but the exclusion of another, there being no other purpose in its being given. Here, the answer stated in the verse, not being ordinarily known, rests but with itself i. e. aims at bringing out its own incomprehensibility. This is the distinction between the two (figures). The word┬╣72рд▓реЛрдХрд╛рддрд┐рдХреНрд░рд╛рдиреНрддрд┐рдЧреЛрдЪрд░in the Vс╣Ыtti means: ‘beyond the

reach of any other means of proof,’ and not ‘remarkably striking.’ For, if we accept the latter meaning, this figure would not be distinguished fromрдкреНрд░рд╢реНрдирдкрд░рд┐рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрд╛where also an answer is remarkably striking.

The second kind is instanced inрдХрд╛ рд╡рд┐рд╕рдорд╛etc. verse 138. Here, ’the capriciousness of fate etc.,’ which are not known. ordinarily, are brought out by the answers given in the verse.

According to the Moderns, the figure occurs, even if there is a single question and a single answer, both of them or even either of them being signficant; as in рдХрд┐рдорд┐рддрд┐etc.

The figure occurs even when the question is but one and the answers many; as in рдХрд┐рдВ рд╕реНрд╡рд░реНрдЧрд╛рджреНetc73┬╣.

So also it occurs when the same words express both a question and an answer (owing to Parcnomasia ); as in рдХреЗрджрд╛рд░ etc74┬▓.

So also it occurs when two questions have only one answer as in рдХреЗ рдЦреЗрдЯрд╛рдГ etc75┬│.

42. THE SUBTLE (рд╕реВрдХреНрд╖реНрдо)

K─Б. xxxvi. cd, xxxvvii. ab:тАФWhen a circumstance, even though delicate, is guessed some-how, and is intimated to another by some mark (indicative of it), it is termed the Subtle.

** SomehowтАФ From some (1) appearance or (2) gesture.

DelicateтАФ That can be known (only) by a man of sharp understanding.

**рдЖрдХрд╛рд░=**A change of expression etc.

The first kind is instanced in рд╡рдХреНрддреНрд░рд╕реНрдпрдиреНрджрд┐etc., verse 139. Here, the masculine action of a woman, guessed by looking at (her) appearance in the form of the ‘mixing of the saffron with the drops of perspiration on the neck’ is cleverly intimated to her and to other friends of hers by some one of her female friends, by drawing (on her hand the figure of) a sword. A sword is the characteristic mark of manliness; for men alone hold swords in their hands, they being fit persons to hold them. Here, although there is рдЕрдиреБрдорд╛рди, since theрд╕рд╛рдзрди i. e. ┬╣рдХрдгреНрдардХреБрдВрдХреБрдорднреЗрдж76 and the рд╕рд╛рдзреНрдп, i. e. рдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╛рдпрд┐рдд are both stated as connected with one and the same рдкрдХреНрд╖, i. e. the woman, still, it is subordinate to the Subtle; for, strikingness consists here in the clever bringing out of a very delicate circumstance.

**рдЗрдВрдЧрд┐рддтАФ**some particular motion of the limbs of the body.

The second kind is instanced in рд╕рдВрдХреЗрдд etc. verse 140. Here, the time of assignation, which (the lover) inquired for, is guessed from the gesture of his anxious look only, and is intimated (to him) by some (woman) sportively, by the closing of the lotus in her handтАФ(a mark) indicating the time of night

43. THE CLIMAX (рд╕рд╛рд░).

K─Б. xxxvii. cd:- An excellence (rising) successively (and) culminating in the end is (termed) the Climax.

** **The climax is an excellence whose utmost limit is (reached in) the last part of a prose or poetical passage. In other words, it is that where the last part is most excellent; for it is there only that the excellence rests after gradually rising in each preceding part.

The figure is instanced in рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдпреЗ рд╕рд╛рд░рдВetc. verse 141. Here each succeeding thing ’earth etc.’ rises, gradually in excellence, until the last thing, i. e. ‘a fair woman,’ is declared to be the most excellent of all.

This is not рдкрд░рд┐рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрд╛┬╣77because strikingness here consists not in the exclusion of another, but in the gradual rise of excellence.

In the above example, the rise is of the excellence of an object of a superior quality. The figure occurs also where the rise is of the excellence of an object of an inferior quality; as in рддреГрдгрд╛рд▓реНрд▓рдШреБрддрд░рдГetc.

44. DISCONNECTION (рдЕрд╕рдВрдЧрддрд┐).

K─Б. xxxviii:- When two things related to each other as cause and effect are represented as simultaneously residing in two totally different places, it is (termed) Disconnection.

In this (world), an effect such as, ‘smoke etc.’ is observed to be produced at the very place where the cause (such as ‘fire etc.) is present. Where, however, things, although related to each other as cause and effect, are represented as simultaneously residing in two totally different places, owing to the peculiar excellence (of the cause), that is area; (so called) because, in it the mutual association of cause and effect which is natural to them (or well-known) is abandoned.

Here, the wordрдЕрддреНрдпрдиреНрддalthough mentioned separatelyfromрднрд┐рдиреНрдирджреЗрд╢рддрдпрд╛ is yet connected (as an adjective) with рднрд┐рдиреНрди, and shows that the places must be quite apart from each other. Thus, the definition does not extend to such an example┬▓78asрджрд╖реНрдЯреЛ рднреБрдЬрдВрдЧреЗрди etc. where the eyes and feet are not completely different from each other in point of locality, they residing in one and the same body.

рдпреБрдЧрдкрддреНis not a part of the definition, but a description simply; thus, the figure occurs in рдЙрджреНрднрд┐рдиреНрдирдорд╛рддреНрд░реЗetc. also, although simultaneity of time is there absent. The representation of cause and effect as residing in two different places is due to the fact that the causes here have a peculiar excellence and are thus different from ordinary causes.

In a Hyperbole79┬╣, there is a reversion of the sequence of cause and effect; here, a local difference between them.

Its instance is рдЬрд╕реНрд╕реЗ рдЕetc. verse 142. Here, ‘biting of the cheek by the teeth’-the cause, and ‘pain’- the effect, are represented as residing in the ‘wife’ and the ‘rival wives’ of the Hero, in order to bring out the particular fact that the ‘biting’ gives acute pain to the rival wives of the Hero. Here80, identification between bodily and mental pain is at the bottom of this figure. In this verse, the use of a synonymрдХреНрд╖рдд, when the same word i. e.рд╡реНрд░рдгought to be employed, makes the verse open to the fault of рднрдЧреНрдирдкреНрд░рдХреНрд░рдорддреНрд╡.

If it be said:тАФThe figure is nothing but Contradiction. For, just┬│81as the residence in one placeрд╕рд╛рдорд╛рдирд╛рдзрд┐рдХрд░рдгреНрдпof two things which reside in two different places makes the two things contradictory of each other; so the residence in two different places (рд╡реИрдпрдзрд┐рдХрд░рдгреНрдп) of cause and effect which reside in one place makes them contradictory of each other. We reply- No. For, рд╡реИрдпрдзрд┐рдХрд░рдгреНрдпis Disconnection itself. Now Disconnection is not Contradiction. It simply indicates that there is a contradiction between two things; for, it is on account of thisрд╡реИрдпрдзрд┐рдХрд░рдгреНрдп that the two things appear to be

contradictory of each other. Thus, Disconnection is quite distinct from Contradiction.

If it again be saidтАФAlthough┬╣82the two figures are distinct, still, inasmuch as no strikingness is here apparent, unless contradiction is brought out, let this contradiction itself be the figure, and not Dis-connection which simply indicates the presence of that contradiction. Nor should it be said that Contradiction is where there is рд╕рд╛рдорд╛рдирд╛рдзрд┐рдХрд░рдгреНрдпbetween two contradictory things, and not when there is рд╡реИрдпрдзрд┐рдХрд░рдгреНрдпbetween them; because the definition of Contradiction is very general and does not speak of this restriction.

We reply:тАФNo. For, although the definition is given generally, still its scope becomes restricted in virtue of a rule that a general proposition covers all the ground except that covered by its exception. Now, Disconnection is as exception to the general figure Contradiction. Disconnection occurs where two things residing in one place are represented as residing in two different places. This is the ground which it occupies. Therefore, the general figure, i. e. Contradiction, must leave this ground and occupy the remaining ground. It thus occurs where two things residing in two different places are represented as residing in one and the same place. Hence, examples of Contradiction have been given by us before, in accordance with this restriction of province made here.

Vс╣Ыtti:тАФ This is an exception to Contradiction, not Contradiction (itself). The opposition that appears here is aue to the residence in two different places of two things which reside in one place; whilst, in Contradiction, the opposition is due to the residence in one place of two things which reside in two different places. Although (this is) not (actually) mentione

in the definition of Contradiction, still, this follows in virtue of the fact that a general proposition establishes itself (i. e. occupies its ground) after leaving the ground covered by its exception. Hence, (Contradiction83)┬╣ has been exemplified by us before, with a regard to this┬▓84very restriction of its scope laid down here.

45. THE FACILITATION. (рд╕рдорд╛рдзрд┐)

K─Б. xxxix. ab:тАФWhen (the accomplishment of) an act becomes easy through the operation of another cause, it is (termed) the Facilitation.

  • When an act, which is begun, is accomplished without difficulty by an agent, being assisted by another (accidental) means, that is named* рд╕рдорд╛рдзрд┐.

The term рд╕рдорд╛рдзрд┐etymologically means ‘Accomplishing┬│85a thing) well, i. e. easily.’

The figure is instanced in рдорд╛рдирдорд╕реНрдпрд╛рдГetc. verse 143. Here, the effect, i. e. ‘quelling of anger’ which is being produced by the cause, i. e. ‘falling at her feet,’ is easily accomplished by the sudden operation of another cause, i. e. ’the roaring of the clouds.’

This figure occurs, only when one cause is intended as principal and the other auxiliary; whilst, рд╕рдореБрдЪреНрдЪрдпoccurs when both the causes are intended as principal.

46. THE EQUAL (рд╕рдо).

K─Б. xxxix. cd:тАФIf a union is (found) somewhere (that may be) accepted (by all) as fit, it is (termed) the Equal.

** **Union is either Conjuction etc., or the relation of cause and effect. Thus, the figure рд╕рдо(occurs) when there is an

ascertainment of a connection as fit, expressed in the form:тАФThis (union) of these two things is commendable. (The figure occurs) when a (fit) union exists between (1) two superior things or (2) two inferior things; but not when it exists between one superior and another inferior thing. In рд╕рдореБрдЪреНрдЪрдп, there is a union of two good or bad causes; here, union is declared as fit even between two good or two bad things that are not causes.

The first variety is instanced in рдзрд╛рддреБрдГ рд╢рд┐рд▓реНрдкрд╛ etc. verse 144. Here the union of the ‘deer-eyed lady’ and the ‘king’тАФtwo superior thingsтАФis declared as fit.

The second variety is instanced in рдЪрд┐рддреНрд░рдВetc. verse 145. Here the union of a ‘Nimba tree’ and ‘crow’тАФtwo inferior thingsтАФis declared as fit.

Fitness of the connection called ’the relation of cause and effect’ occurs when a cause produces an effect having qualities similar to those of itself; as in рдорддреНрд░рд╛рд░реНрдкрд┐рддetc.

The figure occurs, also when a thing produces a quality possessed by others, in virtue of its association with them; as in рд╡рдбрд╡рд╛рдирд▓ etc.

Sometimes, it occurs when the desired object is obtained (verbally and not really) from that source which is resorted to for the accomplishment of that object; as an рдЙрдЪреНрдЪреИрд░реНрдЧрдЬреИрдГ etc.

47. THE UNEQUAL (рд╡рд┐рд╖рдо).

K─Б. xl. & xli - (1) When, in one place, connection is not found to be possible, owing to extreme incongruity; (2) when the endeavour of an agent becomes not only fruitless, but, on the contrary, brings an evil result to him; and (3) and (4) when the Qualities and Actions of a cause are respectively opposed to the Qualities and Actions of an effect; that is deemed the Unequal.

(1) When a connection between two (things) is apprehended as but impossible, owing to extreme incongruity (between them); (2) when an agent who has begun to do some (act), sometimes, not only does not obtain the desired fruit of that (act), owing to that act being destroyed, (or, owing to the intervention of some powerful obstacle), but, on the contrary, obtains even an undesirable result (which is quite) unlooked for; similarly, (3) and (4) when although (as a rule) an effect resembles a cause in its nature, the Qualities and Actions of them are still opposed to each other; that is the four-fold Unequal, the opposite of the Equal.

The first kind is instanced in рд╢рд┐рд░реАрд╖рд╛рджрдкрд┐etc. verse 146. Here, incongruity consists in the nature and qualities of Cupid being opposed to the nature and qualities of the woman under discourse. The impropriety of the union is here suggested.

The second kind is instanced in рд╕рд┐рдВрд╣рд┐рдХрд╛etc. verse 147. Here, not only is self-protection not secured, but, on the contrary, the disaster of being devoured by R─Бhu is met with.

The third kind is instanced in рд╕рджреНрдпрдГрдХрд░etc. verse 148, Here, we have ‘white fame’ arising from the ‘dark sword,’ figured as the cause, in opposition to the general rule that the qualities of the effect conform to those of the cause. Here, there is incongruity between ‘blackness’ and ‘whiteness’ belonging to the cause and the effect, respectively.

The fourth kind is instanced in рдЖрдирдиреНрджetc. verse 149. Here, the Action of ‘delighting’ belonging to ’the woman’тАФthe cause, is opposed to the Action of ‘tormenting the body’ belonging to ’the state of separation’- the effect.

The particleрдЪ in the second line of the fortieth K─Бrik─Б shows that the second variety of рд╡рд┐рд╖рдоoccurs not only (A) when there are both non-attainment of the desired object and the attainment of an undesired object, but also (B) when

there is mere non-attainment of the desired object, or (C) when there is mere attainment of an undesired object.

The division A has been instanced in рд╕рд┐рдВрд╣рд┐рдХрд╛etc. verse 147.

B may be instanced in **рдкреНрд░рднрд╛рдд┬╣86**etc. and C may be instanced in **рдкрджреНрдорд╛рддрдкрддреНрд░┬▓87**etc.

The K─Бrik─Бs do not exhaust the divisions of the figure; thus, other divisions of Inequality which may be generally defined as ‘Absence of compatibility between two things related to each other any how,’ are also possible. Thus, for instance, Inequality between two things related to each other as part and whole may be instanced in рд╡рд┐рдкреБрд▓реЗрдиetc. verse 150. Here, ‘sleeping on the ocean’ and ‘devouring all the worlds with the ocean’ are incompatible things and constitute one рд╡рд┐рд╖рдо. Similarly, that the whole Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa whose belly is able to drink all the worlds should be drunk by a part of a woman’s body, i. e. the eyes, is also incompatible. This is another рд╡рд┐рд╖рдо.

Although рдкрд╛рди(drinking) is different fromрдкрд╛рди (looking intently), still, the two s are here fancied as identical with each other. Thus, this verse becomes an example of the figure in question.

In this variety, the relation is that of part and whole, whilst, in the first, the relation is that of opposition. This is the distinction between the two varieties. S. D. however puts this example under the first variety.

Thus, in this and other (examples) also, Inequality should be understood (as possible) in this and various other ways, according to the particular circumstances of each case.

In Contradiction, what is striking is the residence in one place of two things residing in two different places; in Disconnection, the residence in two different places of the cause and the effect residing in one place; but here, the connection of dissimilar Qualities and Actions belongling to the cause and the effect.

48. THE EXCEEDING (рдЕрдзрд┐рдХ).

K─Б. xlii :тАФWhen the abode and the abider though smaller, are yet represented as greater than the abider and the abode, which are (themselves) great, that is (termed) the Exceeding.

** The abider is the thing contained, the abode is its container. When the container and the contained, although smaller, are yet represented as greater than the contained and the container, respectively; although these (latter) are intended as (themselves) great, with a view to intimate the excellence of the object under description, that is рдЕрдзрд┐рдХwhichis thus two-fold.

  • Examples in order :тАФ*

  • *The first kind is instanced in рдЕрд╣реЛetc. verse 151. Here, ‘heap of fame’тАФthe contained, is intended as great, being described as incapable of being contained.

The triad of worlds’, which is smaller, is represented as greater than ’the heap of fame’, inasmuch as the former is described as containing the latter, in order to bring out the excellence of the latter (i. e. the heap of fame), which is the object under description.

The second kind is instanced in рдпреБрдЧрд╛рдиреНрддetc. verse 152. Here, the containerтАФthe body of рдХреГрд╖реНрдг, is intended as great, being described as the substratum of the whole world. ‘The joy at the arrival of N─Бrada,’ which is smaller, is yet represented as greater than ’the body of Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa,’ inasmuch as the former is described as incapable of being contained by

the latter, in order to intimate the excellence of the latter (i. e. the body of Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa), which is the object under description.

49. THE RIVALRY (рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдиреАрдХ).

K─Б. xliiiтАФWhen somebody unable to avenge himself on his enemy is represented as doing harm to one belonging to him, with a view to praise that very enemy, that is called the Rivalry.

** When some one, unable to directly punish an enemy, although he has done him an injury, (is represented as) punishing (another who is) dependent on him, with a view to prove that very enemy’s superiority, that is termed рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдиреАрдХ*;* so called because, it is like the ally of an army. Just as one attacks, instead of an army directly*, another who is an ally (1) of that (army) foolishly, or (88according to Pradipa’s reading88)88┬╣88[]88*secretly, for fear of being killed by that army; so here also, while an enemy is to be conquered, another (person) connected with him is conquered. The connection between the enemy and his friend may be (1) Direct or (2) Indirect. Thus, the figure is of two kinds.

The first is instanced in рддреНрд╡рдВ рд╡рд┐рдирд┐рд░реНрдЬрд┐рддetc. verse 153. Here, Cupid unable to conquer the Hero, conquers the Heroine who is directly connected with the Hero i. e. as his wife.

The second is instanced in рдпрд╕реНрдп рдХрд┐рдВрдЪрд┐рддреНetc. verse 154. Here, R─Бhu unable to avenge himself on Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa for the cutting of his head, troubles, the Moon who is connected with him. The connection of the Moon with Krsna is here (Indirect), because (the Moon) has a connection (of resemblance) with the face which is connected with Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa by the relation of part and whole.

50. THE LOST (рдореАрд▓рд┐рдд).

K─Б. xliv:тАФ When a thing is concealed by another, through a mark, either (1) natural or (2) even adventitious, and common to both, that is said to be the Lost.

** If through some mark, which is natural or adventitious, and which is common (to both the thing to be concealed and the thing which conceals it), a thing is concealed by another by its very nature, on account of its superior power, that they call twofold рдореАрд▓рд┐рдд.

Here, the disappearance (i. e. non-apprehension) of a thing is natural, on account of the thing being eclipsed by another thing which is similar to and more powerful than it. In **рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЬреЛрдХреНрддрд┐┬╣89**and рдЕрдкрд╣реНрдиреБрддрд┐90┬▓, however, this disappearance is not natural.

The first kind is instanced in рдЕрдкрд╛рдВрдЧetc. verse 155. Here, the marks tremulousness of the eyes etc. are natural to the body of the deer-eyed lady and they are common to the ‘rise of intoxication’, being found in that case also.

  • *Through these marks, the rise of intoxication’ is concealed by ‘youthfulness’ on account of its inherent superiority of power.

The second is instanced in рдпреЗ рдХрдиреНрджрд░рд╛рд╕реБetc. verse 156. Here, the fact of cold, which is understood from the force of the fact that the enemies reside in the caves of the Himalaya mountain*, is adventitious. Hence, (the marks) ’tremor and ‘horripilation’, which are produced from that (cold) are also of an identical nature, i. e. adventitious; and they are common to, being found in the case of, fear also.*

51. THE NECKLACE ( рдПрдХрд╛рд╡рд▓реА).

K─Б. xlv :тАФ When each succeeding thing is (1) affirmed or (2) even denied as an attribute of each preceding thing, that is the twofold Necklace.

** **The Vс╣Ыtti is here simple.

The affirmation or denial of a thing as an attribute of another must be repeated in order to be striking.

According to some, the K─Бrik─Б means:тАФ‘When a thing, which stands first as an attribute of another thing, is affirmed as possessed of its own nature by being afterwards┬╣made a subject and then by having another attribute affirmed of it; that is called рдПрдХрд╛рд╡рд▓реА’. As in рд╕рдкрдгреНрдбрд┐рддрдГ etc., the thing рдкрдгреНрдбрд┐рдд, which stands first as an attribute of another thing referred to by рд╕рдГ, is affirmed as possessed of its own nature, i. e. рдкрдгреНрдбрд┐рддрддреНрд╡, by being afterwards made a subject (referred to by рдпрдГ) and then having another attribute, i. e. рд╕реНрд╡рд╣рд┐рддрд╛рд░реНрдерджрд░реНрд╢рд┐рддреНрд╡affirmed of it. Similarly, in рди рддрдЬреНрдЬрд▓рдВetc., the thing рдЬрд▓рдВis denied as possessed of its own nature, i. e. рдЬрд▓рддреНрд╡, by being made subject (referred to by рдпрддреН) and then having another attribute, (i. e. рд╕реБрдЪрд╛рд░реБрдкрдВрдХрдЬрдВ denied of it).

This interpretation should, however, be rejected, because, it is opposed to Mammta’s Vrtti on this K─Бrik─Б;

┬╣. рдХрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреНрддреНрд╡рд┐рддрд┐ред рдкрд░рдордирдиреНрддрд░рдВ рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реНрдпрдВ рдХреГрддреНрд╡рд╛ рдпрддреНрд░ рд╕реНрдерд╛рдкреНрдпрддреЗ рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рджреНрд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдгреЗрди рд╕реНрд╡рдзрд░реНрдорд╡рд┐рд╢рд┐рд╖реНрдЯрдореБрдкрдкрд╛рджреНрдпрддреЗ рдЗрддреНрдпрд░реНрдердГред рдЕрдерд╡рд╛ рдЕрдкреЛрд╣реНрдпрддреЗ рд╕реНрд╡рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХреЗрдг рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реНрдпрддрд╛рд╡рдЪреНрдЫреЗрджрдХ-рдирд┐рд╖реЗрдзрд╡реБрджреНрдзрд┐рд╡рд┐рд╖рдпреАрдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрддреЗ рдЗрддреНрдпрд░реНрдердГред рдЕрддреНрд░реЛрджрд╛рд╣рд░рдгрдореНтАФ‘рд╕ рдкрдгреНрдбрд┐рддреЛ рдпрдГ рд╕реНрд╡рд╣рд┐рддрд╛рд░реНрдерджрд░реНрд╢реА рд╣рд┐рддрдВ рди рддрджреНрдпрддреНрд░ рдкрд░рд╛рдирдкрдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛ред рдкрд░реЗ рдЪ рддреЗ рдпреЗ рд╢реНрд░рд┐рддрд╕рд╛рдзреБрднрд╛рд╡рд╛рдГ, рд╕рд╛ рд╕рд╛рдзреБрддрд╛ рдпрддреНрд░ рдЪрдХрд╛рд╕реНрддрд┐ рдХреЗрд╢рд╡рдГ’рее рдЕрддреНрд░ рддрдЪреНрдЫрдмреНрджрд╛рд░реНрдереЗ рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдгрдВ рдкрдгреНрдбрд┐рддрдГ, рдкрд╢реНрдЪрд╛рддреН рд╕реНрд╡рд╣рд┐рддрд╛рд░реНрдерджрд░реНрд╢рд┐рддреНрд╡рдВ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐ рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реНрдпрдГ, рддреЗрди рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдгреЗрди рдкрдгреНрдбрд┐рддрддреНрд╡реЗрдиреЛрдкрдкрд╛рджреНрдпрддреЗред рджреНрд╡рд┐рддрдпрднреЗрджрд╕реНрдп рддреБ тАЩрди рддрдЬреНрдЬрд▓рдореН’ рдЗрддрд┐ рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрдорд╛рдгрдореНред рдЕрддреНрд░ рд╣рд┐ рд╕реБрдЪрд╛рд░реНрд╡рд┐рддреНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдгреЗрди рд╕реНрд╡рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХреЗрдг рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реНрдпрддрд╛рд╡рдЪреНрдЫреЗрджрдХрдЬрд▓рддреНрд╡рдирд┐рд╖реЗрдзрд╡реБрджреНрдзрд┐рд░рд┐рддрд┐ред рдЕрддреНрд░ ‘рдкреБрд░рд╛рдгрд┐ рдпрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдореН’ рдЗрддреНрдпреБрджрд╛рд╣рд░рдгрд╛рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдкреНрддрд┐рдГ рд╕реВрддреНрд░рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд░рд╛рдирдиреБрд╕рд╛рд░рддрд╛рдЪреЗрддрд┐ рджреЛрд╖рдГ рд╕реНрдлреБрдЯ рдПрд╡ред рдкреНрд░рднрд╛.

because, according to it, the definition of this figure does not extend to such examples as рдкреБрд░рд╛рдгрд┐ рдпрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдВetc., and because, it does not literally follow the wording of the K─Бrik─Б.

The first kind is instanced in рдкреБрд░рд╛рдгрд┐etc. verse 157. and the second in рди рддрдЬреНрдЬрд▓рдВetc. verse 158. Here, in the former (example, each succeeding thing) is affirmed (of each preceding thing) in the following order :тАФ тАЩwomen’ are affirmed of ‘houses’; of those (‘women’) ‘beauty’ (is affirmed), through its being said to be a means of the act of ‘decoration’ which is an attribute of their bodies; of that ‘beauty’, ‘sports’ (are affirmed); and of those (тАЩsports’ also, the ‘weapon of Cupid’ is affirmed). In the same manner, in the latter example, (each succeeding thing) should be understood as denied as an attribute (of each preceding thing). Thus of ‘water,’ ’lotuses’ should be considered as denied; of ’lotuses,’ ‘bees,’ of ‘bees,’ ‘humming’; and of ‘humming’ also, ‘charmingness.”

The figure occurs also when each succeeding thing is predicated as a subject to each preceding thing; as inрдзрд░реНрдореЗрдг рдмреБрджреНрдзрд┐рдГetc. Here, рдмреБрджреНрдзрд┐etc. are successively predicated as subjects to what precedes, i. e. рдзрд░реНрдордГetc91┬╣.

If each preceding thing helps each succeeding thing in an uniform manner, then this very variety becomes what has been called by the Ancients рдорд╛рд▓рд╛рджреАрдкрдХ. рдорд╛рд▓рд╛рджреАрдкрдХ92┬▓, according to R. G. does not deserve to be рджреАрдкрдХ, because it does not contain тАЩresemblance’ which constitutes the very essence ofрджреАрдкрдХ, and besides, рдорд╛рд▓рд╛рджреАрдкрдХ does not contain рдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд and рдЕрдкреНрд░рдХреГрддthings both of which are found in рджреАрдкрдХ.

52. REMINISCENCE (рд╕реНрдорд░рдг)

K─Б. xlvi. a b c :тАФ The recollection of an object,in the form in which it is cognised, on the perception of another object similar to it, is (termed) Reminiscence.

In this K─Бrik─Б, the word, рдЕрд░реНрдерд╕реНрдп рд╕реНрдореГрддрд┐рдГ alone constitute the definition of рд╕реНрдорд░рдг. The word рдпрдерд╛рдиреБрднрд╡рдореН indicates the form of Reminiscence, and the words рджреГрд╖реНрдЯреЗ рддрддреНрд╕рджреГрд╢реЗ indicate all the circumstances that revive the impression of a former experience which generates recollection. Thus, such circumstances93ред Ny─Бya III, 2.44.”) as Destiny, Contrast, Reflection, Association of ideas etc. are also included.

Or, the words рджреГрд╖реНрдЯреЗ рддрддреНрд╕рджреГрд╢реЗmay be taken as forming part of the definition of рд╕реНрдорд░рдгand thus serving the purpose of excluding all other reminiscences94 which are not based upon resemblance, and are not thus striking; thusрд╕ рддрдереЗрддрд┐ etc. is no example of this figure.

Thus, the definition ofрд╕реНрдорд░рдг is:тАФ When an object, which is once cognised (by any of the kinds of evidence) as possessed of a certain form, is afterwards recollected in the same form (in which it was cognised before), on the perception95 (by any of the senses) or even on the recollection96 of another object

which is similar to it and which is the cause of the awakenment of Reminiscence, through the revival of the impression left on the mind by the former cognition.

The figure is two-fold:тАФ When the object recollected is cognised (1) in this life or (2) in some former life.

The first kind is instanced in рдирд┐рдореНрдирдирд╛рднрд┐etc. verse 159. Here, the recollection is of an object experienced in this life.

The second is instanced in рдХрд░рдЬреБрдЕetc. verse 160. Here, on the perception of the ‘breasts of рдпрд╢реЛрджрд╛the рдкрд╛рдВрдЪрдЬрдиреНрдпis recollected by Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa who had known it in one of his former lives, owing to resemblance between the two objects.

R─Бghav─Бnanda97, however, would have this figure, even where the recollection arises from Contrast; as in рд╢рд┐рд░реАрд╖рдореГрджреНрд╡реА etc.

53. THE ERROR (рднреНрд░рд╛рдиреНрддрд┐рдорд╛рдиреН).

K─Б. xlvi. c d:тАФ The apprehension of (one thing as). another on the perception of (that thing) similar to that (another), is (termed) the Error.

Here also, the word рдЕрдиреНрдпрд╕рдВрд╡рд┐рддреН alone constitutes the definition. The word рддрддреНрддреБрд▓реНрдпрджрд░реНрд╢рдиреЗindicates the circumstances that produce Error. рддрддреН refers to ‘a thing not in question,’ which is referred to by рдЕрдиреНрдпрддреН in рдЕрдиреНрдпрд╕рдВрд╡рд┐рддреН. What is рддрддреНрддреБрд▓реНрдп similar to that (thing not in question), must, therefore, of course, be taken here to be ‘a thing in question.’ When, on the perception of such ‘a thing (in question,’ i. e. of ‘a thing in question’ similar to a thing not in question), the apprehension (of that thing in question) as (identical with) that thing not in question arises, it is (called) the Error. In other words, when тАШa thing in

question’ is taken for ‘a thing not in question’ which is called to mind through the impression of it being revived by the sight of that thing in question similar to it, it is called the Error.

  • This is neither Metaphor nor the first (kind of) Hyperbole; for, although in those figures there is an apprehension of a false identity between two things, still, inasmuch as the apprehension of that false identity is there accompanied by the apprehension that it is false, Error is really absent. Here, however, Error is clearly98 apprehended (to be present). as shown by the name (of the figure99 рднреНрд░рд╛рдиреНрддрд┐рдорддреН) which comes into use by following its sense.*

The natural sense of Error is ‘an apprehension of a false identity which is not accompanied by the apprehension that it is false.’

The cognition of Error is here an ascertained one; thus, this figure is distinguished from the Doubt instanced in рдХрд╛рдиреНрддреЗ рддрд╡ etc. The matter in hand here is cognised as identical with what is not the matter in hand. In other words, the matter in hand is here not cognised at all. Thus, рдореАрд▓рд┐рдд, рд╕рд╛рдорд╛рдиреНрдп, and рддрджреНрдЧреБрдг are excluded; for in рдореАрд▓рд┐рдд, the рдЕрдкреНрд░рд╛рдХрд░рдгрд┐рдХ itself is absent; in рд╕рд╛рдорд╛рдиреНрдп, although no distinction is apprehended between the рдкреНрд░рд╛рдХрд░рдгрд┐рдХ and the рдЕрдкреНрд░рд╛рдХрд░рдгрд┐рдХ, still, both the рдкреНрд░рд╛рдХрд░рдгрд┐рдХ and the рдЕрдкреНрд░рд╛рдХрд░рдгрд┐рдХ are cognised; and in рддрджреНрдЧреБрдг, there is an identity of qualities only, but not of the objects (possessed of those qualities) which are cognised distinctly.

The delusive cognition must spring from the imagination of the poet. In other words, it must be striking. Thus рд░рдВрдЧреЗ рд░рдЬрддрдореН is no example of this figure.

The figure is instanced in рдХрдкрд╛рд▓реЗetc. verse 161. Here, the ‘rays of the Moon’ are mistaken for ‘milk etc.’ by the ‘cat etc.’ through resemblance between the ‘rays’ and ‘milk etc.’

54. THE CONVERSE(рдкреНрд░рддреАрдк).

K─Б. xlvii:тАФ (1) When the thing compared to is condemned, or (2) when it is itself fancied as (being) the thing compared, for the purpose of being condemned; it is (termed) the Converse.

  • When theрдЙрдкрдорд╛рди is condemned (by saying);тАФ ‘what is the use of the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди, since the* рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп itself is quite capable of bearing its yoke, i. e. of serving its purpose; also when the same (рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди), (although) well-known as being an рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди*, is (yet) turned into anрдЙрдкрдореЗрдп, in order to show that it has got another* рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди in the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп itself, i. e. to show that the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп is superior to it and thus to condemn it in this manner; that is the twofold Converse, so called because (in it) the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп becomes a rival of the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди*.*

The figure is instanced in рд▓рд╛рд╡рдгреНрдпреМрдХрд╕рд┐etc. verse 162. Here, the thing compared, i. e. the ‘king’ endowed with such various qualities as ‘beauty etc.’ is present; the various things compared to, i. e. the moon etc.’ are, therefore, condemned as useless.

Here, although there is another figure called рдпрдерд╛рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдп, still, what is striking is not Relative Order but condemnation.

The second is instanced in рдП рдПрд╣рд┐ etc. verse 163. Here, the ‘Moon’, inasmuch as she is said to have the ‘face’ as anрдЙрдкрдорд╛рди to her, is represented as inferior (to that ‘face’) in her qualities.
