The word рд╡рдЪрдиреАрдп*тАФ the Sanskrit form ofрд╡рдЕрдгрд┐рдЬреНрдЬ, however, suggests that even this comparison cannot be established between the Moon and the face, on of the former being considered to be far inferior to the latter. Thus, (the fact of) the non-establishment of comparison leads to the condemnation (of the Moon).*

The figure is thus distinguished from рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХ where, although the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп is superior to the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди as here, still, the fact of comparison is established between them.

Sometimes, however, an act of comparison, (by being) but accomplished, leads to the condemnation (of the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди*);* as instanced in рдЧрд░реНрд╡рдорд╕рдВрд╡рд╛рд╣реНрдпetc. verse 164 Here, the turning of the ’lotuses,’ which are well-known as the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди, into the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдпitself constitutes their condemnation, because, turning them into the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп is tantamount to showing that they are possessed of inferior qualities.

Here, although comparion is effected, still, the superiority of the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп (i. e. рдирд▓рд┐рди) is not apprehended. Thus, this kind is distinguished fromрд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░реЗрдХ where that superiority is apprehended.

  • In this manner, (the figure) рдкреНрд░рддреАрдк should be understood as curring also when an object, which did not before experience: state of being the* рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди, owing to the possession of incomrable qualities, is made to assume that state; as in рдЕрд╣рдореЗрд╡etc. verse 165. Here, (the fact of)’**рд╣рд╛рд▓рд╛рд╣рд▓тАЩ**s (assuming). he position of the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди, (although hitherto regarded as) impossible, is (yet) declared (in the verse).

55. THE SAMENESS (рд╕рд╛рдорд╛рдиреНрдп).

K─Б. xlviii. :тАФ When something in question is represented as appearing like something else, owing to its connection with it, in order to show a likeness of properties (between them), that is said to be the Sameness.

  • When (a thing in question), although dissimilar, becomes connected with (another)тАФa thing not in question,тАФand with its own qualities but not given up, is represented as having become undistinguishable from it, in order to show that (the thing in question) appears like (the thing not in question), it is (called) the Sameness; (so called) because, (in it) there is a connection of like properties.*

The word рдЕрдкрд░рд┐рддреНрдпрдХреНрддрдирд┐рдЬрдЧреБрдг excludes рддрджреНрдЧреБрдг where the thing in question gives up its own qualities. Upon this, Prabh─Б100 remarks that the word рдЕрдкрд░рд┐рддреНрдпрдХреНрддрдирд┐рдЬрдЧреБрдг is not necessary to exclude рддрджреНрдЧреБрдг; for, in aрддрджреНрдЧреБрдг, one thing assumes only the qualities of another; but the things themselves are not represented as undistinguishable from each other; nor are they understood as such. Thus,рддрджреНрдЧреБрдг is excluded by the word рддрджреЗрдХрд╛рддреНрдорддрдпрд╛ itself. The word рдмрдзреНрдпрддреЗ does not mean ‘is expressed’ but simply ‘is conveyed’; for the fact of the similarity of appearance is not ’expressed’ but simply тАШconveyed’ by the words рдЕрд╡рд┐рднрд╛рд╡реНрдпрддрд╛рдВ рдЧрддрд╛рдГ in the verse рдорд▓рдпрдЬ etc.

In the рдореАрд▓рд┐рдд, an object is not apprehended at all, being eclipsed by another of a superior quality similar to it; whilst, in the present figure, an object is apprehended, but it is apprehended as undistinguishable from another, on account of both the objects possessing like properties.

In рднреНрд░рд╛рдиреНрддрд┐рдорд╛рдиреН,the object that is superimposed upon another is one which is recollected. Here, it is one which is perceived. In Metaphor, the identity between the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдпand the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди is expressed by words, and not simply conveyed by them as here. In Hyperbole, the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдпis not expressed by a word different from that which expresses the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди. Here, both of them are expressed by distinct words.

The figure is instanced in рдорд▓рдпрдЬetc. verse 166. Here, the ‘whiteness’ of the thing in question, being spoken of as neither more nor less than that of what is different from it, i. e. of the thing not in question, is the cause of the similarity of their appearance. Hence, they are not apprehended as distinct from each other.

Sometimes, an antecedent apprehension of identity between the thing in question and the thing not in question is inferred from the apprehension of difference between them; as in рд╡реЗрддреНрд░рддреНрд╡рдЪрд╛etc. verse 167. Here, it is only after the ‘bees’ have fallen upon the ‘cheeks,’ that the difference between ‘Campaka flowers’ and ‘cheeks’ is apprehended; afterwards the antecedent apprehension of identity between them is inferred.

Here, the apprehension of difference due to another cause, i. e. ’the fall of bees upon the cheeks’, although subsequent cannot yet do away with antecedent apprehension of identity due to ‘possession of a yellow colour by рдЧрдВрдб and рдЪрдВрдкрдХ; for, it has been (already) effected; and an apprehension (that has been already effected) cannot be sublated.

56. THE EXTRAORDINARY (рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖).

K─Б. xlix & 1:тАФ (1) When an object is (representeds) abiding without its well-known abode; (2) when one object is (spoken of as) being present in the same form in many places, simultaneously; and (3) when somebody, in doing one act, succeeds in doing another impossible act, by means of the same (effort); it is said to be the threefold Extraordinary.

  • When an object is represented as existing in a peculiar (i. e. supportless) condition by leaving its well-known abode. that is the first (kind of)* рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖*.*

It is instanced in рджрд┐рд╡рдордкреНрдпреБetc. verse 168. Here, the ‘discourses of poets’ are represented as delighting the world by existing without their well-known abodes, i. e. ‘poets’. ‘The well-known abode’ is not simply the real abode, but one which is established by a poetic convention also. Thus the well-known abode referred to here is not ’ether,’ which is the real abode of рдЧрд┐рд░рдГ(sounds), but ‘poets’ who are the abode of рдЧрд┐рд░рдГas established by a ‘poetic convention.’

This kind occurs, also when a thing is spoken of as residing in another abode; as in рдЧрддреЗрд╜рдкрд┐ рд╕реВрд░реНрдпреЗetc.

When one and the same object resides in many places, in one and the same form, simultaneously, that is the second kind of

рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖

.

It is instanced in рд╕рд╛ рд╡рд╕рдЗ etc. verse 169. Here, one ‘rival wife’ is represented as being present in many places, i. e. heart, eyes etc. in one and the same form, i. e. that of a rival wife, simultaneously.

The word рдПрдХрд╛рддреНрдорд╛ excludes рдпрдерд╛рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдп where the forms possessed by an object are different; and the word рдпреБрдЧрдкрддреНexcludes рдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рдп where there is succession.

  • When an agent, hurriedly proceeding to do an act, succeeds in doing another impossible act also, by the same effort, that is another (i. e. the third kind of)* рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖*.*

The word рд░рднрд╕реЗрди101 shows that the agent has no intention of doing two acts by one and the same effort. The word рддрдереИрд╡excludes рд╕рдореБрдЪреНрдЪрдп instanced in рдзреБрдиреЛрддрд┐etc. where the efforts are different. The sentence **рдкреНрд░рдЪреНрдпрд╡рддрд┐102**etc. is no example of this kind of рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖, impossibility ofan act being there absent.

It is instanced in рд╕реНрдлреБрд░рджрджреНрднреБрддetc. verse 170. Here, Brahm─Б, in endeavouring to create a particular king has unexpectedly succeeded in creating other impossible things such as Cupid,
the Sun, Bс╣Ыhaspati etc., by the same effort.

In this example, although there is another figure, i. e.рдпрдерд╛рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдп103, yet it is рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖ not рдпрдерд╛рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдп that is prominentlystriking here.

Here, the doing of an impossible act is expressed. Sometimes, it is suggested; as in рдЧреГрд╣рд┐рдгреА рд╕рдЪрд┐рд╡рдГ etc. verse 171. Here, the impossible act of taking away minister, confidant, beloved, disciple etc., is suggested by the words рдХрд┐рдВ рди рдореЗ рд╣реГрддрдореН.

If it be said: The representation of a thing existing without its abode is improper, since such a representation is opposed to experience which shows that a thing always resides in its abode. Similarly, the other representations contained in the K─Бrik─Бs are also improper.

We reply that such things as are described above are no doubt impossible. But they are here represented as possible only metaphorically.

Thus, the ‘words’ which please the world are really speaking uttered by a man of the present times. But they are metaphorically said to be the actual words of a past poet, on account of close resemblance between them. Similarly, the ‘woman’ is only metaphorically said to reside in her lover’s heart, on account of her being constantly thought of by him. So also, the ‘king’ is only metaphorically said to be Cupid etc., inasmuch as he resembles him in point of beauty.

  • (This metaphorical representation)тАФ (this) unusual and extraordinary mode of statementтАФitself constitutes the very life (of a figure) everywhere, in these places. For, a figure generally does not exist without it. Hence it is said (by Bh─Бmaha and others):тАФ (This metaphorical mode of statement’) тАФthis unusual form of speechтАФwhich is described above (is found) everywhere. By this a sense is invested with a peculiar beauty. Poets should exert themselves for (securing) it.. For, what figure (exists) without it?*

The word рдЕрддрд┐рд╢рдпреЛрдХреНрддрд┐in the Vс╣Ыtti is intended to mean a metaphorical description simply. It does not here denote the figure Hyperbole, because, that figure is here impossible.

The same is the meaning of рд╡рдХреНрд░реЛрдХреНрддрд┐. The two words are in fact synonymous here.

The word рдкреНрд░рд╛рдпреЗрдгin the Vс╣Ыtti excludes such a figure as рд╕реНрд╡рднрд╛рд╡реЛрдХреНрддрд┐where the description is not metaphorical,

57. THE BORROWER (рддрджреНрдЧреБрдг).

K─Б. li:тАФ When an object quits its own form and assumes that of another possessed of very brilliant qualities, by coming in contact with it, it is termed the Borrower.

When a thing has its form overshadowed by another (which is) near it, and with whose own superior qualities it becomes connected, on account of the superior excellence (of that another), and assumes the form of that (another), that isрддрджреНрдЧреБрдг(so called) because, it (literally) is that in which there is assumption by the thing in question of the quality of that, i. e. the thing not in question.

In рдореАрд▓рд┐рдд, one thing is apprehended (but) as covered over by another. Here, one thing assumes the quality of another, although its nature is not covered over by that of another. Or, in рдореАрд▓рд┐рдд, a thing is not apprehended, being eclipsed by another. In рд╕рд╛рдорд╛рдиреНрдп, things are apprehended as undistinguishable from each other, although they do not give up their own qualities. Here, only a quality is eclipsed; the things are apprehended as distinct from each other.

In рднрд╛рдиреНрддрд┐рдорд╛рдиреН, the thing that is superimposed upon another is one that is recollected. Here, it is one which is percieved. Besides, a delusion is not here stated in words.

The figure is instanced in рд╡рд┐рднрд┐рдиреНрди etc. verse 172. Here, the colour of ArunaтАФ Garuс╕Нa’s brother, is (represented as) superior to that of the Sun’s horses, and the colour of the green jewels as superior to that of Aruс╣Зa. Hence the Sun’s horses are apprehended as identical with the Aruс╣Зa. Similarly,

these horses are apprehended as identical with the green jewels. Thus, there are two examples of рддрджреНрдЧреБрдг here.

Thus, those men are wrong who say that the figure occurs when an object, that has quitted its form, is again restored to it. For, their definition runs counter to the etymological explanation of рддрджреНрдЧреБрдг given in the Vс╣Ыtti, also to the fact that in the Vс╣Ыtti, two examples have been shown to be present in the verse by the mention of two qualities, and also to the fact that there is рддрджреНрдЧреБрдг in the example of рд╕рдВрдХрд░(i. e.рдЖрддреНрддреЗ рд╕реАрдордиреНрддрд░рддреНрдиреЗ etc. verse 179.) cited by Mammaс╣нa afterwards which it would not be if their definition be accepted; since there is in that verse no restoration of a thing to the form which it has quitted.

58. THE NON-BORROWER(рдЕрддрджреНрдЧреБрдг).

K─Б. lii a b:тАФ When this does not assume the form of that, that is termed the Non-borrower.

** рддрддреН** means ’the thing in question.’рдЕрд╕реНрдп means ‘of thething not in question.’ The wordsрдЕрддреНрдкреБрдЬреНрдЬреНрд╡рд▓рдЧреБрдгрд╕реНрдп рдпреЛрдЧрд╛рддреНfrom the preceding S┼лtra are here understood. Thus, the full definition is:тАФ ‘If this, e. i. the thing not in question of an inferior quality does not assume the colour (form or quality) of that i. e. of the thing in question, although it has a capability of assuming that colour, form or quality, (i. e. although it comes in contact with the superior qualities of that thing in question), that is termed рдЕрддрджреНрдЧреБрдг, so called because, it literally is that in which there is no assumption by the thing not in question of the quality of the thing in question.

Although here the cause i. e. ‘capability’ being present, the effect; i. e. ‘assumption of another’s form’ is absent, yet this is not рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реЛрдХреНрддрд┐, because, this is founded upon the peculiarly striking circumstance of a thing not assuming the quality of another.

The figure is instanced in рдзрд╡рд▓реЛрд╜рдкрд┐ etc. verse 173. Here, (the lover) does not become red (i. e. affectionate), though he is seated in a heart which is extremely red, (i. e. glowing with ardent love). Thus, the last half alone is an example of this figure. In the first half, there is рд╡рд┐рд░реЛрдзbetween ‘whiteness’ and ‘redness.’

In the example, the ‘heart’ is the thing in question, the ‘man addressed’ is the thing not in question; for, what is intended here is the narration by a woman of an account of the state of her own heart.

Besides, in this (K─Бrik─Б), рддрддреН may refer to рдЕрдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд (also), and рдЕрд╕реНрдп to рдкреНрд░рдХреГрдд, since pronouns stand for any nouns that we intend them to stand for. Thus, the figure рдЕрддрджреНрдЧреБрдгрд╜hould also be understood (as occurring) when the form of the thing not in question is not assumed by the thing in question, for some reason or other : as in рдЧрд╛рдВрдЧрдордореНрдмреБetc. verse 174. Here, the ‘swan’ being the object of description is the matter in hand; рдЧрдВрдЧрд╛and рдпрдореБрдирд╛are the matters not in hand. The ‘swan’ does not take the colour of either. Thus, if we rest simply in the expressed sense of the verse, there is no difficulty in apprehending the verse as an example of рдЕрддрджреНрдЧреБрдг.

But if we look to the suggested sense of the verse, by taking it as an example of рдЕрдкреНрд░рд╕реНрддреБрддрдкреНрд░рд╢рдВрд╕рд╛, we see it is ’the person of a steady character’, not ’the swan’, that becomes the matter in hand. Thus, inasmuch as the ‘swan’ is not the matter in hand, there is difficulty in regarding the verse as an example of рдЕрддрджреНрдЧреБрдг. But, this difficulty may be avoided by looking upon swan’ as nothing but the matter in hand, inasmuch as it is an рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди with reference to a ‘steady man’ who is the matter in hand.

59. THE FRUSTRATION (рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдШрд╛рдд).

K─Б. lii c d & liii a b:тАФ When, by the same means by which one does a certain thing another undoes it that is said to be the Frustration.

  • When a certain thing which is accomplished by one, by a certain means, is rendered otherwise by another by the same means, with a desire of conquering (that one), that is* рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдШрд╛рдд:so called because, it is the cause of the frustration of a thing (already) accomplished.

It is instanced in рджреГрд╢рд╛ рджрдЧреНрдзрдВ etc. verse 175. Here, by the very means, i. e. eyes, by which God ┼Ъiva burnt down Cupid, the ‘women’ animate Cupid with the desire of conquering ┼Ъiva. Here, identity of ’eyes’ means their similarity; for, the eyes of the women are not identical with but similar to, those of ┼Ъiva. Thus the figure may be defined as ’that where one and the same cause produces different effects in violation of the rule that different causes produce different effects’.

The figure also occurs when an effect is produced by a case which is well-known to produce another; as in рдпреИрд░реНрдЬрдЧрддреН etc.

In all the preceding examples, the manifestation of opposition is due to a fancied identity between two causes The opposition is, however, removed when the causes are regarded in their own individual capacities.

The figure does not occur when one and the same cause, by residing in two different abodes, produces two opposite effects; as in рдкрд╛рдВрдбрд┐рддреНрдпреЗрди etc. ‘Frustration’ is not based upon opposition, and therefore does not constitute a figure.

The figure occurs also when the contrary of a certain act is justified by the same reason by which that act is justified as in рд╡рд┐рдореБрдЮреНрдЪрд╕рд┐etc.

Thus, Pure figures have been described. The union of these, however, obtains a distinct beauty like the union of ornaments, and therefore constitutes a distinct figure. This

union is of two kinds: (1) the union of figures which are independent of each other; and (2) of those which are not so. The first kind of union, is called the Aggregation, and the second, the Commixture, which is again three-fold. Thus, there are in all four varieties of union, which the author now proceeds to define.

60. THE AGGREGATION (рд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрд┐).

K─Б. liii c d:тАФ

The existence of these, separately, in one place, is desired to be the

Aggregation.

** рднреЗрдж** means the mutual independence of figures as regards their essential natures, or as regards the words104that contain them; or rather, the mutual independence of figures as regards their essential nature, accompanied by the difference of the words that contain them.

The first105 definition of рднреЗрдж is not good, because it does not serve the purpose of excluding the third kind of рд╕рдВрдХрд░ instanced in рд╕реНрдкрд╖реНрдЯреЛрд▓реНрд▓рд╕рддреН etc., where, although the words that contain рд░реВрдкрдХ and рдЕрдиреБрдкреНрд░рд╛рд╕are identical, still, the two figures do not possess mutual independence. In a рд╕рдВрдХрд░, however, the mutual dependence of figures is necessary. The second definition, however, excludes this рд╕рдВрдХрд░, because, in it the words containing the figures being identical, the рд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрднреЗрджof the definition is absent. рд╕реНрдерд┐рддрд┐ means an ascertained existence. Thus when these figures, i. e. those whose natures have been described just before (i. e. in 9th and 10th Ull─Бsas), exist independently of each other, according to possibility, in one place, i. e. in that portion only (of a poem) which is (called) ‘word’ or that only (called) sense’ or even in a sentence or

verse which consists of both word and sense; that is рд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрд┐; (so called because) its nature is Connection of two or many (figures) with one place, i. e. with one poetic piece.

The plural of рдПрддреЗрд╖рд╛рдВ is insignificant. Thus, рд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрд┐ occurs even when two figures exist together separately in one place.

The words рднреЗрджреЗрди рд╕реНрдерд┐рддрд┐рдГexclude рд╕рдВрдХрд░, in the first kind of which, the figures are dependent upon each other as regards their natures; in the second, their existence is not an ascertained one; and in the third, they are dependent upon each other as regards the words that contain them, or rather, the words that contain them are not different. This Aggregation may be of two figures of ‘word’ or of two figures of ‘sense’ or of one figure of ‘word’ and one figure of ‘sense.’

Of these, the

Aggregation of two figures of ‘word’ may be instanced in рд╡рджрди

etc. verse 176. The

Aggregation of two

figures of ‘sense, however, may be instanced in рд▓рд┐рдореНрдкрддреАрд╡etc. verse 177. Here, in the former. (verse), Alliteration (рднтАФрдн) and Rhyme (рд▓рдХрд▓рдГтАФрд▓рдХрд▓рдГ)тАФboth figures of word’тАФexist independent of each other and thus lead to the (figure) Aggregation. In the latter (verse), however, рдЙрдкрдорд╛ and рдЙрддреНрдкреНрд░реЗрдХреНрд╖рд╛

, both figures of ‘sense’ exist similarly (i. e. independent of each other), and thus (lead to the

figure Aggregation).

The

Aggregation of one

figure of ‘word’ and one

figure of ‘sense’, on the other hand, may be instanced in рд╕реЛ рдгрддреНрдерд┐etc. verse 178. Here, in the first106half, AlliterationтАФa figure of ‘word,’ and in the second half, (Metaphor) (рд╣реГрджрдпрд▓реБрдгреНрдардирдореН)тАФ a figure of ‘sense,’ (exist) independent of each other.

If it be said that inasmuch as the abodes of these figures are different, that of рдЕрдиреБрдкреНрд░рд╛рд╕being ‘word,’ and of рд░реВрдкрдХbeing ‘sense,’ they cannot form рд╕рдВрд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрд┐ which consists of Connection of many figures with one abode; we reply that these (figures)

are (here said to be) connected with one abode, because they are (here) connected with one and the same sentence (and a sentence is nothing but a collection of words conveyiny meanings), or with one and the same verse (which may contain many sentences).

61. COMMIXTURE (рд╕рдВрдХрд░).

(a) Of Mutual Subserviency.

K─Б. liv. a b:тАФ But when (these) do not rest in themselves, but are subservient to one another, it is (termedthe Commixture).

But when these very figures do not assume an independent position for themselves, each being dependent upon another,for the sake of obtaining an existence for itself, or for the production of a particular beauty, and are thus subservient to one another, it is рд╕рдВрдХрд░ ; so called because, its nat ure is (the intermingling107, i. e. interdependence of these figures.

Thus, the figure108 рдЗрддреНрдпрд╛рджреМ рд╡рдВрд╢рд╢рдмреНрджреЗ рд╢реНрд▓реЗрд╖рдГ рд╢рдмреНрджрд╕рд╛рдореНрдпрд╛рддреН рд╕реНрд╡рддрдГрд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрдГ рд░реВрдкрдХрдореБрдкрдХрд░реЛрддреАрддрд┐ рдирд╛рдпрдВ рд╕рдВрдХрд░рдГ ред Vam.") does not occur if one figure being independent of another assists that another, as in рд╕рджреНрд╡рдВрд╢ etc.). where the paronomasia on the word рд╡рдВрд╢ obtains an independent existence through a verbal identification and then assists Metaphor.

It is instanced in рдЖрддреНрддреЗ etc. verse 179.

Here, рднреНрд░рд╛рдВрддрд┐рдорд╛рдиреН in рдЧреБрдВрдЬрд╛рдлрд▓рд╛рдирд╛рдВ рд╕реНрд░рдЬрдГ obtains an existence only as subservient to рддрджреНрдЧреБрдг in рдмрд┐рдВрдмреМрд╖реНрдардХрд╛рдиреНрддреНрдпрд╛ рд╢реЛрдгрдВ, since the production of error is due to the recollection of Gu├▒j─Б fruits at the sight of pearls red through contact with the lower lip. рддрджреНрдЧреБрдгalso causes much pleasure to the men of taste, only when it is

subordinate to рднреНрд░рд╛рдВрддрд┐рдорд╛рдиреН, and not independently. Thus, there is a mutual subserviency here between these two figures. Here, the Commixture is of two figures; it may be of many figures also; as instanced in рдЬрдЯрд╛рднрд╛рднрд┐рдГ etc. verse 180.

Here, there are four (

figures); рдЙрдкрдорд╛ in рдЬрдЯрд╛рднрд╛рднрд┐рд░реНрднрд╛рднрд┐рдГ andрдкрд┐рддреГрд╡рди etc., рд░реВрдкрдХ in рдХрд▓рдВрдХрд╛рдХреНрд╖ etc., and рддрд╛рд░рд╛рдкрд░рд┐ etc., рдЙрддреНрдкреНрд░реЗрдХреНрд╖рд╛ inрд╡рд┐рдпреЛрдЧрд┐ etc., and рд╢реНрд▓реЗрд╖ in рд╡реИрд░рд╛рдЧреНрдп etc. All these are apprehended as mutually subservient as before. Of these,рдЙрддреНрдкреНрд░реЗрдХреНрд╖рд╛ is suborPi- nate toрд╢реНрд▓реЗрд╖ ; for, the second sense that is apprehended fromрд╡реИрд░рд╛рдЧреНрдпрд╡рд┐рд╢рдж is due to this рдЙрддреНрдкреНрд░реЗрдХреНрд╖рд╛. рд╢реНрд▓реЗрд╖ again is subordinate toрд░реВрдкрдХand рдЙрдкрдорд╛; for, it is only in consequence of the apprehension of ‘indifference to the world’тАФ a sense yielded by the paronomastic word рд╡реИрд░рд╛рдЧреНрдп, that the holding of ‘matted hair’ and a ‘string of beads’ on the part of the Moon becomes intelligible. The Metaphor in рддрд╛рд░рд╛рдкрд░рд┐ etc., is subordinate toрдЙрдкрдорд╛in рдкрд┐рддреГetc. This subordination is due to a resemblance between the ‘cemetery’ and the ‘sky’. This resemblance again exists between them not naturally, but only when the ‘sky’ is supposed as the abode of ‘head-bones’ in the shape of the ‘cluster of stars.’ Of these, each subordinate figure depends upon each principal figure, in order that each may produce its own beauty. The figure which is the cause of the ultimate beauty of all these figures and to which all these are subordinate is рд╕рдорд╛рд╕реЛрдХреНрддрд┐; because the verse in consequence of the adjectives рдХрд░рдзреГрддрдХрд▓рдВрдХрд╛рдХреНрд╖рд╡рд▓рдпрддреНрд╡ etc. suggests the account of a great ‘Yogin’тАФ a thing not in question. This figure is obvious and therefore not noticed by Mamma╚Ыa.

If it be said: ’ In рдХрд▓рдВрдХрд╛рдХреНрд╖рд╡рд▓рдп, рдЙрдкрдорд╛ is as well possible as рд░реВрдкрдХ, it being possible to solve the compound in both the (рдХрд▓рдВрдХрдГрдЕрдХреНрд╖рд╡рд▓рдпрдорд┐рд╡) and (рдХрд▓рдВрдХрдГ рдПрд╡ рдЕрдХреНрд╖рд╡рд▓рдпрдВ). Thus, the figure deserves to be рд╕рдВрджреЗрд╣рд╕рдВрдХрд░ and not рд░реВрдкрдХnecessarily.’ We reply:тАФ “There is here one circumstance favouring the determination of the figure to be рд░реВрдкрдХ (рдХрд▓рдВрдХ рдПрд╡ рдЕрдХреНрд╖рд╡рд▓рдпрдореН), and that is theattributeрдХрд░рдзреГрддрддреНрд╡itself. It is universally known that what

is held by the hand is a ‘string of beads,’ not a ‘spot.’ This requires that the ‘string of beads’ should be prominently apprehended; and this is possible only when we take the figure to be рд░реВрдкрдХ; for, in a рд░реВрдкрдХ, the second member of the compound is always predominant. Thus, the ‘string of beads’ itself, by concealing the nature of the ‘spot’ becomes prominently apprehended; and with this, the attribute “held by the hand” can be properly connected. For, it is but the ‘string of beads’ that is universally known as having got the fitness of being held by the hand.

If it be urged: Even in this way the attribute рдХрд░рдзреГрддрддреНрд╡is not proper; for when we take the verse as referring to the Moon, the ‘spot’ is not held by her ‘rays,’ but by her ‘orb.’ Thus, рдХрд░рдзреГрддрддреНрд╡ cannot be connected with the ‘spot.’

We reply:тАФ It is true that the holding of the spot by the rays is impossible, since the Moon holds the spot on (her) body (i. e. orb) itself; still, in virtue109 of the fact that the poet has deliberately used such a word (i. e. рдХрд░) as contains a paronomasia, we should suppose that the ‘rays’ which really speaking, do not hold the ‘spot,’ but are only near110 it (both the rays and the spot residing in the same Moon), are, in virtue of (that) proximity, intended by him as holding that spot metaphorically.

If it be said: Why should you not then take рдЙрдкрдорд╛ to be the figure here by resorting to this very Indication?

We reply:тАФ If we take the figure to be рдЙрдкрдорд╛(рдХрд▓рдВрдХреЛрд╜рдХреНрд╖рд╡рд▓рдпрд╛рдорд┐рд╡); the spot becomes prominently apprehended. Now since the spot is not, as a matter of fact, held by the hand, the connection of рдХрд░рдзреГрддрддреНрд╡with рдХрд▓рдВрдХ becomes impossible. We

must, therefore, to render this connection possible, understand рдХрд░рдзреГрддрддреНрд╡ metaphorically. Thus, if we take the figure to be рдЙрдкрдорд╛, we shall have to resort to рд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрд╛ in order to render the connection of even the principal thing (рдХрд▓рдВрдХ) with рдХрд░рдзреГрддрддреНрд╡possible. But if we take the figure tobe рд░реВрдкрдХ, рд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрд╛will have to be resorted to, to render the connection of but a subordinate thing (рдХрд▓рдВрдХ) withрдХрд░рдзреГрддрддреНрд╡ possible. Now, it is better thatрд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрд╛ should be resorted to as regards the connection of a subordinate thing than as regards the connection of a principal thing. Thus, we should accept рд░реВрдкрдХ as the figure inрдХрд░рдзреГрддрдХрд▓рдВрдХрд╛рдХреНрд╖рд╡рд▓рдп, and not рдЙрдкрдорд╛.

According to the Ancients, this Commixture of Mutual subserviency is found to exist between two figures of a word also; as instanced in рд░рд╛рдЬрддрд┐ etc. verse 181. Here рдпрдордХ and a variety of рдЪрд┐рддреНрд░ ( called) рдЕрдиреБрд▓реЛрдордкреНрд░рддрд┐рд▓реЛрдо (i.e that kind of where if we read from the end we get the same arrangement of letters as if we read from the beginning) are subservient to each other in the two (i. e. second and fourth) quarters of the verse.

Although the mutual subserviency of these figures is not quite obvious, still, as the poet whilst engaged in arranging a Rhyme succeeds in producing a рдЪрд┐рддреНрд░ without any special effort,for its sake, рдЪрд┐рддреНрд░ is said to depend on рдпрдордХ for its existence; whilst,рдпрдордХis invested with a peculiar beauty only by depending upon рдЪрд┐рддреНрд░; because the fact that the Yamaka arrangement as dependent upon aрдЪрд┐рддреНрд░ arrangement is very difficult to be effected, is especially charming to the man of taste. This is the view of the Ancients. But, really speaking, there is nothing enabling us to ascertain that the poet is engaged in arranging a Rhyme only; or even granting that we have a ground for the ascertainment of this fact, still, it is notрдпрдордХ111 that is the cause of the production of рдЪрд┐рддреНрд░, but an

effort for it. Thus, рдЪрд┐рддреНрд░is not dependent upon рдпрдордХ for its production. Therefore, this deserves to be a Commixture not of Mutual Subserviency, but of Identical Position (i. e. where the two figures reside in one and the same place i. e. words).

B. OF DUBIOUSNESS

K─Б. liv. ed:тАФ

When there is a doubt as re

gards the acceptance of a (particular) fi

gure, owing to the absence of a reason either for or against it (that is the second Commixture).

When two or many figures, although by nature fit to exist together (in a verse), yet being opposed to each other as regards both or all of them being simultaneously intended by the poet, cannot exist (together) simultaneously; when besides, there is no reason in favour either of the acceptance of one or of the rejection of the other, (reason) which would lead us to accept only one and not the other; that is the second (kind of) рд╕рдВрдХрд░ whose nature is absence of determination. The copulative conjunction рдЪ in the S┼лtra shows112that the wordрд╕рдВрдХрд░itself in the preceding S┼лtra is here understood.

Although113 in the examples given below there is determination of the natures of figures, yet there is a doubt as to which of them in particular is intended by the poet.

Instanced in рдЬрд╣ рдЧрд╣рд┐рд░реЛetc. verse 182. Here, there is a doubt as to whether there is рд╕рдорд╛рд╕реЛрдХреНрддрд┐, the ‘ocean’ being the thing in question and a ‘particular man’тАФ the thing not in questionтАФ being understood from the common i. e. paronomastic attributes used in the verse; or рдЕрдкреНрд░рд╕реНрддреБрддрдкреНрд░рд╢рдВрд╕рд╛, a ‘particular man’ being the thing in question and understood through the description of

the ‘ocean’ which is the thing not in question, through a community of attributes.

Here, it is impossible that both the figures should exist simultaneously, because one and the same thing cannot be in question and not in question at one and the same time. Besides, there is here no reason either for or against any one of these two figures.

Commixture of Dubiousness figures is instanced in existing among many рдирдпрдирд╛рдирдиреНрджetc. verse 183. Here, (it is dubious whether) there is рдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рдпреЛрдХреНрдд, the fact of the presence of passion-exciting (night) time being described in different manner, i. e. through the description of the Moon, the rise of which is the cause thereof; or рдЕрддрд┐рд╢рдпреЛрдХреНрддрд┐the ‘face’ being completely swallowed up by the ‘orb of the Moon’ (the pronoun рдПрддрддреН being taken here as an adjective to

рдмрд┐рдВрдм); or рд░реВрдкрдХ, in consequence of the superimposition of the nature of the ’lunar orb upon the ‘face’ which should be taken here as referred to byрдПрддрддреН; or рджреАрдкрдХ, both ‘face’ which is in question and the Moon which is not in question being intended to be connected114”) with one and the same action of destroying (internal or external) gloom’ which is expressed by the verb рдкреНрд░рд╕реАрджрддрд┐; or рддреБрд▓реНрдпрдпреЛрдЧрд┐рддрд╛, both the ‘face’ and the ‘Moon’ being things in question or both being things not in question; or рд╕рдорд╛рд╕реЛрдХреНрддрд┐, the ‘orb of the Moon’ being in question, as the time is night, and the ‘face’ not being in question and understood through a community of attributes; or рдЕрдкреНрд░рд╕реНрддреБрддрдкреНрд░рд╢рдВрд╕рд╛, the ’transparency of the face’ being the subject under discourse, and understood through the description of the ‘Moon’ which is not in question. The doubt here arises because there is no reason here why we should accept one figure as that which is intended and reject another as that

which is not intended by the poet.

Thus, inasmuch as there is a doubt as regards many fi

gures, this is nothing but Commixture of Dubiousness.

But where there is a reason for one figure or a reason against another, there the presence of one fi

gure being ascertained, no doubt exists; рдиреНрдпрд╛рдп

means a reason (for one fi

gure), i. e. a reason favouring (the acceptance of one fi

gure). рджреЛрд╖

also means a reason against (one fi

gure), i. e. a reason not favouring (the acceptanceof one fi

gure).

It is instanced рд╕реМрднрд╛рдЧреНрдпрдВ etc.

  • Here, ’the beauty of the smile’тАФ which is prominently apprehended from the word* рд╣рд╛рд╕рджреНрдпреБрддрд┐is favourable115 to the apprehension of the ‘face’ only as prominent, because ’the beauty of the smile’ is directly possible in the ‘face’ only. The apprehension of the ‘face’ as prominent is possible in рдЙрдкрдорд╛ only. Thus, the beauty of the smile’ is a reason for (accepting the figure to be рдЙрдкрдорд╛ (рд╡рдХреНрддреНрд░рдВ рд╢рд╢реАрд╡). ‘*The beauty of the smile, however, is not ‘favourable’*to the apprehension of the Moon’ as prominent. For, it is not directly possible in her. This should not lead us to suppose, however, that it is then unfavourable’ to such an apprehension. For, it is not even unfavourable’ to the apprehension of the ‘Moon’ as prominent in the way in which it is ‘favourable’ to the apprehension of the ‘face’ as prominent; sinceрд╣рд╛рд╕рджреНрдпреБрддрд┐ meaning by Indication рд╡рд┐рдХрд╛рд╕рджреНрдпреБрддрд┐ may be said to be tropically possible in the ‘Moon.’

Thus, it is not a reason either for or against (accepting the fi

gure to be) рд░реБрдкрдХ.

In рд╡рдХреНрддреНрд░реЗрдиреНрджреМ etc., the attribute рдЕрдкрд░рддреНрд╡is favourable to the apprehension of the ‘Moon’ as prominent; for, what is apprehended from the line рд╡рдХреНрддреНрд░реЗрдиреНрджреМetc. is :тАФ ‘One Moon in the

form of the face being present, what is the use of a second’? Now, such an apprehension is impossible unless we admit рд░реВрдкрдХ to be the figure in рд╡рдХреНрддреНрд░реЗрдиреНрджреМ. For, the fact that a second Moon has arisen supposes that there is already a first Moon. But a first Moon is not obtained unless the ‘Moon’ inрд╡рдХреНрддреНрд░реЗрдиреНрджреМ is apprehended as prominent. But the apprehension of the тАШMoon ’ as prominent is not possible except in рд░реВрдкрдХ (рд╡рдХреНрддреНрд░рдореЗрд╡ рдЗрдиреНрджреБрдГ). Thus, the attribute рдЕрдкрд░рддреНрд╡ is a reason for рд░реВрдкрдХ. It is not, however, unfavourable to the apprehension of the ‘face as prominent, since such an apprehension as the face that resembles the Moon being present, why has a second Moon. arisen?’ is here possible. Hence, рдЕрдкрд░рддреНрд╡cannot be said to be quite inconsistent with the apprehension of the ‘face’ as prominent in рд╡рдХреНрддреНрд░реЗрдиреНрджреМ. Thus, it is not a reason against рдЙрдкрдорд╛. In рд░рд╛рдЬрдирд╛рд░рд╛рдпрдгрдВ etc., again, the fact of (Lakс╣гm─л’s) embracing the king who is like N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa thwarts рдЙрдкрдорд╛. For, it is inconsis- tent that one man’s wife should embrace another although he is like her husband. The fact of embrace’ cannot, however, be said to be a reason for рд░реВрдкрдХ (as will be seen just below).

In рдкрд╛рджрд╛рдореНрдмреБрдЬ, etc., the sounding of the anklets’ is impossible in a lotus’ and is therefore unfavourable to the apprehension of the lotus as prominent. It is thus a reason against рд░реВрдкрдХ.

If it be said: ‘The sounding of the anklets’ is also a reason for рдЙрдкрдорд╛, since it is favourable to the apprehension of the ‘feet’ as prominent. How then do you say that it is a reason against рд░реВрдкрдХ only, and not a reason for рдЙрдкрдорд╛ also? Thus, in other places, whatever, is favourable to one is generally unfavourable to another and whatever is unfavourable to one is generally favourable to another; for, if they are not so, they cannot be appropriately said to be either ‘favourable or unfavourable.’

We reply:тАФ True what you say; but the designation of one thing as ‘favourable’ or ‘unfavourable’ depends upon its

being prominently apprehended as such. Here, a reason againstтАФ which thwarts a (counter)тАФproposition (i. e. that there.is рд░реВрдкрдХ*) is apprehended as more powerful than a reason for the (original) proposition* i. e. that there is рдЙрдкрдорд╛.

If ‘sounding of the anklets’ be said to be a reason forрдЙрдкрдорд╛, a doubt arises as to whether there may not be a reason for рд░реВрдкрдХ also. But when sounding of the anklets’ is said to be a reason against рд░реВрдкрдХ, рд░реВрдкрдХ is excluded and the above doubt is removed. Thus, ‘sounding of the anklets,’ inasmuch. as it is apprehended more prominently as a reason against than as a reason for, is designated after what is prominent, i. e. as a reason against. It cannot, however, be said that inasmuch as ‘sounding of the anklets’ is favourable to the apprehension of the ‘feet’ as prominent, it is a reason forрдЙрдкрдорд╛*;for, sounding of the anklets’ is not prominently apprehended as a reason for* рдЙрдкрдорд╛.

Others interpret this Vс╣Ыtti thus:тАФ

** рд╡рд┐рдзрд┐** is that by which something is established in regard to something else, i. e. a reason for; and рд╡рд┐рдзреНрдпреБрдкрдорд░реНрджрд┐ means (that which) is more powerful than a reason for, i. e. a reason against. What they mean is this:тАФ ‘Sounding of the anklets’ is only possible in the ‘feet’ and thus cannot be said to be a reason for рдЙрдкрдорд╛, unless it is determined that it is impossible in the ’lotus’. Thus, ‘sounding of the anklets’ is designated as a reason against, because it is first apprehended as such. In this (very) manner, the learned should examine whether a thing should be called a reason for, or a reason against, elsewhere also.

C. OF IDENTICAL POSITION

K─Б. lv. ab c:тАФ

When two f

igures, (one) of ‘word’ and (the other) of ‘sense’, prominently reside to

gether in the same place, (that is) also (Commixture).

‘Place’ means ‘words’. Thus,

if both a fi

gure of ‘sense’ and a fi

gure of word’ also, prominently reside in identical words, that is also another (kind of) Commixture. The wordрд╕реНрдлреБрдЯрдореН in the K─Бrik─Б shows that if the figures are not prominent, they do not constitute this kind of Commixture.

It is instanced in рд╕реНрдкрд╖реНрдЯреЛрд▓реНрд▓рд╕рддреНetc. verse 184. Here,two figures, i. e.рд░реВрдкрдХand рдЕрдиреБрдкреНрд░рд╛рд╕reside in identical words, twice in the compound wordрд╕реНрдкрд╖реНрдЯреЛрд▓реНрд▓рд╕рддреН etc. and once inрд╢реНрд▓рд┐рд╖реНрдЯрд╛рд╖реНрдЯ etc. i. c. in the words рдХрд┐рд░рдгрдХреЗрд╕рд░рд╕реВрд░реНрдпрдмрд┐рдВрдмрд╡рд┐рд╕реНрддреАрд░реНрдгрдХрд░реНрдгрд┐рдХ andрджрд┐рдЧреНрджрд▓рдХрд▓рд╛рдк. A rule has been stated in the K─Бrik─Б that a figure of ‘sense and a figure of ‘word’ reside in one and the same place; but this rule is only general, not universal; thus, two figures of ‘word’ may also reside in one and the same place; as in рдХрд▓рдХрд▓реЛetc.

Here, рдЕрдиреБрдкреНрд░рд╛рд╕ and рдпрдордХ reside in identical words.

The figures of ‘sense’ also may reside in one and the same place; as in рд╡рдХреНрддреНрд░рд╛рд░рд╡рд┐рдиреНрдж116 etc.

Here, рд░реВрдкрдХ and рдЕрддрд┐рд╢рдпреЛрдХреНрддрд┐, the first in рд╡рдХреНрддреНрд░рд╛рд░рд╡рд┐рдиреНрдж, and the econd in рдордзреБрд╡реНрд░рддрд╛:, reside in one and the same compound wordрд╡рдХреНрддреНрд░рд╛рд░рд╡рд┐рдиреНрджрдордзреБ etc.

K─Б. lv. e dтАФThus, this (Commixture) has been declared to be threefold.

Thus, this Commixture has been declared to be only threefold, being possible (1) where there is a mutual subserviency (of figures), (2) where there is a doubt, (as re

gards f

igures), and (3) where the fi

gures are apprehended117 as residing in identicaред

words. It is impossible to divide Commixture in any other manner, i. e. by turning the union of every two of the figures hitherto described into a separate Commixture; for, such divisions will be endless.

  • Thus, figures admitting of division into three classes, i. e. the class of those which belong to ‘word’, of those which belong to ‘sense’ and of those which belong to both (‘word’ and sense’) have been expounded.*

  • (If it be said): All these figures divided into three classes, equally serve the purpose of investing a poem with beauty, on what circumstance then is the regulation based that certain figures belong to’ word’, certain others to ‘sense’ and certain others to both word’ and’ sense.’*

(We reply): The question, whether in a poem a certain fault, excellence, or figure belong to ‘word’ or ‘sense’ or both as the case may be, is, as has been already declared in the ninth Ull─Бsa of this (book), to be regulated in accordance with the Laws of presences and absences alone (namely, that the word being present the figure is present, the word being absent the figure is absent and so forth). There is no other circumstance (guiding this regulation). Thus, of whichever of these (i. e. of either ‘word’, or ‘sense’ or both) a figure follows the presence and absence, to that a figure is determined to belong. That a figure follows the presence and absence of ‘word’ means that the words containing a figure do not endure an exchange with other words. Thus, if the words containing a figure do not endure an exchange with other words, it is a figure of ‘word’. If those words endure an exchange with other words, it is a figure of ‘sense’. And if some of them endure an exchange with other words, and others do not, it is a figure of both ‘word’ and ‘sense’.

If it be again urged: Just as рдкреБрдирд░реБрдХреНрддрд╡рджрд╛рднрд╛рд╕118 and рдкрд░рдореНрдкрд░рд┐рддрд░реВрдкрдХ have been classed as figures of both ‘word’ and ‘sense,’ inasmuch as they follow the presence and absence of both, i. e. in them certain words endure an exchange with other words and certain others do not ; so such figures as рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдиреНрдпрд╛рд╕,рдЙрдкрдорд╛ etc. that are based upon both senses and (paronomastic) words, as instanced in рдХреНрд╖рдгрджрд╛рд╕рд╛рд╡рдХреНрд╖рдгрджрд╛and рд╕рдХрд▓рдХрд▓рдВ рдкреБрд░рдореЗрддрддреН etc. also deserve to be classed as figures of both. How then have you ranked them among the figures of sense’ only, instead of ranking them among the figures of both?

We reply :тАФWe have classed рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдиреНрдпрд╛рд╕ etc. as figures of ‘sense,’ because in them the strikingness of the sense is most prominently apprehended, although, really speaking, they do belong to both. Thus, just as рдкреБрдирд░реБрдХреНрддрд╡рджрд╛рднрд╛рд╕ and рдкрд░рдореНрдкрд░рд┐рддрд░реВрдкрдХ are figures of both word’ and ‘sense because they follow the presence and absence of both, so рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдиреНрдпрд╛рд╕ and others, which are based upon (paranomastic) words should also be understood (as figures of both )’ word’ and ‘sense’ because they follow the presence and absence of both. And if in complete disregard of (this) real fact, these figures have been defined among the figures of sense’, that is only due to the fact that in them the strikingness of the sense is (most) prominently apprehended.

If it be said:тАФ Why should not the classification of figures as figures of ’ word ’ etc. be regulated (as is done119 by

the author of рдЕрд▓рдВрдХрд╛рд░рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╕реНрд╡ ) in accordance with the principle of the relation of the abode and the abider?

We reply :тАФ Even though we accept the view that in whichever of these (word,’ ‘sense,’ or both) a figure resides to that a figure belongs, still, we must (ultimately) accept the Laws of presences and absences themselves. For the particularrelation of the abode and the abider, that is admitted to exist between figures’ on the one hand and ‘words’, etc. on the other, does not exist independently of these laws. For instance, such a figure asрдЙрдкрдорд╛** abides in ‘senses,’ only because senses’ being present, рдЙрдкрдорд╛ is present and ‘senses’ being absentрдЙрдкрдорд╛ is absent.

If it be said:тАФThe relation of the abode and the abider exists between ‘figures’ and ‘word’ etc. independently of these Laws, since this relation directly exists between them. Thus, for instance, рдЙрдкрдорд╛ directly abides in ‘senses’ and hence the relation of the abode and the abider betweenрдЙрдкрдорд╛ and ‘senses’ is independent of the Laws of presences and absences.

We reply:тАФ The relation of the abode and the abider does not exist directly in all cases. For instance, this relation does not directly exist between such figures as рдпрдордХetc. and ‘words,’ since рдпрдордХ does not directly reside in ‘words’ but in ’letters’. So also рдЙрддреНрдкреНрд░реЗрдХреНрд╖рд╛, рд╕рдорд╛рд╕реЛрдХреНрддрд┐ etc. in asmuch as they are capable of being made only by a human being, do not directly reside in ‘senses’ but in the soul.

If it be said that although this relation does not directly exist between ‘figures’ and ‘words’ etc., yet it may exist between them indirectly; we reply that if we admit such an indirect existence of the relation of the abode and the abider between ‘figures’ and ‘words’ etc., the result would be that what are called figures of ‘word’ would have to be styled. figures of ‘sense’ and vice versa. For every figure of ‘word,’

as a matter of fact, resides in ‘sense’ indirectly, and every figure of ‘sense’ also resides in ‘word’ indirectly.

It is therefore better to accept only the aforesaid Laws of presences and absences as our guiding principle in distinguishing figures from each other i. e.

in determining whether a figure belongs to ‘word’ or to ‘sense’ or to both.

If it be said: The Ancients have treated of the ‘faults’ of figures. The fact that you do not treat of them raises a doubt as to whether such faults are impossible, or being possible have been passed over by you. You cannot say that they are impossible, because that would be against experience. Your omission, on the other hand, would make you liable to the fault of Deficiency.

We reply:тАФ

[FAULTS OF FIGURES. ]

K─Б. lvi:тАФ Althou

gh it is possible that some faults may be found in (i. e. figures of ‘word’ and of ‘sense’), still, they have not been treated here, because they come under some one or another, as the case may be, of those that have been described (already).

Already= In the seventh Ull─Бsa. For instance, the three faults of Alliteration, i.e. Absence of Usage (рдкреНрд░рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзреНрдпрднрд╛рд╡), Fruitlessness (рд╡реИрдлрд▓реНрдп) and Opposition to style (рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐рд╡рд┐рд░реЛрдз) are not different from Opposition to Usage (рдкреНрд░рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрд┐рд╡рд┐рд░реБрджреНрдзрддрд╛),Superfluousness (рдЕрдкреБрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рд░реНрдерддреНрд╡), and Incongruity of letters (рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдХреВрд▓рд╡рд░реНрдгрддрд╛), respectively; because their natures are identical with the natures of these.

Examples in order:тАФ рдкреНрд░рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзреНрдпрднрд╛рд╡ is instanced in рдЪрдХреНрд░реА рдЪрдХреНрд░рд╛рд░etc. verse 185. Here, the praise of each (part of the Sun’s chariot рдЪрдХреНрд░рд╛рд░рдкрдВрдХреНрддрд┐ etc. which is the) object (of the verb рд╕реНрддреМрддрд┐) by each corresponding (deity which is the) subject (of the verbрд╕реНрддреМрддрд┐) is stated only with a view to (secure) Alliteration. Such (a praise) is, however, unknown in the Pur─Бс╣Зas, Epics, etc. Thus, this is, no other than рдкреНрд░рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрд┐рд╡рд┐рд░реБрджреНрдзрддреНрд╡

рд╡реИрдлрд▓реНрдпis instanced in рднрдг рддрд░реБрдгрд┐ etc. verse 186. Here,. on a careful consideration it will appear that no strikingness is apprehended from the sense expressed (by the verse). The two adjectives120рдЕрдирдгреБрд░рдгрдиреНetc. and рдЕрд╡рд┐рд░рдд etc. do not at all contribute to the strikingness of the expressed sense of the verse, i. e. рддреНрд╡рджреАрдпрдВ рдкрд░рд┐рд╕рд░рдгрдВ etc. nor do they in any way contribute to the strikingness of the suggested sense of the verse, i. e. ‘prospective separation.’ The employment of these adjectives is only for the sake of securing Alliteration.

Thus, the Fruitlessness of Alliteration is nothing but Superfluousness. Alliteration, although present, is not here striking beeause the excellence of words (which is Alliteration) is not here accompanied by a corresponding excellence of senses. Figures of word’ also, become striking, only by investing a sense with a particular excellence. The designation of a figure of ‘word’ is due only to the fact that words in it do not endure an exchange with other words.

рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐рд╡рд┐рд░реЛрдз is instanced in рдЕрдХреБрдгреНрдареЛ etc. verse 188. Here, by abandoning121 the Dulcet (рдЙрдкрдирд╛рдЧрд░рд┐рдХрд╛) style which letters manifesting Sweetness (рдорд╛рдзреБрд░реНрдп), the Grand (рдкрд░реБрд╖рд╛) style containing letters that are harsh and that manifest Energy (рдУрдЬрд╕реН) is employed. This styleтАФ this exuberance of harsh lettersтАФis, in the manner described before, i. e. while treating of Excellences (рдЧреБрдг) in the 8th Ull─Бsa, (extremely) inappropriate to the Erotic (рд╢реГрдВрдЧрд╛рд░) whichis the flavour (рд░рд╕) in the present verse. Thus, Opposition

to style consisting in an Alliteration of harsh letters is nothing but the fault called incongruity of letters.

Composition of a Rhyme in three quarters (only of a verse) is the fault (named) Unemployedness (рдЕрдкреНрд░рдпреБрдХреНрддрддреНрд╡); as instanced in рднреБрдЬрдВрдЧрдорд╕реНрдпреЗрд╡ etc. verse 189. Here, the Rhyme, рд╕рджрдВрднрд╛рдГ occurring in three quarters only is nothing but Unemployedness. For, such is not the practice of poets in general. The practice122is to employ the Rhyme in one quarter or two or four, but not in three.

In рдЙрдкрдорд╛, Inferiority of the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди over the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп in point of class or size, or Superiority of the same kind (i. e. in point of class or size) is the fault (called) Improper Signification; whilst, Deficiency and Redundancy residing in the (common) property come under Deficiency and Redundancy of a word, respectively.

Examples in order:тАФ Inferiority in point of class is instanced in рдЪрдгреНрдбрд╛рд▓реИрдГ etc.

Here, the class or rather caste of a рдЪрдгреНрдбрд╛рд▓ is inferior to that of the man under description. This inferiority of the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди suggests “doing of sinful deeds,” which is repugnant to the object under discourse; where this suggestion is, however, intended, there is no fault. The present123 verse is thus an example of the fault under description, only when the comparison is intended in point of ‘rashness,’ not of ‘sinfulness."

Inferiority in point of size is instanced in рд╡рд╣реНрдирд┐рд╕реНрдлреБрд▓рд┐рдВрдЧ etc. Here, the spark of fire is far inferior in size to the Sun.

Superiority in point of class is instanced in рдЕрдпрдВ рдкрджреНрдорд╛рд╕рди etc. verse 190.

Here, Brahm─Б is superior to the рдЪрдХреНрд░рд╡рд╛рдХin point of class. The word ‘Brahman’ is a class-noun here, because Brahm─Бs are supposed to be many, there being one for each рдХрд▓реНрдк.

Superiority in point of size is instanced in рдкрд╛рддрд╛рд▓рдорд┐рд╡etc. verse 191. Here, Hell etc. are vastly superior to the navel etc. in point of size.

Thus, here, i. e. in all these examples the (various) objects under description are extremely depreciated by (getting) рдЪрдгреНрдбрд╛рд▓рд╜ etc. as the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рдирд╜; such comparisons bring out only contempt or ridicule of the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдпрд╜;тАФ contempt when the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рдирд╜ are inferior, ridicule when they are superior. Thus, this is nothing but Improper Signification (рдЕрдиреБрдЪрд┐рддрд╛рд░реНрдерддреНрд╡).

Deficiency of the common property is instanced in рд╕ рдореБрдирд┐рд░реНрд▓рд╛рдЮреНрдЫрд┐рддреЛ etc: verse 192.

Here the property called ’lightning’ possessed by theрдЙрдкрдорд╛рди corresponding to (the property) ‘Mu├▒ja-grass’ possessed by the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп is not expressed by any word in the verse. Nor can that property be obtained by implication; for, there is no invariable concomitance between the two properties. Without that property, however, resemblance stated in the verse is not clearly apprehended. Thus there is a fault. But this fault is no other than Deficiency of a word.

Redundancy of the common property is instanced in рд╕ рдкреАрддрд╡рд╛рд╕рд╛: etc. verse 193. Here ‘Conch’ or any other property of the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдпis not stated: therefore, the statement of (the property) ‘Moon’ of the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди, corresponding to that of theрдЙрдкрдореЗрдп is redundant. Thus there is a fault. But this fault is no other than Redundancy of a word.

So, also, if the difference of Gender or of Number would make a word expressive of a property that is common to theрдЙрдкрдореЗрдп and the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди, assume the gender or number of a word expressive of either, and thus would make the common property uncommon i. e. would connect it with either the

рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп or the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди only but not with both, then inasmuch as that property is connected with one only, i. e. either theрдЙрдкрдореЗрдп or the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди, comparison cannot be apprehended from the verse, since its apprehension is possible only when the common property that is stated in the verse becomes connected with both the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп and the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди.

If it be said:тАФ Though the common property expressed in the verse is connected with one only, i. e. either the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп or the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди, still, we may apprehend comparison by taking another common property which may be supposed understood124 as indicated by the particles рдЗрд╡ etc.

We reply:тАФ Although in this way the apprehension of comparison is possible, still, in virtue of this common property. that is understood, (the thing mentioned in the verse as either) the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп or the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди would be apprehended as either the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп or the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди, not by itself, but only as possessed of the property that is stated in the verse. But this is not what is intended by the poet. For, what he intends is that comparison should be apprehended by means of that common property which is stated in the verse and the presence of which alone is indicated by the particles рдЗрд╡etc., and that the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп and the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди should be understood as such, by themselves. Thus, what is intended by the poet being clearly not established, this difference of Gender or of Number is a fault. But this fault is no other than Violation of Uniformity.

According to Prabh─Б125 and Chakravarti126,the Violation of Uniformity here is thus:тАФ The comparison which began by

having the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдпor the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рдиas not possessed of any attribute, ends by having theрдЙрдкрдорд╛рди or the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдпas possessed ofan attribute.

According to Vivaraс╣Зa127 рдЙрдкрд╕рдВрд╣рд╛рд░рд╛рддреНред Viv."), it is thus:тАФ The common property that began by connecting itself with the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдпor the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рдиexpressedly now ends by connecting itself with the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди or the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп impliedly.

According to Saс╣Зketa128,Violation of Uniformity here consists in the fact that the common property assumes one gender when connecting itself with the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди, and another gender when connecting itself with the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп.

Difference of Gender is instanced in рдЪрд┐рдиреНрддрд╛рд░рддреНрдирдорд┐рд╡etc. Here, the common property: рдЪреНрдпреБрддрддреНрд╡ being expressed by a noun in the masculine gender becomes connected with the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп only, and not with the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди. This is, however, Violation of Uniformity as shown above. If no common property is stated in the verse, this fault does not occur. It does not also occur if a common property is expressed by a verb; as in рд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрд╡ рдЧрдЪреНрдЫрддрд┐ рд╖рдгреНрдвреЛрд╜рдпрдореН etc.

Difference of Number is instanced in рд╕рдХреНрддрд╡реЛetc.

Here, the common property рд╢реБрджреНрдзрддреНрд╡ expressed by a noun in the plural number becomes connected with the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп ‘рд╕рдХреНрддреБ’ only. Here, the difference of gender, though present, is insignificant. For, if the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рдиbe in the plural number, connection of the common property with both would be possible, in spite of the difference of gender. Where, however,

a word expressive of the common property assumes a grammatical form that requires no change when it is to be connected with the word expressive of either the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп or the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди, this fault does not occur, because the word has got a form which renders it capable of being connected with both the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдпand theрдЙрдкрдорд╛рди(in spite of the difference of gender or of number).

Difference of Gender no fault, is instanced in рдЧреБрдгреИрд░рдирд░реНрдзреНрдпреИрдГ etc. Here, the common property рдЕрдирд░реНрдзреНрдпрддреНрд╡ can be equally connected with both the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп ‘рдЧреБрдгреИрдГ’ and the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди ‘рд░рддреНрдиреИрдГ’, though the genders of the words expressive of both are different.

Difference of Number no fault, is instanced in рддрджреНрд╡реЗрд╖реЛetc. verse 194. Here, the common propertiesрдЕрд╕рджреГрд╢рдГ, рдордзреБрд░рддрд╛рднреГрддрдГetc. can be equally connected with both the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп рд╡реЗрд╖ and the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди ‘рд╡рд┐рднреНрд░рдо’. (Similarly) also, when there is a Difference of Tenses or Persons, or a Change of the Imperative Mood etc. the apprehension (of comparison) does not strike (us) as that of a thing possessed of a uniform nature in the manner in which it strikes us when there is no difference of Tenses etc. Thus, this Difference or Change also comes under Violation of Uniformity itself.

Difference of Tenses is instanced in рдЕрддрд┐рдерд┐рдВ рдирд╛рдо etc. verse 195. Here, (what is intended is): рдЪреЗрддрдирд╛ рдкреНрд░рд╕рд╛рджрдВ рдЖрдкреНрдиреЛрддрд┐but not (рдкреНрд░рд╕рд╛рджрдВ) рдЖрдк. Thus, there is here a difference of Tenses.

Difference of Persons is instanced in рдкреНрд░рддреНрдпрдЧреНрд░etc. verse 196. Here, (what is intended is) : рд▓рддрд╛ рд╡рд┐рднреНрд░рд╛рдЬрддреЗ but not (рд▓рддрд╛)рд╡рд┐рднреНрд░рд╛рдЬрд╕реЗ. The latter part of the verb рднреНрд░рд╛рдЬреН*, ie the termination* рд╕реЗof the second person singular makes the verb рднреНрд░рд╛рдЬреНagree with the pronoun рддреНрд╡рдореН understood referring to рд╡рд╛рд╕рд╡рджрддреНрддрд╛who is the person addressed in the verse. For, it is a rule that a word denoting a person addressed, agrees with a verb in the second person. Now, since the latter part (рд╕реЗ) makes the verbрднреНрд░рд╛рдЬреНagree with (the noun рд▓рддрд╛ denoting) an object that is not addressed, (the second person of the verb) must be changed

(into the third person). For, the connection of this verb withрд▓рддрд╛ a noun not in the vocative case cannot be apprehended unless this change is effected. Thus, there is a difference of Persons. We should, therefore, read рд╡рд┐рднреНрд░рд╛рдЬрддреЗ. This termination of the third person can now make the verb рднреНрд░рд╛рдЬреНagree with рднрд╡рддреА a noun which refers to рджреЗрд╡реА in the vocative case.

Change of the Imperative Mood is instanced in рдЧрдЩреНрдЧреЗрд╡ рдкреНрд░рд╡рд╣рддреБetc.Here, (what is intended is): рдЧрдВрдЧрд╛ рдкреНрд░рд╡рд╣рддрд┐, but not(рд╕рд╛) рдкреНрд░рд╡рд╣рддреБ . For, the Imperative mood can be used in connection with рдХреАрд░реНрддрд┐ only, but not in connection with the Ganges which was and is even now flowing. Thus the Imperative Mood which consists in making a thing do what it was not doing (before) is changed into the Indicative.

  • Similarly, other like things, although admitting of a connection with theрдЙрдкрдорд╛рди, may not admit of a connection (with theрдЙрдкрдореЗрдп*); thus, the change of the Imperative Mood etc. (may be found to occur elsewhere also).

For instance, there may be a change of the Benedictive mood as in рдЪрд┐рд░рдВ рдЬреАрд╡рддреБ129etc. So also there may be a change of a verb as in рдЗрдВрджреНрд░рд╕реНрдпреЗрд╡130 etc., where the verb рдкреНрд░рд╛рд░реНрдереНрдпрддреЗ is impossible in the case of the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди, and must, therefore, be changed into another.

The wordрднреЗрдж inрд╡рд┐рдзрд┐рднреЗрджmeans ‘change’ not ‘difference.’ For, we do not here get two different Imperative Moods, one as connected with the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдпand the other as connected with the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди.

(If it be said :) In all the examples above cited, we may take a common property, either expressed or implied, different

from that which is affected by the change of tenses etc.; thus through this another property, the apprehension of comparison may result; afterwards the common property which is under dispute may be connected with either the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп or the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди as the case may be. For instance, in the verse рд╡рд┐рднреНрд░рд╛рдЬрд╕реЗetc., we may take рд╡рд┐рд╡рд┐рдХреНрддрдореВрд░реНрддрддреНрд╡asthe common property between the ‘creeper’ and the ‘Heroine’ and by means of it may understand comparison ; we may then connect рд╡рд┐рднреНрд░рд╛рдЬрд╕реЗ with рдирд╛рдпрд┐рдХрд╛only. Thus, there is no Difference of Tenses etc. at all in the above examples. In those places also where another common property is absent and the comparison is apprehended throughthat common property which is expressed (in the sentence) and which undergoes a change on account of the change of tenses etc., as in рдпреБрдзрд┐рд╖реНрдард┐рд░ рдЗрд╡etc., comparison cannot fail to be apprehended, since we may take the same common property, i. e. (рд╕рддреНрдпрд╡рд╛рджрд┐рддреНрд╡) not as expressed by the words рд╕рддреНрдпрдВ рд╡рджрддрд┐ but as implied by the particle рдЗрд╡, and through it understand (comparison by understanding) the sentence thus:тАФ-This (man) whose habit, like that of Yudhisthira, is to speak the truth, speaks the truth. This common property cannot be changed, because the habit of speaking the truth which is the meaning of рд╕рддреНрдпрд╡рд╛рджрд┐рддреНрд╡тАФ is the same at all times (either in the past or in the present). It should not be urged that, comparison being thus effected by the words рдпреБрдзрд┐рд╖реНрдард┐рд░ рдЗрд╡рд╛рдпрдВ рд╕рддреНрдпрд╡рд╛рджреА, the remaining words рд╕рддреНрдпрдВ рд╡рджрддрд┐ are useless, and that thus, there is Tautology (рдкреМрдирд░реБрдХреНрддреНрдпрдореН in рд╕рддреНрдпрд╡рд╛рджреА) рд╕рддреНрдпрдВ рд╡рджрддрд┐. For, just as from the twice employment of the verb рдкреБрд╖реНin рд░реИрдкреЛрд╖рдВ рдкреБрд╖реНрдгрд╛рддрд┐, an additional idea of nourishment in a sumptuous (and not miserly) manner,’ is brought out and thus there is no Tautology there, so there is no Tautology here also, because the repetition of рд╕рддреНрдпрдВ рд╡рджрддрд┐ conveys the additional idea that truth-speaking is quite (disinterested and) natural and not selfish on the part of this man. Thus, (from the whole sentenceрдпреБрдзрд┐рд╖реНрдард┐рд░ etc.) we apprehend that this man is a speaker of the truth by speaking

the truth like рдпреБрдзрд┐рд╖реНрдард┐рд░, i. e. naturally; in other words, that he is a natural speaker of the truth.

(We reply:тАФ) True what you say. But this justification is to be resorted to only in the case of such examples as have long been in current use. It is not, however, completely free from objection. For, Tautology destroys, i. e. delays the apprehension of the thing in question such as a flavour or a figure. That it does so is the experience of men of taste and cannot, therefore, be gainsaid.

Moreover, we cannot accept your view that comparison can be apprehended by accepting a common property that is implied and rejecting that which is expressed. Because, comparison is intended to be brought out by means of the expressed property itself.

  • Absence of resemblance* (рдЕрд╕рд╛рджреГрд╢реНрдп) impossiblity (рдЕрд╕рдВрднрд╡)тАФfaults occurring in рдЙрдкрдорд╛тАФ also terminate in Improper Signification (рдЕрдиреБрдЪрд┐рддрд╛рд░реНрдерддреНрд╡) itself.

** рдЕрд╕рд╛рджреГрд╢реНрдпis instanced in рдЧреНрд░рдереНрдирд╛рдорд┐ etc. Here, resemblance between a poem’ and the ‘Moon,’ and senses’ and’ rays,’ is nowhere perceived in the world. Thus, this is improper Signification. The wordрдЧреНрд░рдереНрдирд╛рдорд┐131**shows that the figures in the line is рдЙрдкрдорд╛ and not рд░реВрдкрдХ.

Chakravarti132 says, however, that this fault is nothing but Unemployedness (рдЕрдкреНрд░рдпреБрдХреНрддрддреНрд╡), otherwise, some resemblance between the ‘poem’ and the Moon, say, for instance, ‘pleasingness,’ can be found out, and thus comparison can be

brought out from the verse, as it is from рдорд╣рд╛рдХрд╛рд╡реНрдпрд╡реНрдпреЛрдореНрдирд┐etc. an example of the fault called Obscurity (рдХрд╖реНрдЯрддреНрд╡).

Although рд╕рд╛рдзрд░реНрдореНрдпhere and elsewhere has been translated by the word ‘resemblance,’ still, as has been shown already (Vide Note, p. 1), it really means рд╕рд╛рдзрд╛рд░рдгрдзрд░реНрдорд╕рдВрдмрдВрдзwhich is the cause of тАШresemblance’ рдХрд╛рд╡реНрдп and рд╢рд╢реА, рдЕрд░реНрде and рд░рд╢реНрдорд┐ are here the рдЕрдиреБрдпреЛрдЧреАs133of the рд╕рдВрдмрдВрдз. The рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдпреЛрдЧреА of it here and in the other places where the word рд╕рд╛рдзрд░реНрдореНрдп occurs is рд╕рд╛рдзрд╛рд░рдгрдзрд░реНрдоitself.

** рдЕрд╕рдВрднрд╡** is instanced in рдирд┐рдкреЗрддреБрд░рд╛рд╕реНрдпрд╛etc. verse 197. Here, also flaming showers of rain issuing out of the orb of the Sun’ are impossible. Thus, the thing described (in the verse) displays nothing but Improper Signification.

The fault of рдЙрддреНрдкреНрд░реЗрдХреНрд╖рд╛called ‘Inability’ is nothing but Inexpressiveness (рдЕрд╡рд╛рдЪрдХрддреНрд╡) of a word. InрдЙрддреНрдкреНрд░реЗрдХреНрд╖рд╛ also, such words asрдзреНрд░реБрд╡, рдЗрд╡etc. alone are able to bring out (the sense of) probability and not the word рдпрдерд╛also which singly134, i. e. not accompanied by such a word as рдкреНрд░рд╛рдпрдГetc., is able to point out mere resemblance. Now that (resemblance) is not here intended. Thus, the inability of this (word, i. e. рдпрдерд╛) to bring out that (sense. i. e. the sense of probability) constitutes the fault of Inexpressiveness.

** рдЕрд╢рдХреНрддрд┐**is instanced in рдЙрджреНрдпрдпреМ etc. verse 198. Here, the faulty word is рдпрдерд╛ ; we should therefore read **рдзреНрд░реБрд╡рдВ135**for рдпрдерд╛.

The fault of рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдиреНрдпрд╛рд╕called ‘Objectlessness’ is nothing but Improper Signification.

  • The adducing of another proposition to corroborate the statement of a thing which, although imagined as probable, is yet void of real nature, and is, therefore, like any (other) un-*

real thing such as the horn of a hare, is extremely improper like the drawing of pictures in the sky. Thus, the fault “Objectlessness’ of this рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдиреНрдпрд╛рд╕corroborating the statement of a matter which is the subject of рдЙрддреНрдкреНрд░реЗрдХреНрд╖рд╛is nothing but Improper Signification.

рдирд┐рд░реНрд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрддреНрд╡ is instanced in рджрд┐рд╡рд╛рдХрд░рд╛рджреНрд░рдХреНрд╖рддрд┐ etc. verse 199. Here ‘fear from the Sun’ on the part of ‘darkness’ which is an inanimate object is itself impossible. Whence then the possibility of protection’ by ’the Him─Бlaya Mountain, due to this fear on the part of ‘darkness’?

Thus, this (fact), i. e. ’the Mountain’s protecting darkness’ being apprehended here as possessed of an unreal character, there is no (question of) improbability about it. Hence an attempt to corroborate this fact, i. e. to show that it is probable, is altogether useless. For136,corroboration has for its object the removal of an improbability. But, here the fact being unreal and of an indefinable nature the question whether it is probable or otherwise is quite irrelevant. It is only those facts which are real and whose natures are ascertained, which deserve corroboration, i. e. which must be shown to be probable. Thus, the corroboration of an unreal fact is faulty. It is faulty only when the fact is unreal and indefinable naturally. It is not faulty, however, when the fact, although unreal and indefinable naturally, is yet imagined by the poet as possessed of a real and definite nature; as in рд╕реБрд╕рд┐рддрд╡рд╕рдирд╛ etc. (Vide example of рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдиреНрдпрд╛рд╕). verse 88.

A рд╕рдорд╛рд╕реЛрдХреНрддрд┐, in virtue of attributes common to the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди and the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдп, intimates, i. e. causes the apprehension of, the

particular рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди intended in the verse, although it is not there stated in actual words. Hence inasmuch as that рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди is already apprehended, there is here no motive for again stating it. Thus, (this) purposelessness of (the statement of) the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди is a fault; but it is nothing but either Superfluity (рдЕрдкреБрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рд░реНрдерддреНрд╡) or Tautology (рдкреБрдирд░реБрдХреНрддрддреНрд╡); as in рд╕реНрдкреГрд╢рддрд┐etc. verse 200. Here, just as in virtue of the common attributes рд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрд╕реНрдкрд░реНрд╢рдХрд╛рд░рд┐рддреНрд╡*, and the use of the particular gender of the nouns* рддрд┐рдЧреНрдорд░реБрдЪрд┐ and рдХрдХреБрднреН*, the Sun is intimated to be the hero, and the ‘directions’ to be the ‘heroines;’ so for the same reasons, i. e. in virtue of the common attribute* рдЕрддрдиреБрдорд╛рдирдкрд░рд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдпрд╛ and the feminine gender of the noun рджрд┐рдирд╢реНрд░реА, ’the beauty of the autumnal day will also be intimated to be the rival heroine. This being the case, what necessity is there of stating the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди ‘рджрдпрд┐рддрд╛’ by the use of the word рджрдпрд┐рддрд╛ which is expressive of itself? Thus, the wordрджрдпрд┐рддрдпрд╛is either Superfluous (according to рдордореНрдордЯ), or Tautologous (according to others), because its sense is obtained by Implication from the other words of the verse.

If it be said: If the statement of the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди is open to the fault of superfluity, then рд╢реНрд▓реЗрд╖реЛрдкрдорд╛would be without a province; for, in it the presence of the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди is necessary as enabling it to become striking.

We reply:тАФ No. For, that is the province ofрд╢реНрд▓реЗрд╖реЛрдкрдорд╛ *where even though common (or paronomastic) attributes are present * рд╕рдорд╛рд╕реЛрдХреНрддрд┐, unless the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди is stated, is not apprehended as (clearly as in the verse рд╕реНрдкреГрд╢рддрд┐ etc. where it is clearly appremayeven though the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди may not be stated).

What is meant is this:тАФ Where even though the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рдиis expressed by a word expressive of itself, рд╕рдорд╛рд╕реЛрдХреНрддрд┐ does not vanish, there inasmuch asрд╕рдорд╛рд╕реЛрдХреНрддрд┐ isnecessarily apprehendedindependently of the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди,рд╕рдорд╛рд╕реЛрдХреНрддрд┐ itself purpose of intimating theрдЙрдкрдорд╛рди.Thus, the employment of aword to express theрдЙрдкрдорд╛рдиis there useless;as in рд╕реНрдкреГрд╢рддрд┐etc

But, where рд╕рдорд╛рд╕реЛрдХреНрддрд┐vanishes when the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди is expressed, and where the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди is not apprehended when it is not expressed, all the attributes mentioned in the verse being connected with the рдЙрдкрдореЗрдпonly, there the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рдиshould be expressed; as in a рд╕реНрд╡рдпрдВ рдЪetc. verse 201. Here, the рдЙрдкрдорд╛рди, i. e. ‘Morning twilight,’ cannot be clearly apprehended unless it is expressed by the word рдкреНрд░рднрд╛рддрд╕рдВрдзреНрдпрд╛.

In рдЕрдкреНрд░рд╕реНрддреБрддрдкреНрд░рд╢рдВрд╕рд╛also, uselessness of the statement of the matter in hand is the fault called ‘Superfluity.’

There also, the matter in hand, being apprehended in this very manner137, i. e. from paronomastic or common attributes should not be vitiated by the fault of Superfluity by again being expressed by a word; as in рдЖрд╣реНрд╡рддреЗрд╖реБ etc. verse 202. Here, the matter in hand. i. e. a ’thoughtless king’ can be intimated by (the description of) the Universal of the particular kind, i. e. the ‘Non-recognition of the difference of things,’ which is not the matter in hand. Thus, the expression of it again by a word is improper and constitutes the fault of either Superfluity or Tautology.

Thus, these faults belonging to fi

gures, and other possible faults also, similar to these, do not deserve to be separately treated, because they are included under the class of those very fi

gures which have been treated already, i. e. in the Seventh Ull─Бsa.

K─АVYAPRAK─А┼ЪA

APPENDIX

1 рдЕрддреНрдпреБрдХреНрддрд┐.

рдЕрддреНрдпреБрдХреНрддрд┐рд░рджреНрднреБрддрд╛рддрдереНрдпрд╢реМрд░реНрдпреМрджрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рд╡рд░реНрдгрдирдореНред
рддреНрд╡рдпрд┐ рджрд╛рддрд░рд┐ рд░рд╛рдЬреЗрдВрджреНрд░ рдпрд╛рдЪрдХрд╛рдГ рдХрд▓реНрдкрд╢рд╛рдЦрд┐рдирдГрее

Ku. 163.

рдЕрджреНрднреБрддрдВ рдЖрд╢реНрдЪрд░реНрдпрднреВрддрдореНред рдЕрддрдереНрдпрдВ рдорд┐рдереНрдпрд╛рднреВрддрдореНред A**.**

The word рд╡рд╕реНрддреБ in Mammaс╣нa’s definition of рдЙрджрд╛рддреНрддincludes in its meaning, courage, generosity etc. also as wealth. Thus, рдЕрддреНрдпреБрдХреНрддрд┐ is nothing but рдЙрджрд╛рддреНрдд (Vide Udyota on рдЙрджрд╛рддреНрддрд╛рд▓рдВрдХрд╛рд░.)

2 рдЕрдзрд┐рдХ.

рдпрддреНрд░рд╛рдиреНрдпреЛрдиреНрдпрд╡рд┐рд░реБрджреНрдзрдВ рд╡рд┐рд░реБрджреНрдзрдмрд▓рд╡рддреНрдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рдкреНрд░рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрдВ рд╡рд╛ред
рд╡рд╕реНрддреБрджреНрд╡рдпрдореЗрдХрд╕реНрдорд╛рдЬреНрдЬрд╛рдпрдд рдЗрддрд┐ рддрджреНрднрд╡реЗрджрдзрд┐рдХрдореНрее

Ru.

рд╡рд┐рд░реБрджреНрдзрд╛рднреНрдпрд╛рдВ рдмрд▓рд╡рддреАрднреНрдпрд╛рдВ рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рднреНрдпрд╛рдВ рдкреНрд░рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрдореНред

Na.

Ex

.

рдореБрдВрдЪрддрд┐ рд╡рд╛рд░рд┐ рдкрдпреЛрджреЛ рдЬреНрд╡рд▓рдиреНрддрдордирд▓рдВ рдЪ рдпрддреНрддрджрд╛рд╢реНрд╡рд░реНрдпрдореНред
рдЙрджрдкрджреНрдпрдд рдиреАрд░рдирд┐рдзреЗрд░реНрд╡рд┐рд╖рдордореГрддрдВ рдЪреЗрддрд┐ рддрдЪреНрдЪрд┐рддреНрд░рдореНред

This may be included under рд╡рд┐рд╖рдо as defined by Prad─лpa.

3 рдЕрдзрд┐рдХрд╛рд░рд░реВрдврд╡реИрд╢рд┐рд╖реНрдЯреНрдпрд░реВрдкрдХ.

рдЕрдзрд┐рдХрд╛рд░рд░реВрдврд╡реИрд╢рд┐рд╖реНрдЯрдпрдВ рд░реВрдкрдХрдВ рдпрддреНрддрджреЗрд╡ рддрддреНред S. D.

Ex.

рдЗрджрдВ рд╡рдХреНрддреНрд░рдВ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд╛рджреНрд╡рд┐рд░рд╣рд┐рддрдХрд▓рдВрдХрдГ рд╢рд╢рдзрд░рдГ
рд╕реБрдзрд╛рдзрд╛рд░рд╛рдзрд╛рд░рд╢реНрдЪрд┐рд░рдкрд░рд┐рдгрддрдВ рдмрд┐рдореНрдмрдордзрд░рдГред
рдЗрдореЗ рдиреЗрддреНрд░реЗ рд░рд╛рддреНрд░рд┐рдиреНрджрд┐рд╡рдордзрд┐рдХрд╢реЛрднреЗ рдХреБрд╡рд▓рдпреЗ
рддрдиреБрд░реНрд▓рд╛рд╡рдгреНрдпрд╛рдирд╛рдВ рдЬрд▓рдзрд┐рд░рд╡рдЧрд╛рд╣реЗ рд╕реБрдЦрддрд░рдГрее

This is рд░реВрдкрдХ.

4 рдЕрдиреБрдХреВрд▓.

рдЕрдиреБрдХреВрд▓рдВ рдкреНрд░рд╛рддрд┐рдХреВрд▓реНрдпрдордиреБрдХреВрд▓рд╛рдиреБрдмрдиреНрдзрд┐ рдЪреЗрддреНред

S. D.

Ex.

рдХреБрдкрд┐рддрд╛рд╕рд┐ рдпрджрд╛ рддрдиреНрд╡рд┐ рдирд┐рдзрд╛рдп рдХрд░рдЬрдХреНрд╖рддрдореНред
рдмрдзрд╛рди рднреБрдЬрдкрд╛рд╢рд╛рднреНрдпрд╛рдВ рдХрдгреНрдардорд╕реНрдп рджреГрдврдВ рддрджрд╛рее

This is a kind of рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдШрд╛рдд (Vide Udyota pp. 112тАФ3.)

5 рдЕрдиреБрдЧреБрдг.

рдкреНрд░рд╛рдХреНрд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрд╕реНрд╡рдЧреБрдгреЛрддреНрдХрд░реНрд╖реЛрд╜рдиреБрдЧреБрдгрдГ рдкрд░рд╕рдиреНрдирд┐рдзреЗрдГред
рдиреАрд▓реЛрддреНрдкрд▓рд╛рдирд┐ рджрдзрддреЗ рдХрдЯрд╛рдХреНрд╖реИрд░рддрд┐рдиреАрд▓рддрд╛рдореНрее Ku. 145.

** рддрджреНрдЧреБрдг** occurs also when the quality possessed by an object is brought into prominent relief by proximity with another object. Thus рдЕрдиреБрдЧреБрдгis not a distinct figure. (Vide Udyotaon рддрджреНрдЧреБрдгрд╛рд▓рдВрдХрд╛рд░.)

6 рдЕрдиреБрдкрд▓рдмреНрдзрд┐.

рдкреНрд░рдорд╛рдгрддреНрд╡реЗрди рдирд┐рд░реНрджрд┐рд╖реНрдЯрд╛рд╜рдиреБрдкрд▓рдмреНрдзрд┐рд░рд▓рдВрдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛ред
рдЕрдпрд╢рд╕реНрддрд╡ рдирд╛рд╕реНрддреАрддрд┐ рд╕рддреНрдпрдВ рдпрдиреНрди рд╢реНрд░реБрддрдВ рдХреНрд╡рдЪрд┐рддреНрее A

The mere knowledge derived from this kind of evidence is not striking and does not minister to the expressed or suggested sense of the verse. Thus, this is no figure. (Vide Udyota рдЕрдиреНрдпреЗрд╖рд╛рдВ рддреБ рдирд╛рд▓рдВрдХрд╛рд░рддреНрд╡рдореН ред рддрддреНрддрддреНрдкреНрд░рдорд╛рдгрдЬрдиреНрдпрдкреНрд░рдорд┐рддрд┐рд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрддреНрд╡рдХреГрдд- рдЪрдорддреНрдХрд╛рд░рд╛рднрд╛рд╡рд╛рддреНтАХ on рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдШрд╛рддрд╛рд▓рдВрдХрд╛рд░.)

7 рдЕрдиреБрдЬреНрдЮрд╛.

**рджреЛрдкрд╕реНрдпрд╛рднреНрдпрд░реНрдердирд╛рд╜рдиреБрдЬреНрдЮрд╛ рддрддреНрд░реИрд╡ рдЧреБрдгрджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╛рддреНред
рд╡рд┐рдкрджрдГ рд╕рдВрддреБ рдирдГ рд╢рд╢реНрд╡рджреНрдпрд╛рд╕реБ рд╕рдВрдХреАрд░реНрддреНрдпрддреЗ рд╣рд░рд┐рдГрее**Ku. 137.

The three divisions of рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖ mentioned by рдордореНрдордЯ are not exhaustive. Hence рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖ occurs also when a man desires a bad thing by seeing some good in it. Thus, рдЕрдиреБрдЬреНрдЮрд╛ is not a distinct figure. (Vide Udyota on рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рд╛рд▓рдВрдХрд╛рд░.)

8 (a) рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рдкрддреНрддрд┐.

Ex.

рддрд╡рд╛рдЧреНрд░реЗ рдпрджрд┐ рджрд╛рд░рд┐рджреНрд░реНрдпрдВрд╕реНрдерд┐рддрдВ рднреВрдк рджреНрд╡рд┐рдЬрдиреНрдордирд╛рдореНред
рд╢рдиреИрдГ рд╕рд╡рд┐рддреБрд░рдкреНрдпрдЧреНрд░реЗ рддрдордГ рд╕реНрдерд╛рд╕реНрдпрддреНрдпрд╕рдВрд╢рдпрдореНрее

(R. G. p. 487.)

рдХреЗрдирдЪрд┐рджрд░реНрдереЗрди рддреБрд▓реНрдпрдиреНрдпрд╛рдпрддреНрд╡рд╛рджрд░реНрдерд╛рдиреНрддрд░рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкрддреНрддрд┐рд░рд░реНрдерд╛рдкрддреНрддрд┐рдГрее

R. G. p. 485

When the establishment of one fact implies the establishment of another fact, the reason for the establishment of both being the same, it is рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рдкрддреНрддрд┐. According to Udyota, however,рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рдкрддреНрддрд┐ is included under the third kind of рдЕрддрд┐рд╢рдпреЛрдХреНрддрд┐or рдЕрдиреБрдорд╛рди. Thus, in the verse рд╕ рдЬрд┐рддрдГ рддреНрд╡рдиреНрдореБрдЦреЗрдиреЗрдиреНрджреБрдГ рдХрд╛ рд╡рд╛рд░реНрддрд╛ рд╕рд░рд╕реА-

рд░реВрд╣рд╛рдореН; there is рдЕрдиреБрдорд╛рди. In рддрд╡рд╛рдЧреНрд░реЗ etc., there is the third kind of рдЕрддрд┐рд╢рдпреЛрдХреНрддрд┐.

8 (b) рдЕрд░реНрдерд╛рдкрддреНрддрд┐ (as a kind of evidence)

рдХрд▓реНрдкрдирдВ рдЪрд╛рдиреНрдпрдерд╛рд╜рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзреНрдпрд╛рд╜рд░реНрдерд╕реНрдпрд╛рд░реНрдерд╛рдкрддреНрддрд┐рд░рд┐рд╖реНрдпрддреЗред
рдЧрдВрдЧрд╛ рдкрддрд┐рд╡реНрд░рддрд╛ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд╛рджрдиреНрдпрдерд╛рд╜рдЧреНрдирд┐рдВ рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗ

рд╢реНрдХрдердореНрее

** рдкрддрд┐рд╡реНрд░рддрд╛ рд╕реНрддреНрд░реА рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд╛рджреНрдЧрдВрдЧреИрд╡ред рдЕрдиреНрдпрдерд╛рд╜рдЧреНрдирд┐рдВ рдХрдердВ рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрддреНред рдЧрдВрдЧрд╛рддреНрд╡реЗ рддреБ рд╡рд╣реНрдирд┐рдкреНрд░рд╡реЗрд╢реЛ рди рджреБрд░реНрдШрдЯрдГред** A**.**

** рдЕрддреНрд░ рдкрддрд┐рд╡реНрд░рддрд╛рдпрд╛рдГ рдЧрдВрдЧрд╛рддреНрд╡рд╛рднрд╛рд╡реЗ рд╡рд╣реНрдирд┐рдкреНрд░рд╡реЗрд╢рд░реВрдкрд╛рд░реНрдерд╕реНрдпрд╛рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрдпрд╛ рдЧрдВрдЧрд╛рддреНрд╡рд░реВрдкрд╛рд░реНрдерд╕реНрдп рдХрд▓реНрдкрдирдореНред**

This is nothing but рдЕрдиреБрдорд╛рди.

9 рдЕрд▓реНрдк.
